3.8.4.2.1 The on-board shall start a Section timer for each section: 

--- Document Chunk 3670 ---
a) For Level 2: at the value of the time stamp of the message including the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3671 ---
b) For Level 1: at the time of passage over the first encountered balise of the balise 

--- Document Chunk 3672 ---
group giving the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3673 ---
3.8.4.2.1.1 Justification for b): This is to ensure that the timer is always started before or at the 

--- Document Chunk 3674 ---
same time as the related variable information is received . Thus the timer start is 

--- Document Chunk 3675 ---
independent of in which balise the variable information is given.  

--- Document Chunk 3676 ---
3.8.4.2.2 When a Section timer value becomes greater than the time -out value given by 

--- Document Chunk 3677 ---
trackside, the following shall apply: 

--- Document Chunk 3678 ---
a) the EOA/LOA and the SvL shall be withdrawn to the  entry point of the revoked 

--- Document Chunk 3679 ---
section. Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based information 

--- Document Chunk 3680 ---
stored on-board, which shall be deleted accordingly; 

--- Document Chunk 3681 ---
b) the National/ Default Value of the Release Speed shall apply ; 

--- Document Chunk 3682 ---
c) if any, a non zero target speed value at the EOA/LOA shall be set to zero. 

--- Document Chunk 3683 ---
3.8.4.2.2.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 3684 ---
3.8.4.2.3 The Section timer shall be stopped when the min safe front end of the train has passed 

--- Document Chunk 3685 ---
the associated Section timer stop location. 

--- Document Chunk 3686 ---
3.8.4.3 Time-out of the speed associated with the EOA/LOA 

--- Document Chunk 3687 ---
3.8.4.3.1 The on-board shall start a timer for the speed at the EOA/LOA: 

--- Document Chunk 3688 ---
a) For Level 2: at the value of the time stamp of the message including the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3689 ---
b) For Level 1: at the time of passage over the first encountered balise of the balise 

--- Document Chunk 3690 ---
group giving the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3691 ---
3.8.4.3.1.1 Justification for b): This is to ensure that the timer is always started before or at the 

--- Document Chunk 3692 ---
same time as the related variable information is received. Thus the timer start is 

--- Document Chunk 3693 ---
independent of in which balise the variable information is given. 

--- Document Chunk 3694 ---
3.8.4.3.2 When the LOA speed timer value  becomes greater than the time-out value given by 

--- Document Chunk 3695 ---
trackside, the speed associated with the EOA/LOA shall be set to zero (i.e. the Limit of 

--- Document Chunk 3696 ---
Authority becomes an End of Authority  and the SvL  is defined on-board according to 

--- Document Chunk 3697 ---
3.8.4.5). Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based information 

--- Document Chunk 3698 ---
stored on-board, which shall be deleted accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 3699 ---
3.8.4.4 Time-out of Overlap 

--- Document Chunk 3700 ---
3.8.4.4.1 The Overlap timer shall be started on -board when the train passes the Overlap timer 

--- Document Chunk 3701 ---
start location given by trackside with its ma x safe front end.  The timer shall be 

--- Document Chunk 3702 ---
considered as started even if a time-out value “infinite” is given. 

--- Document Chunk 3703 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 3714 ---
3.8.4.4.2 When the Overlap timer value becomes greater than the time -out value given by 

--- Document Chunk 3715 ---
trackside, the following shall apply: 

--- Document Chunk 3716 ---
a) the overlap information shall be deleted, i.e. the Supervised Location shall be  

--- Document Chunk 3717 ---
withdrawn to the Danger Point if there is any or else to the EOA. Refer to appendix 

--- Document Chunk 3718 ---
A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based information stored on -board, which 

--- Document Chunk 3719 ---
shall be deleted accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 3720 ---
b) the release speed associated with the Overlap shall be deleted 

--- Document Chunk 3721 ---
c) if any, a non zero target speed value at the EOA/LOA shall be set to zero. 

--- Document Chunk 3722 ---
3.8.4.4.3 If the train comes to a standstill after the Overlap timer has been started, the on-board 

--- Document Chunk 3723 ---
shall consider that the Overlap timer valu e became greater than its time -out value and 

--- Document Chunk 3724 ---
shall apply 3.8.4.4.2. 

--- Document Chunk 3725 ---
3.8.4.4.4 In case no Overlap timer is running when the on -board receives a new MA with an 

--- Document Chunk 3726 ---
Overlap timer start location in rear of the max safe front end of the train, the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 3727 ---
shall consider that the Overlap timer value became greater than its time-out value and 

--- Document Chunk 3728 ---
shall apply 3.8.4.4.2. 

--- Document Chunk 3729 ---
3.8.4.4.4.1 Justification: in this case the train is already beyond the timer start location, therefore it 

--- Document Chunk 3730 ---
is impossible to determine when that location was crossed and so what  share of the 

--- Document Chunk 3731 ---
time-out value has elapsed since the crossing event. The safe assumption is to 

--- Document Chunk 3732 ---
consider that the time-out value has been exceeded and therefore that the Overlap will 

--- Document Chunk 3733 ---
soon be released by the Interlocking. 

--- Document Chunk 3734 ---
3.8.4.4.5 In case an Overlap timer is already running when the on-board receives a new MA with 

--- Document Chunk 3735 ---
an Overlap timer start location in rear of the max safe front end of the train, the on -

--- Document Chunk 3736 ---
board shall keep the Overlap timer running but replace the Overlap time-out value with 

--- Document Chunk 3737 ---
the value received with the new MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3738 ---
3.8.4.4.5.1 Justification: this allows repetition of the MA via RBC (e.g. acknowledgment of current 

--- Document Chunk 3739 ---
MA was lost) without unintentionally affecting the Overlap timer. 

--- Document Chunk 3740 ---
3.8.4.5 Supervised Location 

--- Document Chunk 3741 ---
3.8.4.5.1 The Supervised Location (SvL) shall be defined on board as; 

--- Document Chunk 3742 ---
a) the end of overlap (if any and before time-out). 

--- Document Chunk 3743 ---
b) if not, the Danger Point (if any). 

--- Document Chunk 3744 ---
c) if not, the End Of Authority. 

--- Document Chunk 3745 ---
3.8.4.5.2 As long as a Limit of Authority is supervised, no SvL shall be defined on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 3746 ---

3.8.4.6.2 An infill MA shall be evaluated on -board only if the on -board equipment is in FS or LS 

--- Document Chunk 3760 ---
mode. 

--- Document Chunk 3761 ---
3.8.4.6.3 The infill information shall include the identity of the balise group at the next main 

--- Document Chunk 3762 ---
signal i.e. the identity of the balise group giving the information that is t ransmitted in 

--- Document Chunk 3763 ---
advance by the infill device. 

--- Document Chunk 3764 ---
3.8.4.6.4 An infill MA shall be evaluated on -board only if the linking information, regarding the 

--- Document Chunk 3765 ---
main signal balise group to which it refers, is available. 

--- Document Chunk 3766 ---
3.8.4.6.5 The on-board shall start a Section timer for each section beyond the next main signal: 

--- Document Chunk 3767 ---
a) When the infill information is received from a balise group at the time of passing the 

--- Document Chunk 3768 ---
first encountered balise of the infill balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 3769 ---
b) When the infill information is received from a loop at the time of receiving the loop 

--- Document Chunk 3770 ---
message. 

--- Document Chunk 3771 ---
c) When the infill information is received from a radio infill unit at the value of the time 

--- Document Chunk 3772 ---
stamp of the radio infill message including the MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3773 ---
3.8.5 MA Update 

--- Document Chunk 3774 ---
3.8.5.1 A new MA shall replace a previously received MA in the following ways: 

--- Document Chunk 3775 ---
a) When the new MA is given from a balise group at a main signal (i.e. not infill 

--- Document Chunk 3776 ---
information) or from the RBC all data included in the previous MA shall be replaced 

--- Document Chunk 3777 ---
by the new data.  

--- Document Chunk 3778 ---
b) When the new MA is given as infill information all data beyond the announced 

--- Document Chunk 3779 ---
balise group at the next main signal shall be replaced. 

--- Document Chunk 3780 ---
3.8.5.1.1 Note: This refers to all information included in the MA as listed in section 3.8.1.1 and 

--- Document Chunk 3781 ---
the Signalling related speed restriction (see section 3.11.6). 

--- Document Chunk 3782 ---
3.8.5.1.2 When an infill MA is  received, the on -board shall start a new MA section at the infill 

--- Document Chunk 3783 ---
location reference, i.e. the balise group at the next main signal (see 3.6.2.3.1). 

--- Document Chunk 3784 ---
3.8.5.1.3 If the SvL defined from the new MA is closer than the one supervised with the former 

--- Document Chunk 3785 ---
MA, this shall be considered by the on-board equipment as an MA shortening. Refer to 

--- Document Chunk 3786 ---
appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based information stored on -board, 

--- Document Chunk 3787 ---
which shall be deleted accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 3788 ---
3.8.5.1.4 If a new MA defines an SvL while the on -board was supervising an LOA, this shall 

--- Document Chunk 3789 ---
always be considered by the on -board equipment as an MA shortening regardless of 

--- Document Chunk 3790 ---
the SvL location. Refer to appendix A.3.4 for the exhaustive list of location based 

--- Document Chunk 3791 ---
information stored on-board, which shall be deleted accordingly. 

--- Document Chunk 3792 ---
3.8.5.2 It shall be pos sible to update the length of the current section by means of 

--- Document Chunk 3793 ---
repositioning information (see section 3.8.5.3). 

--- Document Chunk 3794 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.8.5.2.1 Note: The current section need not be the end section. 

--- Document Chunk 3806 ---
3.8.5.2.2 Repositioning information contained in a balise group message  shall only be evaluated 

--- Document Chunk 3807 ---
if linking information has announced a following balise group as unknown but 

--- Document Chunk 3808 ---
containing repositioning information. 

--- Document Chunk 3809 ---
3.8.5.2.3 A balise group message containing a movement authority shall not contain 

--- Document Chunk 3810 ---
repositioning information for the same direction. 

--- Document Chunk 3811 ---
3.8.5.2.3.1 Note: It is possible to combine repositioning with an infill MA. 

--- Document Chunk 3812 ---
3.8.5.2.4 The reception of repositioning information or of a new MA with an LOA shall not be 

--- Document Chunk 3813 ---
considered as an MA shortening by the on-board equipment.

3.8.6 Co-operative shortening of MA (Level 2 and 3 only) 

--- Document Chunk 4074 ---
3.8.6.1 It shall be possible to shorten a given MA using a special procedure between on -board 

--- Document Chunk 4075 ---
equipment and RBC. The procedure is as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 4076 ---
a) The RBC proposes a new MA with an EOA closer to the train than the current EOA, 

--- Document Chunk 4077 ---
optionally with a mode profile. 

--- Document Chunk 4078 ---

--- Document Chunk 4088 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4089 ---
b) The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall check the train front end position 

--- Document Chunk 4090 ---
versus the Indication supervision limit of the proposed shortened MA. 

--- Document Chunk 4091 ---
 If it is in rear, the on-board equipment shall accept the new MA. 

--- Document Chunk 4092 ---
 If it is in advance , the request shall be rejected and the previously received MA 

--- Document Chunk 4093 ---
remains valid 

--- Document Chunk 4094 ---

3.9 Means to transmit Infill information (Level 1 only) 

--- Document Chunk 4098 ---
3.9.1 General 

--- Document Chunk 4099 ---
3.9.1.1 It shall be possible to transmit infill information to the on-board equipment using 

--- Document Chunk 4100 ---
a) Balise groups 

--- Document Chunk 4101 ---
b) Euroloops 

--- Document Chunk 4102 ---
c) Radio infill units. 

--- Document Chunk 4103 ---
3.9.1.1.1 Note: If the information transmitted by Balise groups, Euroloops, and Radio includes 

--- Document Chunk 4104 ---
infill information, those devices are also identified as infill devices. 

--- Document Chunk 4105 ---
3.9.1.2 The principle used for the infill information shall be the same independent of 

--- Document Chunk 4106 ---
transmission media. 

--- Document Chunk 4107 ---
3.9.1.3 If the on -board system is not equipped with the infill transmission media as requested 

--- Document Chunk 4108 ---
by the announcement balise group, the announcement information shall be ignored by 

--- Document Chunk 4109 ---
the on -board equipment and the train shall proceed according to the previously 

--- Document Chunk 4110 ---
received information.  

--- Document Chunk 4111 ---
3.9.1.4 Note: No additional description is needed for infill by balise group (other than already 

--- Document Chunk 4112 ---
covered in previous chapters). 

--- Document Chunk 4113 ---
3.9.2 Infill by loop 

--- Document Chunk 4114 ---
3.9.2.1 An End Of Loop Marker (EOLM) is by definition a device to mark the beginning or the 

--- Document Chunk 4115 ---
end of a loop. When receiving this information, the on-board equipment knows that it is 

--- Document Chunk 4116 ---
entering/leaving a track equipped with a loop. In unidirectional applications it shall be 

--- Document Chunk 4117 ---
possible to have an EOLM only at the entry side of a loop. 

--- Document Chunk 4118 ---
3.9.2.2 Balise groups shall be used as EOL Ms. They act as an EOLM by sending the EOLM 

--- Document Chunk 4119 ---
information to the passing train.  

--- Document Chunk 4120 ---
3.9.2.3 EOLMs have an orientation that is identical to the balise group orientation. The general 

--- Document Chunk 4121 ---
rules for balise orientation therefore also apply to EOLMs.  

--- Document Chunk 4122 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4123 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4124 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4125 ---

--- Document Chunk 4132 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4133 ---
3.9.2.4 EOLM information might be contained in a balise group that contains other information.  

--- Document Chunk 4134 ---
3.9.2.5 The EOLM shall send the identity of the announced loop. 

--- Document Chunk 4135 ---
3.9.2.6 The on-board shall only accept information coming from the loop with the announced 

--- Document Chunk 4136 ---
identity.  

--- Document Chunk 4137 ---
3.9.2.7 Deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 4138 ---
3.9.2.8 Deleted.  

--- Document Chunk 4139 ---
3.9.2.9 The following information shall be sent in advance by the EOLM to prepare for 

--- Document Chunk 4140 ---
reception of the loop information: 

--- Document Chunk 4141 ---
 Loop identity used to identify the loop.  

--- Document Chunk 4142 ---
 Key to select the spread spectrum key necessary to receive the loop telegrams. 

--- Document Chunk 4143 ---
 Distance to the loop giving the distance from th e EOLM to the location from where 

--- Document Chunk 4144 ---
on loop messages can be received.  

--- Document Chunk 4145 ---
 Length of the loop giving the length of the loop over which messages can be 

--- Document Chunk 4146 ---
received.  

--- Document Chunk 4147 ---
 Indicator telling the on -board whether the orientation of the loop is identical or 

--- Document Chunk 4148 ---
reverse to the orientation of the announcing EOLM.  

--- Document Chunk 4149 ---
3.9.2.10 The on-board shall be prepared to receive messages from the Euroloop after passing 

--- Document Chunk 4150 ---
the EOLM. 

--- Document Chunk 4151 ---
3.9.2.11 When the on -board equipment reads the next main signal balise group or when it 

--- Document Chunk 4152 ---
detects that the next main signal balise group wa s missed, new infill information 

--- Document Chunk 4153 ---
possibly received from the loop shall be ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 4154 ---
3.9.2.12 The distances given in an EOLM (distance to loop, length of loop) are used for 

--- Document Chunk 4155 ---
diagnostic purpose only. They shall therefore not be used to restrict reception of loop 

--- Document Chunk 4156 ---
telegrams to specific locations.

3.9.3 Infill by radio 

--- Document Chunk 4158 ---
3.9.3.1 In level 1 areas it shall be possible to send to the on -board equipment orders to 

--- Document Chunk 4159 ---
establish/terminate a communication session with a radio infill unit.  

--- Document Chunk 4160 ---
3.9.3.2 The orders shall be sent via balise groups or via Radio Infill units. 

--- Document Chunk 4161 ---
3.9.3.3 The order to establish a communication session shall be ignored: 

--- Document Chunk 4162 ---
a) Intentionally deleted.  

--- Document Chunk 4163 ---
b) If the on-board equipment does not include radio.  

--- Document Chunk 4164 ---
3.9.3.4 If the on -board equipment includes radio, the communication session shall be 

--- Document Chunk 4165 ---
established using the same protocols and interfaces as for Level 2/3 operations.

3.9.3.5 If the order to establish a communication session with a radio infill unit sent via balise 

--- Document Chunk 4178 ---
groups is received by an on -board equipment, connected with another radio infill 

--- Document Chunk 4179 ---
unit(s), two cases may arise: 

--- Document Chunk 4180 ---
3.9.3.5.1 Case 1: the on -board can handle only one communication session at a time. In this 

--- Document Chunk 4181 ---
case, the onboard shall (unless §3.9.3.5.1.1 applies): 

--- Document Chunk 4182 ---
a) terminate the existing communication session at the location indicated in the order 

--- Document Chunk 4183 ---
b) establish a communication session wi th the RIU indicated in the order as soon as 

--- Document Chunk 4184 ---
action a) is completed. 

--- Document Chunk 4185 ---
3.9.3.5.1.1 The order shall be ignored in case it refers to an RIU with which a session is currently 

--- Document Chunk 4186 ---
being established or is already established. 

--- Document Chunk 4187 ---
3.9.3.5.2 Case 2: the on -board can handle more than one communi cation session at a time. In 

--- Document Chunk 4188 ---
this case, at the location indicated in the order the on-board shall: 

--- Document Chunk 4189 ---
a) terminate any communication session existing with RIU(s) not indicated in the order 

--- Document Chunk 4190 ---
b) as soon as a new communication session can be handled, establish a 

--- Document Chunk 4191 ---
communication session with the RIU indicated in the order, unless currently being 

--- Document Chunk 4192 ---
established or already established with the said RIU. 

--- Document Chunk 4193 ---
3.9.3.6 If the order to establish a communication session with a radio infill unit sent via Radio 

--- Document Chunk 4194 ---
Infill unit is received by an on-board equipment: 

--- Document Chunk 4195 ---
a) If the on -board can handle only one communication session, the order shall be 

--- Document Chunk 4196 ---
ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 4197 ---
b) If the on -board can handle two communication sessions simultaneously  and only 

--- Document Chunk 4198 ---
one session is ongoing , the existing communication session shall be maintaine d 

--- Document Chunk 4199 ---
and the new one shall be established. 

--- Document Chunk 4200 ---
c) If the on -board can handle two communication sessions simultaneously and two 

--- Document Chunk 4201 ---
sessions are ongoing, then the communication session related to the current infill 

--- Document Chunk 4202 ---
area shall be maintained, the other one shall be termina ted and the new one shall 

--- Document Chunk 4203 ---
be established. 

--- Document Chunk 4204 ---
3.9.3.7 A Radio Infill Unit shall not initiate a communication session with an on -board 

--- Document Chunk 4205 ---
equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 4206 ---
3.9.3.8 The order to establish/terminate a communication session sent via balise groups shall 

--- Document Chunk 4207 ---
be sent together with the following radio infill area information: 

--- Document Chunk 4208 ---
a) Location where to perform the action (referred to the balise group containing the 

--- Document Chunk 4209 ---
order).Note: if the action is to establish a communication session, this location 

--- Document Chunk 4210 ---
marks the beginning of the Radio Infill Area. 

--- Document Chunk 4211 ---
b) Next main signal  balise group identifier ( ignored by the on -board if the action is 

--- Document Chunk 4212 ---
Terminate communication session).Note: the reference location of this balise group 

--- Document Chunk 4213 ---
marks the end of the Radio Infill Area.

--- Document Chunk 4244 ---

its responsibility, it shall

--- Document Chunk 4247 ---
equipment, AND

--- Document Chunk 4249 ---
the next main signal balise group indicated in the information from the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 4250 ---
equipment.  

--- Document Chunk 4251 ---

--- Document Chunk 4252 ---
after having passed the previous main signal, was lost.

3.10 Emergency Messages 

--- Document Chunk 4317 ---
3.10.1 General 

--- Document Chunk 4318 ---
3.10.1.1 Emergency messages shall be sent individually to each on -board equipment, either as 

--- Document Chunk 4319 ---
high priority data or as normal priority data of the same radio connection, as desc ribed 

--- Document Chunk 4320 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 4321 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4322 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4323 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 4324 ---
3.4.0 

--- Document Chunk 4325 ---
12/05/14 

--- Document Chunk 4326 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 4327 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 4328 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 4329 ---
Page 69/200 

--- Document Chunk 4330 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 4331 ---
in Euroradio specification. Only emergency messages can be sent as high priority 

--- Document Chunk 4332 ---
data, not their acknowledgement or their revocation. 

--- Document Chunk 4333 ---
3.10.1.1.1 Justification: In case of hazardous events, it is possible to use high priority data in the 

--- Document Chunk 4334 ---
radio connection between RBC and on-board equipment to get a quick reaction.  

--- Document Chunk 4335 ---
3.10.1.2 An emergency message shall contain an identifier decided by the trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 4336 ---
3.10.1.3 The same identifier shall be used in case the emergency message is repeated. 

--- Document Chunk 4337 ---
3.10.1.3.1 If the on -board receives a new message with the sa me identifier it shall replace the 

--- Document Chunk 4338 ---
previous one. 

--- Document Chunk 4339 ---
3.10.1.4 Each emergency message to an on -board equipment shall be acknowledged, using 

--- Document Chunk 4340 ---
the corresponding emergency message identification number. 

--- Document Chunk 4341 ---
3.10.1.4.1 Note: This acknowledgement informs the RBC about the use of the emergen cy 

--- Document Chunk 4342 ---
message by on -board equipment and is independent from the general 

--- Document Chunk 4343 ---
acknowledgement for track-to-train messages, as specified in section 3.16.3.5. 

--- Document Chunk 4344 ---
3.10.2 Emergency Stop  

--- Document Chunk 4345 ---
3.10.2.1 It shall be possible to stop a train with a conditional or an unconditional emergency 

--- Document Chunk 4346 ---
stop message.  

--- Document Chunk 4347 ---
3.10.2.2 A conditional emergency stop message shall contain the information of a new stop 

--- Document Chunk 4348 ---
location, referred to the LRBG. In case, when receiving this message 

--- Document Chunk 4349 ---
 the train has already passed with its min safe front end the new stop location, the 

--- Document Chunk 4350 ---
emergency stop message shall be rejected and the RBC shall be informed. 

--- Document Chunk 4351 ---
 the train has not yet passed with its min safe front end the new stop location, the 

--- Document Chunk 4352 ---
emergency stop message shall be accepted, however this location shall be used by 

--- Document Chunk 4353 ---
the onboard to define the new EOA and SvL only if not beyond the current E OA. 

--- Document Chunk 4354 ---

--- Document Chunk 4386 ---

--- Document Chunk 4387 ---

--- Document Chunk 4389 ---

--- Document Chunk 4391 ---
3.11.2.1 Static Speed Restrictions are imposed by the trackside infrastructure, the train 

--- Document Chunk 4392 ---
characteristics, the signalling and the mode of the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 4393 ---

--- Document Chunk 4394 ---
a) Static Speed Profile (SSP) 

--- Document Chunk 4395 ---

--- Document Chunk 4396 ---

--- Document Chunk 4397 ---
d) Maximum Train Speed 

--- Document Chunk 4398 ---
e) Signalling related speed restriction (only level 1) 

--- Document Chunk 4399 ---
f) Mode related Speed Restriction. 

--- Document Chunk 4400 ---
g) STM Max speed (for details refer to Subset-035) 

--- Document Chunk 4401 ---
h) STM System speed (for details refer to Subset-035) 

--- Document Chunk 4402 ---
i) Level Crossing speed restriction (LX SR) 

--- Document Chunk 4403 ---
j) Override function related Speed Restriction

3.11.3 Static Speed Profile (SSP) 

--- Document Chunk 4433 ---
3.11.3.1.1 The Static Speed Profile (SSP) is a description of the fixed speed restrictions of a 

--- Document Chunk 4434 ---
given piece of track. The speed restrictions can be related to e.g. maximum line speed, 

--- Document Chunk 4435 ---
curves, points, tunnel profiles, bridges. 

--- Document Chunk 4436 ---
3.11.3.1.2 The Static Speed Profile is based on factors, which are both track and train dependent. 

--- Document Chunk 4437 ---
The relationship between track and train characteristics determine s the individual 

--- Document Chunk 4438 ---
Static Speed Profile for each train.  

--- Document Chunk 4439 ---
3.11.3.1.3 It shall be possible for every element (distance between two discontinuities) of a static 

--- Document Chunk 4440 ---
speed profile to define, if a transition to a higher speed limit than the speed limit 

--- Document Chunk 4441 ---
specified for this element is permitted before the complete train has left the element. 

--- Document Chunk 4442 ---

--- Document Chunk 4661 ---

board equipment, it is the responsibility of the trackside to set the appropriate 

--- Document Chunk 4700 ---
permitted braking distance with regard to the risk of not initiating the brake command 

--- Document Chunk 4701 ---
in due time when encountering a further balis e group providing restrictive information. 

--- Document Chunk 4702 ---
In other words, if deemed necessary, the trackside can include provisions based on 

--- Document Chunk 4703 ---
the characteristics of the balise group providing restrictive information e.g. distances 

--- Document Chunk 4704 ---
between balises in that group with regard s to validity direction of transmitted 

--- Document Chunk 4705 ---
information and balise group orientation, accuracy of balise location. 

--- Document Chunk 4706 ---
3.11.11.4.2 Note: If the permitted braking distance is to be achieved with the service brake, it is the 

--- Document Chunk 4707 ---
responsibility of the trackside to also consider an es timation of the on-board over-

--- Document Chunk 4708 ---
reading and under-reading amounts at the time the brake command is initiated in order 

--- Document Chunk 4709 ---
to lower the likelihood of the max safe front end of the train reaching the EBI 

--- Document Chunk 4710 ---
supervision limit. 

--- Document Chunk 4711 ---

--- Document Chunk 4712 ---
are counted from a single arbitrary reference location.

3.11.12 Gradients 

--- Document Chunk 4849 ---
3.11.12.1 The gradient information for a given piece of track shall be transmitted to the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 4850 ---
equipment in form of a gradient profile. 

--- Document Chunk 4851 ---
3.11.12.2 The gradient profile shall be continuous, i.e., give a gradient value for each location 

--- Document Chunk 4852 ---
within the piece of track covered by the profile. 

--- Document Chunk 4853 ---
3.11.12.3 A gradient value shall be identified as a positive value for an uphill slope, and with a 

--- Document Chunk 4854 ---
negative value for a downhill slope. 

--- Document Chunk 4855 ---
3.11.12.4 The gradient profile shall contain the gradient information as a sequence of gradient 

--- Document Chunk 4856 ---
values, constant between two defined locations each, see Figure 27. 

--- Document Chunk 4857 ---

3.12 Other Profiles 

--- Document Chunk 4887 ---
3.12.1 Track Conditions  

--- Document Chunk 4888 ---
3.12.1.1 The Track Condition function is used to inform the driver and/or the  train of a condition 

--- Document Chunk 4889 ---
in front of the train.  

--- Document Chunk 4890 ---
3.12.1.2 A Track Condition shall be given as profile data (e.g. non -stopping area), i.e. start and 

--- Document Chunk 4891 ---
end of the data is given, or location data (e.g. change of traction system) i.e. start 

--- Document Chunk 4892 ---
location given, depending on the type of track condition.  

--- Document Chunk 4893 ---
3.12.1.2.1 The starting point of a profile type track condition shall be evaluated taking into 

--- Document Chunk 4894 ---
account the max safe front end of the train, the end of the profile taking into account 

--- Document Chunk 4895 ---
the min safe rear end of the train. Location type data sha ll be evaluated taking into 

--- Document Chunk 4896 ---
account the max safe front of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 4897 ---
3.12.1.2.1.1 Note: The timing of output data to control train equipment (e.g. pantograph) is 

--- Document Chunk 4898 ---
application specific. 

--- Document Chunk 4899 ---
3.12.1.2.1.2 Exception 1: The starting point of a Big Metal Mass type track condition shall be 

--- Document Chunk 4900 ---
evaluated taking into account the max safe antenna position, the end of the profile 

--- Document Chunk 4901 ---
taking into account the min safe antenna position. 

--- Document Chunk 4902 ---

--- Document Chunk 4917 ---

--- Document Chunk 4918 ---
3.12.1.3 The types of track conditions to be covered by this function are: 

--- Document Chunk 4919 ---
 Powerless section, low er pantograph (initial state: no powerless section , i.e. 

--- Document Chunk 4920 ---
pantograph not to be lowered) 

--- Document Chunk 4921 ---
 Powerless section, switch off main power switch (initial state: no powerless section, 

--- Document Chunk 4922 ---
i.e. main power switch not to be switched off) 

--- Document Chunk 4923 ---
 Air tightness (initial state: no request for air tightness) 

--- Document Chunk 4924 ---
 Sound horn (initial state: no request for sound horn) 

--- Document Chunk 4925 ---
 Non stopping area (initial state: stopping permitted) 

--- Document Chunk 4926 ---
 Tunnel stopping area (initial state: no tunnel stopping area) 

--- Document Chunk 4927 ---
 Change of traction system, switch traction system on-board, used for train capable 

--- Document Chunk 4928 ---
of handling several traction systems (initial state: no initial state – keep the current 

--- Document Chunk 4929 ---
setting) 

--- Document Chunk 4930 ---
 Change of allowed current consumption, limit current consumed by the train, used 

--- Document Chunk 4931 ---
to adapt the maximum current consumption of the train to  the maximum current 

--- Document Chunk 4932 ---
allowed by the trackside (initial state: no initial state – keep the current setting) 

--- Document Chunk 4933 ---
 Big metal masses, ignore onboard integrity check alarms of balise transmission. 

--- Document Chunk 4934 ---
(initial state: alarms not ignored) 

--- Document Chunk 4935 ---
 Radio hole, stop supervision of t he loss of safe radio connection (initial state: loss 

--- Document Chunk 4936 ---
of safe radio connection supervised) 

--- Document Chunk 4937 ---
 Switch off regenerative brake (initial state: regenerative brake on) 

--- Document Chunk 4938 ---
 Switch off eddy current brake for service brake (initial state: eddy current brake on 

--- Document Chunk 4939 ---
for service brake) 

--- Document Chunk 4940 ---
 Switch off eddy current brake for emergency brake (initial state: eddy current brake 

--- Document Chunk 4941 ---
on for emergency brake) 

--- Document Chunk 4942 ---
 Switch off magnetic shoe brake (initial state: magnetic shoe brake on). 

--- Document Chunk 4943 ---
 Station platforms, enable passenger doors with or without steps ac cording to 

--- Document Chunk 4944 ---
platform location, side and height (initial state: not enabled). 

--- Document Chunk 4945 ---

--- Document Chunk 4946 ---
deceleration of the emergency brake might be affected if the effect of these brakes 

--- Document Chunk 4947 ---
was included in the calculation of the deceleration value.

3.12.2 Route Suitability  

--- Document Chunk 4982 ---
3.12.2.1 Route suitability data defines which values concerning loading gauge, traction system 

--- Document Chunk 4983 ---
and axle load category a train must meet to be allowed to enter the route. 

--- Document Chunk 4984 ---
3.12.2.2 The route suitability data is sent as location data from the trackside when needed. 

--- Document Chunk 4985 ---
3.12.2.3 On reception of route suitability data, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 4986 ---
compare it with the corresponding Train Data stored on-board. Unsuitability exists if: 

--- Document Chunk 4987 ---
a) The loading gauge profile of the train is not inclu ded in the list of loading gauges 

--- Document Chunk 4988 ---
accepted by trackside 

--- Document Chunk 4989 ---
b) The list of traction systems  accepted by the engine does not include the one 

--- Document Chunk 4990 ---
received from trackside 

--- Document Chunk 4991 ---
c) The axle load category of the train is higher than the permitted one received from 

--- Document Chunk 4992 ---
trackside 

--- Document Chunk 4993 ---

--- Document Chunk 5021 ---
3.12.3.1 General Rules  

--- Document Chunk 5022 ---
3.12.3.1.1 It shall be possible to transmit information to be displayed  to the driver from the 

--- Document Chunk 5023 ---
trackside to the on-board equipment in the form of text messages.  

--- Document Chunk 5024 ---
3.12.3.1.2 Text messages shall always be supplemented by conditions on when and where they 

--- Document Chunk 5025 ---
are to be displayed, and whether any acknowledgement is requested from the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 5026 ---
These parameters shall be transmitted individually for each message.  

--- Document Chunk 5027 ---
3.12.3.1.3 Text messages and the supplementary information shall always be transmitted in one 

--- Document Chunk 5028 ---
message.  

--- Document Chunk 5029 ---
3.12.3.1.4 Text messages can contain the text to be displayed in plain text or a number selecting 

--- Document Chunk 5030 ---
a fixed message. 

--- Document Chunk 5031 ---
3.12.3.1.4.1 Note: In case of plain text messages the trackside selects the language in which 

--- Document Chunk 5032 ---
the message is displayed.

--- Document Chunk 5094 ---

--- Document Chunk 5095 ---

--- Document Chunk 5097 ---

--- Document Chunk 5098 ---

--- Document Chunk 5099 ---

--- Document Chunk 5100 ---

--- Document Chunk 5108 ---

3.12.4 Mode profile  

--- Document Chunk 5136 ---
3.12.4.1 The Mode Profile can request On Sight mode , Limited Supervision mode and Shunting 

--- Document Chunk 5137 ---
mode. 

--- Document Chunk 5138 ---
3.12.4.2 For OS and LS mode the mode profile shall de fine the entry and the length of the On 

--- Document Chunk 5139 ---
Sight/Limited Supervision area. For SH mode the mode profile only defines the entry 

--- Document Chunk 5140 ---
location to SH mode, any length given shall be ignored by the on-board.  

--- Document Chunk 5141 ---
3.12.4.3 On reception of a new MA (with or without Mode Profile) the on-board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 5142 ---
delete the currently supervised Mode Profile. 

--- Document Chunk 5143 ---
3.12.4.3.1 Exception: When receiving a new MA by infill, any currently supervised Mode Profile 

--- Document Chunk 5144 ---
shall be deleted only beyond the reference location of the infill information. 

--- Document Chunk 5145 ---
3.12.4.4 In case the mode prof ile information for shunting is overwritten by a new shunting 

--- Document Chunk 5146 ---
profile, before the on -board equipment switches to SH mode, a previous list of balise 

--- Document Chunk 5147 ---
groups for SH area shall be deleted or replaced by a new list of balise groups  for SH 

--- Document Chunk 5148 ---
area. 

--- Document Chunk 5149 ---
3.12.4.5 The beginning of the Mode Profile relates to the max safe front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 5150 ---
3.12.4.6 The end of the mode profile relates to the min safe front end of the train.  

--- Document Chunk 5151 ---
3.12.5 Level Crossings 

--- Document Chunk 5152 ---
3.12.5.1 It shall be possible for trackside to inform the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 5153 ---
about the conditions under which a Level Crossing (LX) must be passed. 

--- Document Chunk 5154 ---
3.12.5.2 Each Level Crossing shall have an identity, so that all LX information shall be 

--- Document Chunk 5155 ---
independent of each other. This means that an individual LX information shall not 

--- Document Chunk 5156 ---
affect, nor be affected by, any other individual LX information. 

--- Document Chunk 5157 ---
3.12.5.3 If the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment receives a new LX information with the same 

--- Document Chunk 5158 ---
identity as an already received LX information, the new LX information shall replace 

--- Document Chunk 5159 ---
the previous one. 

--- Document Chunk 5160 ---
3.12.5.4 Level Crossing information shall be given as prof ile data, corresponding to the LX start 

--- Document Chunk 5161 ---
location and the length of the LX area. 

--- Document Chunk 5162 ---
3.12.5.5 Level Crossing information shall indicate whether the LX is protected or not. 

--- Document Chunk 5163 ---
3.12.5.6 In case the LX is not protected, ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall be informed: 

--- Document Chunk 5164 ---
a) at which speed the LX is allowed to be passed 

--- Document Chunk 5165 ---
b) whether the stopping of the train in rear of the LX start location is required or not 

--- Document Chunk 5166 ---
3.12.5.7 In case stopping in rear of the non protected LX is required, a stopping area in rear of 

--- Document Chunk 5167 ---
the LX start location shall be defined. 

--- Document Chunk 5168 ---

3.13 Speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 5180 ---
3.13.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 5181 ---
3.13.1.1 The speed and distance monitoring is the supervision of the speed of the train versus 

--- Document Chunk 5182 ---
its position, in order to assure that the train remains within the given speed and 

--- Document Chunk 5183 ---
distance limits. 

--- Document Chunk 5184 ---
3.13.1.1.1 Note: The speed and distance monitorin g of the on -board can only assure this when 

--- Document Chunk 5185 ---
the following necessary conditions are fulfilled: 

--- Document Chunk 5186 ---
 Brake system of the train functions as specified 

--- Document Chunk 5187 ---
 wheel/rail adhesion is sufficient for the required safe deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 5188 ---
 Brake characteristics (and other Train Data)  are correctly entered into the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 5189 ---
(automatic or by driver) 

--- Document Chunk 5190 ---
3.13.1.2 Note: The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment triggers brake commands and revokes 

--- Document Chunk 5191 ---
them, it may also receive status information if the brakes are applied or released. 

--- Document Chunk 5192 ---
However, it cannot be made res ponsible if brake control circuits outside the equipment 

--- Document Chunk 5193 ---
fail. Also the way the brakes are released by the driver after a revocation of a brake 

--- Document Chunk 5194 ---
command is an implementation issue. 

--- Document Chunk 5195 ---
3.13.1.3 Figure 28 gives an overview of the main elements c ontributing to the speed and 

--- Document Chunk 5196 ---
distance monitoring. These elements (inputs, functions and outputs) are detailed in the 

--- Document Chunk 5197 ---
following chapters. 

--- Document Chunk 5198 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.13.2 Inputs for speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 5341 ---
3.13.2.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 5342 ---
3.13.2.1.1 The traction / braking models, the brake position / brake percentage are used for the 

--- Document Chunk 5343 ---
definition of the kinematic behaviour of the train after a service brake command or an 

--- Document Chunk 5344 ---
emergency brake command has been initiated. 

--- Document Chunk 5345 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 5353 ---
Principles

--- Document Chunk 5355 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5356 ---
3.13.2.1.2 However, railway brakes have a statistical behaviour and braking distances vary within 

--- Document Chunk 5357 ---
the typical distribution for a given condition. Correction factors are therefore 

--- Document Chunk 5358 ---
incorporated for the speed and distance monitoring. 

--- Document Chunk 5359 ---
3.13.2.1.3 The correction factors will allow obtaining, from the nominal emergency braking 

--- Document Chunk 5360 ---
performance of the train, the minimum emergency braking performances that are 

--- Document Chunk 5361 ---
required for reference conditions set by trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 5362 ---
3.13.2.2 Train related inputs 

--- Document Chunk 5363 ---
3.13.2.2.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 5364 ---
3.13.2.2.1.1 The train related inputs to be considered for the speed and distance monitoring are: 

--- Document Chunk 5365 ---
a) Traction model 

--- Document Chunk 5366 ---
b) Braking models (brake build up time and speed dependent deceleration) or brake 

--- Document Chunk 5367 ---
percentage 

--- Document Chunk 5368 ---

--- Document Chunk 5369 ---

--- Document Chunk 5370 ---

--- Document Chunk 5371 ---

--- Document Chunk 5372 ---

--- Document Chunk 5373 ---

--- Document Chunk 5374 ---
i) Train length 

--- Document Chunk 5375 ---
j) Fixed values related to speed and distance monitoring 

--- Document Chunk 5376 ---
k)  Train related speed restriction (i.e. the maximum train speed) 

--- Document Chunk 5377 ---
3.13.2.2.1.2 All train related inputs except the fixed values are acquired as Train Data (see 

--- Document Chunk 5378 ---
3.18.3.2 items b) c) and d)). 

--- Document Chunk 5379 ---
3.13.2.2.1.3 The speed and distance m onitoring shall use braking models acquired as Train 

--- Document Chunk 5380 ---
Data, unless the brake percentage is acquired as Train Data and the conversion model 

--- Document Chunk 5381 ---
is applicable (see 3.13.3.2 for its validity limits).

considered during this time delay.

--- Document Chunk 5410 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1 Speed Dependent Deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 5411 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.1 The deceleration due to braking shall be given as a step function of the speed. 

--- Document Chunk 5412 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.2 It shal l be possible to define up to seven steps for each speed dependent 

--- Document Chunk 5413 ---
deceleration model. 

--- Document Chunk 5414 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.3 Note: An example with 4 steps is given in Figure 30. A_brake(V) is calculated as 

--- Document Chunk 5415 ---
follows: 

--- Document Chunk 5416 ---
 A_brake = AD_0  when 0 ≤ speed ≤ V1 

--- Document Chunk 5417 ---
 A_brake = AD_1  when V1 < speed ≤ V2 

--- Document Chunk 5418 ---
 A_brake = AD_2  when V2 < speed ≤ V3 

--- Document Chunk 5419 ---
 A_brake = AD_3  when V3 < speed 

--- Document Chunk 5420 ---

3.13.2.2.3.1.4 The last step o f A_brake(V) shall by definition be considered as open ended, i.e. it 

--- Document Chunk 5442 ---
has no upper speed limit. 

--- Document Chunk 5443 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.5 The model shall be applicable only after full build up of the braking effort (see a_full 

--- Document Chunk 5444 ---
in Figure 31) 

--- Document Chunk 5445 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.6 The model shall be used for the  emergency brake nominal deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 5446 ---
(A_brake_emergency(V)), for the full service brake deceleration (A_brake_service(V)) 

--- Document Chunk 5447 ---
and for the normal service brake deceleration (A_brake_normal_service(V)). 

--- Document Chunk 5448 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.7 It shall be possible to define individual speed dependent deceleration models of 

--- Document Chunk 5449 ---
A_brake_emergency(V) and A_brake_service(V)  for each combination of use of 

--- Document Chunk 5450 ---
regenerative brake, eddy current brake and magnetic shoe brake. 

--- Document Chunk 5451 ---
3.13.2.2.3.1.8 Note: Individual deceleration models may be equal, thereby avoiding the influence 

--- Document Chunk 5452 ---
of a specifi c brake on A_brake_emergency(V) or A_brake_service(V). However, the 

--- Document Chunk 5453 ---
choice to take into account or not the contribution of a specific brake for 

--- Document Chunk 5454 ---
A_brake_emergency(V) or A_brake_service(V) is only rolling stock dependent, not an 

--- Document Chunk 5455 ---
ETCS implementation issue. 

--- Document Chunk 5456 ---

--- Document Chunk 5473 ---

--- Document Chunk 5484 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.1 The deceleration A_brake is not available immediately after the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 5485 ---
commands the brake. There is a time lag between brake command and the st art of the 

--- Document Chunk 5486 ---
brake force build-up. There is also time needed to build up the full brake force. 

--- Document Chunk 5487 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.2 The model for the brake build up time shall be given as a step function as explained 

--- Document Chunk 5488 ---
in Figure 31. 

--- Document Chunk 5489 ---
 A_brake 

--- Document Chunk 5490 ---
95% 

--- Document Chunk 5491 ---
a_full 

--- Document Chunk 5492 ---
t3 t2 t1 t0 time 

--- Document Chunk 5493 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 5494 ---
Figure 31: Brake Build Up Time Model 

--- Document Chunk 5495 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.3 In Figure 31, the following time intervals are defined: 

--- Document Chunk 5496 ---
a) T_brake_react (t0…t1) is the interval between the command of the brake by the on -

--- Document Chunk 5497 ---
board and the moment the brake force starts to build up. 

--- Document Chunk 5498 ---
b) T_brake_increase (t1...t2) is the interval in which the brake force increases from the 

--- Document Chunk 5499 ---
zero to the moment when 95% of full brake power is reached. 

--- Document Chunk 5500 ---
c) T_brake_build_up (t0...t3) is the equivalent brake build up time. 

--- Document Chunk 5501 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.4 The equivalent brake build up time (T_brake_build_up) is defined as 

--- Document Chunk 5502 ---
T_brake_build_up = T_brake_react + 0.5*T_brake_increase. 

--- Document Chunk 5503 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.5 This model for T_brake_build_up shall be used for the emergency brake 

--- Document Chunk 5504 ---
(T_brake_emergency) and for the full service brake (T_brake_service). 

--- Document Chunk 5505 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.6 Note: The equivale nt brake build up time is a safe approximation. In the beginning 

--- Document Chunk 5506 ---
of the build -up time the model assumes a smaller deceleration, in the later part this is 

--- Document Chunk 5507 ---
compensated by a higher deceleration. 

--- Document Chunk 5508 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.7 Note: T_brake_react and T_brake_increase are indicated in Figure 31 for 

--- Document Chunk 5509 ---
completeness reasons; only T_brake_build_up is to be considered as an input for the 

--- Document Chunk 5510 ---
speed and distance monitoring function. 

--- Document Chunk 5511 ---
3.13.2.2.3.2.8 It shall be possible to define individual values of T_brake_emergency and 

--- Document Chunk 5512 ---
T_brake_service for each  combination of use of regenerative brake, eddy current 

--- Document Chunk 5513 ---
brake, magnetic shoe brake and Ep brake.

3.13.3 Conversion Models 

--- Document Chunk 5897 ---
3.13.3.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 5898 ---
3.13.3.1.1 For trains with variable composition (loco hauled trains), the brake characteristics can 

--- Document Chunk 5899 ---
vary together with the composition of the train. In this case, it is not convenient to  pre-

--- Document Chunk 5900 ---
program the brake parameters necessary to calculate the braking curves. The only 

--- Document Chunk 5901 ---
practical way to obtain the correct values for the current train composition is to include 

--- Document Chunk 5902 ---
them into the data entry process by the driver. However, it cannot be expected from 

--- Document Chunk 5903 ---
the driver to know deceleration values and brake build up times. Conversion models 

--- Document Chunk 5904 ---
are therefore defined to convert the parameters entered by the driver (brake 

--- Document Chunk 5905 ---
percentage and brake position) into the parameters of the corresponding brake model. 

--- Document Chunk 5906 ---
3.13.3.1.2 Note: The process for defining the input parameters for the conversion model (brake 

--- Document Chunk 5907 ---
percentage and brake position) is outside the scope of the ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 5908 ---
specifications. 

--- Document Chunk 5909 ---
3.13.3.2 Applicability of the conversion models 

--- Document Chunk 5910 ---
3.13.3.2.1 The conversion models shall be used by the on -board e quipment if the brake 

--- Document Chunk 5911 ---
percentage is acquired as part of Train Data, and if the maximum train speed, the 

--- Document Chunk 5912 ---
brake percentage and the train length are all within the following validity limits of the 

--- Document Chunk 5913 ---
conversion models: 

--- Document Chunk 5914 ---
a) 0 ≤ V ≤ 200, where V is the maximum train speed in km/h 

--- Document Chunk 5915 ---
b) 30 ≤ λ ≤ 250, where λ is the brake percentage in % 

--- Document Chunk 5916 ---
c) 0 ≤ L ≤ Lmax, where L is the train length in m  and where Lmax = 900 m if the brake 

--- Document Chunk 5917 ---
position is “Passenger train in P” or Lmax = 1500  m if the brake p osition is “Freight 

--- Document Chunk 5918 ---
train in P” or “Freight train in G” 

--- Document Chunk 5919 ---
3.13.3.2.1.1 Note: The overspeed above the maximum train speed which may occur due to the 

--- Document Chunk 5920 ---
ceiling speed margins is taken into account in the definition of the conversion model. 

--- Document Chunk 5921 ---
3.13.3.2.2 For trains not fitting into at least one of those validity limits, it is still possible to acquire 

--- Document Chunk 5922 ---
the brake percentage as Train Data, but the conversion models are not applicable, 

--- Document Chunk 5923 ---
which means that braking models (i.e. pre -programmed deceleration profiles and 

--- Document Chunk 5924 ---
brake build up times) shall be used by the speed and distance monitoring function. 

--- Document Chunk 5925 ---

--- Document Chunk 6050 ---
3.13.4.2.1 Assuming that a fictive train front end would be at any locati on between the current 

--- Document Chunk 6051 ---
(actual) train front end location and the SvL, the acceleration due to the gradient shall 

--- Document Chunk 6052 ---
be determined using the lowest (taking the sign into account) gradient value given by 

--- Document Chunk 6053 ---
the gradient profile between the location of the fictive train front end and the location of 

--- Document Chunk 6054 ---
the fictive train rear end (see Figure 35). 

--- Document Chunk 6055 ---
3.13.4.3 Rotating mass 

--- Document Chunk 6056 ---
3.13.4.3.1 The influence of gradients shall be compensated for the rotating mass of the train (see 

--- Document Chunk 6057 ---
Figure 35). 

--- Document Chunk 6058 ---
3.13.4.3.1.1 Note: Since the rotating mass works like a flywheel (rotating inertia), the effect of 

--- Document Chunk 6059 ---
the gradient is reduced. Assume for instance a (theoretical) train without any rotating 

--- Document Chunk 6060 ---
mass, not braking, on a downhill gradient from height 1 to height 2. All the energy 

--- Document Chunk 6061 ---
added to the train when it goes from H1 to H2 is converted into linear forward motion. 

--- Document Chunk 6062 ---
This can be observed as an acceleration due to the gradient. Now assume the same 

--- Document Chunk 6063 ---
train with part of the weight rotating. If this train travels the same distance from H1 to 

--- Document Chunk 6064 ---
H2, the same amount of energy is added to the train. But now a part of that energy is 

--- Document Chunk 6065 ---
converted into rotational motion and only the remaining part is converted into linear 

--- Document Chunk 6066 ---
forward motion. The latter can be observed as an acceleration which is less than for 

--- Document Chunk 6067 ---
the train without rotating mass. 

--- Document Chunk 6068 ---
3.13.4.3.1.2 Note: For the influence of the rotating mass on the deceleration due to the brake, it 

--- Document Chunk 6069 ---
is already taken into account in the values for the brake parameters. 

--- Document Chunk 6070 ---
3.13.4.3.2 The following formulas shall be used: 

--- Document Chunk 6071 ---
a) If M_rotating_nom is unknown: 

--- Document Chunk 6072 ---
 Uphill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_max) 

--- Document Chunk 6073 ---
 Downhill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_min) 

--- Document Chunk 6074 ---
b) If M_rotating_nom is known: 

--- Document Chunk 6075 ---
 Uphill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_nom) 

--- Document Chunk 6076 ---
 Downhill: A_gradient = g * grad / (1000+10*M_rotating_nom) 

--- Document Chunk 6077 ---
Legend: 

--- Document Chunk 6078 ---
A_gradient = acceleration/deceleration due to gradient 

--- Document Chunk 6079 ---
g = 9.81 m/s2 - acceleration of gravity in m/s2 

--- Document Chunk 6080 ---
grad = gradient values in ‰ (positive = uphill) 

--- Document Chunk 6081 ---
M_rotating_nom = nominal rotating mass (part of train data) as a percentage of the 

--- Document Chunk 6082 ---
total train weight 

--- Document Chunk 6083 ---
M_rotating_max = maximum possible rotating mass (see A3.1) as a percentage of the 

--- Document Chunk 6084 ---
total train weight 

--- Document Chunk 6085 ---
M_rotating_min = minimum possible rotating mass (see A3.1) as a percentage of the 

--- Document Chunk 6086 ---
total train weight 

--- Document Chunk 6087 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

3.13.5 Determination of locations without special brake contribution and with 

--- Document Chunk 6099 ---
reduced adhesion conditions 

--- Document Chunk 6100 ---
3.13.5.1 As long as  it uses a  track condition profile given by trackside, the on -board shall 

--- Document Chunk 6101 ---
consider locations with out special  brake contribution over a distance going from the 

--- Document Chunk 6102 ---
start location of the profile to the  foot of the deceleration curve (EBD, SBD or GUI, see 

--- Document Chunk 6103 ---
sections 3.13.8.3, 3.13.8.4 and 3.13.8.5). 

--- Document Chunk 6104 ---
3.13.5.2 If the status of a special brake is “not active”, all locations shall be  considered without 

--- Document Chunk 6105 ---
the contribution of this special brake. 

--- Document Chunk 6106 ---
3.13.5.2.1 Note: in such case, a track condition profile implying the inhibition of this special brake 

--- Document Chunk 6107 ---
will have no effect. 

--- Document Chunk 6108 ---
3.13.5.3 From the adhesion profile given by trackside, the on-board shall consider locations with 

--- Document Chunk 6109 ---
reduced adhesion conditions over a distance going from the start location of the profile 

--- Document Chunk 6110 ---
to the location derived by adding the train length to the end location of the profile. 

--- Document Chunk 6111 ---
3.13.5.4 When slippery rail is selected by the driver, all locations shall be consi dered with 

--- Document Chunk 6112 ---
reduced adhesion conditions. 

--- Document Chunk 6113 ---
3.13.5.5 The speed and distance monitoring shall use, as resulting reduced adhesion 

--- Document Chunk 6114 ---
conditions, the most restrictive value of the adhesion conditions selected by the driver 

--- Document Chunk 6115 ---
and the adhesion conditions calculated from the trackside profile.

is used 

--- Document Chunk 6160 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6161 ---
3.13.6.2.1.3 A_safe(V,d) shall be equal to: 

--- Document Chunk 6162 ---
For locations with normal adhesion conditions: 

--- Document Chunk 6163 ---
A_safe(V,d) = A_brake_safe(V,d) + A_gradient(d) 

--- Document Chunk 6164 ---
For locations with reduced adhesion conditions: 

--- Document Chunk 6165 ---
A_safe(V,d) = MIN(A_brake_safe(V,d) , A_MAXREDADH) + A_gradient(d) 

--- Document Chunk 6166 ---
3.13.6.2.1.4 A_brake_safe(V,d) shall be the safe emergency brake deceleration. 

--- Document Chunk 6167 ---

--- Document Chunk 6168 ---

--- Document Chunk 6169 ---
acquired as part of Train Data: 

--- Document Chunk 6170 ---

--- Document Chunk 6171 ---
*(1- Kwet_rst(V))) * A_brake_emergency(V,d) 

--- Document Chunk 6172 ---
If the conversion model is used: 

--- Document Chunk 6173 ---
A_brake_safe(V) = Kv_int(V) * Kr_int(L_TRAIN) * A_brake_emergency(V) 

--- Document Chunk 6174 ---

3.13.8 Determination of targets and brake deceleration curves 

--- Document Chunk 6443 ---
3.13.8.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 6444 ---
3.13.8.1.1 A target is defined by a target location and a target speed, to which the train must 

--- Document Chunk 6445 ---
decelerate before reaching the target location. 

--- Document Chunk 6446 ---
3.13.8.1.2 For that purpose, the on -board equipment shall use brake deceleration curves related 

--- Document Chunk 6447 ---
to the supervised targets, from the deceleration values as specified in sections 

--- Document Chunk 6448 ---
3.13.6.2.1, 3.13.6.3.1and 3.13.6.4. 

--- Document Chunk 6449 ---
3.13.8.1.3 These deceleration values being speed and distance dependent, a brake deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 6450 ---
curve shall be calculated piecewise, i.e. it shall be composed of interconnected arcs of 

--- Document Chunk 6451 ---
parabola, each one being based on one of the speed/distance dependent deceleration 

--- Document Chunk 6452 ---
values (see Figure 38). 

--- Document Chunk 6453 ---
3.13.8.2 Determination of the supervised targets 

--- Document Chunk 6454 ---
3.13.8.2.1 The on -board shall continuously supervise a list of targets, which may include the 

--- Document Chunk 6455 ---
following types of target: 

--- Document Chunk 6456 ---
a) the locations corresponding to a speed decrease of the MRSP (if any), which are in 

--- Document Chunk 6457 ---
advance of the max safe front end of the train 

--- Document Chunk 6458 ---
b) the Limit of Authority (LOA), if the target speed at the EOA/LOA is not equal to zero 

--- Document Chunk 6459 ---
c) the End of Authority (EOA) and the Supervised Location (SvL), if the target speed at 

--- Document Chunk 6460 ---
the EOA is equal to zero 

--- Document Chunk 6461 ---
d) the location deduced from the maximum permitted distance to run in Staff 

--- Document Chunk 6462 ---
Responsible, with a target speed zero 

--- Document Chunk 6463 ---
3.13.8.2.1.1 Note: depending on the information received from trackside a nd the position of the 

--- Document Chunk 6464 ---
train, the list of supervised targets may be empty. 

--- Document Chunk 6465 ---
3.13.8.2.2 The list of supervised targets shall be re -evaluated when any of the elements it is built 

--- Document Chunk 6466 ---
of is changed (e.g. new MA and/or track description accepted on -board, EOA and/or 

--- Document Chunk 6467 ---
SvL tempo rarily supervised at the start location of a mode profile, update of stored 

--- Document Chunk 6468 ---
information in specific situations (see sections A.3.4 and 4.10)). 

--- Document Chunk 6469 ---
3.13.8.2.3 A target corresponding to a speed decrease of the MRSP shall be removed from the 

--- Document Chunk 6470 ---
list of supervised targets when the max safe front end of the train has passed the 

--- Document Chunk 6471 ---
target location. 

--- Document Chunk 6472 ---

3.13.8.5 Guidance curves (GUI) 

--- Document Chunk 6551 ---
3.13.8.5.1 The purpose of the guidance curve (GUI) is to provide a comfortable way of braking for 

--- Document Chunk 6552 ---
the driver, to avoid excessive wear of the brakes and to save traction energy. 

--- Document Chunk 6553 ---
3.13.8.5.2 If the National Value does not inhibit them, the on -board shall calculate a guidance 

--- Document Chunk 6554 ---
curve (GUI) for each supervised target, based on the normal service brake 

--- Document Chunk 6555 ---
deceleration A_normal_service(V,d). The foot of a GUI curve (i.e. the location where 

--- Document Chunk 6556 ---
the GUI speed is equal to the target speed) shall be: 

--- Document Chunk 6557 ---
a) the target location, in case of EOA/SvL 

--- Document Chunk 6558 ---
b) the location defined in 3.13.9.3.5.9, for others targets 

--- Document Chunk 6559 ---

3.13.9.3.2 EBI supervision limit 

--- Document Chunk 6709 ---
3.13.9.3.2.1 If not inhibited by National Value, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 6710 ---
compensate the inaccuracy of the speed measurement by taking into account  the 

--- Document Chunk 6711 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 6712 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6713 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6714 ---
SUBSET-026-3 

--- Document Chunk 6715 ---
3.4.0 

--- Document Chunk 6716 ---
12/05/14 

--- Document Chunk 6717 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 6718 ---
Chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 6719 ---
Principles 

--- Document Chunk 6720 ---
Page 118/200 

--- Document Chunk 6721 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 6722 ---
speed under reading amount (V_ura)  at the moment when the calculation is made : 

--- Document Chunk 6723 ---
V_delta0 = V_ura (see Figure 45). 

--- Document Chunk 6724 ---
3.13.9.3.2.2 The time elapsed between the Emergency brake intervention and the full application 

--- Document Chunk 6725 ---
of the braking effort is reached (EBD) shall be split into two parts: 

--- Document Chunk 6726 ---
a) Time during which the traction effort is still present: T_traction 

--- Document Chunk 6727 ---
b) Remaining time during which the traction effort is not present: T_berem 

--- Document Chunk 6728 ---
3.13.9.3.2.3 The traction time (T_Traction) shall be defined as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 6729 ---
a) when the traction cut-off is implemented: 

--- Document Chunk 6730 ---
T_traction = MAX((T_traction_cut_off - (T_warning + T_bs2)) ; 0). 

--- Document Chunk 6731 ---
b) when the traction cut-off is not implemented: T_traction = T_traction_cut_off 

--- Document Chunk 6732 ---
3.13.9.3.2.4 Note: When the traction cut -off is implemented, the traction cut -off command is 

--- Document Chunk 6733 ---
triggered when passing the warning limit. The term (T_warning + T_bs2) in the 

--- Document Chunk 6734 ---
equation above takes this into accou nt, assuming that the warning limit is derived from 

--- Document Chunk 6735 ---
the EBD. 

--- Document Chunk 6736 ---
3.13.9.3.2.5 T_bs2 and T_warning are defined in sections 3.13.9.3.3 and 3.13.9.3.4. 

--- Document Chunk 6737 ---
3.13.9.3.2.6 The remaining time with no traction (T_berem) shall be equal to MA X(T_be - 

--- Document Chunk 6738 ---
T_traction ; 0). 

--- Document Chunk 6739 ---
3.13.9.3.2.7 Note: T_Traction exceeding T_be is rather a theoretical case, but is nevertheless 

--- Document Chunk 6740 ---
included to make the specifications complete. 

--- Document Chunk 6741 ---
3.13.9.3.2.8 During T_traction, the estimated acceleration (A_est1) shall be the one measured at 

--- Document Chunk 6742 ---
the moment when the calculation is made, but limited to positive or null values. 

--- Document Chunk 6743 ---
3.13.9.3.2.9 If T_be > T_traction, the estimated acceleration during T_berem (A_est2) shall be 

--- Document Chunk 6744 ---
the one measured at the moment when the calculation is made, but limited to values 

--- Document Chunk 6745 ---
between 0 and +0.4m/s2. 

--- Document Chunk 6746 ---
3.13.9.3.2.10 The compensated speed and the distance travelled during the time elapsed

between the Emergency brake intervention and the full application of the braking effort 

--- Document Chunk 6748 ---
is reached shall be derived as follows (see Figure 45):

3.13.9.3.3.3 If the service brake command is available for use and the service brake feedback is 

--- Document Chunk 6810 ---
not available for use, T_bs1 and T_bs2 shall be equal to T_bs. 

--- Document Chunk 6811 ---

--- Document Chunk 6812 ---

--- Document Chunk 6813 ---

--- Document Chunk 6814 ---

--- Document Chunk 6815 ---
until the target speed monitoring is left; they are then reset again to T_bs (see detailed 

--- Document Chunk 6816 ---
algorithm in Appendix A3.10). 

--- Document Chunk 6817 ---

--- Document Chunk 6818 ---

--- Document Chunk 6819 ---
to zero. 

--- Document Chunk 6820 ---
3.13.9.3.3.6 Note: The values T_bs1 and T_bs2 = 0s are defined to achieve the maximum 

--- Document Chunk 6821 ---
performance when service brake command is not used.

3.13.9.3.3.8.1 Note: the re -use of the same distance travelled and speed increase between the 

--- Document Chunk 6914 ---
SBI2 supervision limit and the EBD, as for the estimated speed (see Figure 48), leads 

--- Document Chunk 6915 ---
to an overestimation/underestimation of the SBI2 speed to be displayed to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 6916 ---
This simplification, which avoids the need of an iterated calculation, is however 

--- Document Chunk 6917 ---
acceptable and necessary since the error made tends to zero when th e train reaches 

--- Document Chunk 6918 ---
the SBI2 supervision limit.

--- Document Chunk 7235 ---
3.13.9.4 Release speed supervision limits 

--- Document Chunk 7236 ---
3.13.9.4.1 The release speed is a special ceiling speed limit, applicable in the vicinity of the EOA. 

--- Document Chunk 7237 ---
The EBI supervision limit shall b e equal to the release speed. There is no SBI, W, P, I 

--- Document Chunk 7238 ---
supervision limit associated to the release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 7239 ---
3.13.9.4.2 Note: The release speed may be necessary for two reasons. One is that a train has to 

--- Document Chunk 7240 ---
be able to approach the EOA where the permitted speed reaches zer o and might be 

--- Document Chunk 7241 ---
too restrictive to permit acceptable driving due to inaccuracy of the measured distance. 

--- Document Chunk 7242 ---
The other reason is that in a level 1 application the train has to be able to overpass the 

--- Document Chunk 7243 ---
balise when the signal clears. For these two reasons a (low) release speed may be 

--- Document Chunk 7244 ---
given from trackside or may be calculated on board, based on the distance from the 

--- Document Chunk 7245 ---
EOA to the Supervised Location. 

--- Document Chunk 7246 ---
3.13.9.4.3 With each MA, it shall be possible for the trackside to: 

--- Document Chunk 7247 ---
a) Give the value of the release speed directly to the on-board, OR 

--- Document Chunk 7248 ---
b) Instruct the on-board to calculate the release speed, OR 

--- Document Chunk 7249 ---
c) Instruct the on-board to use the national value. 

--- Document Chunk 7250 ---
3.13.9.4.4 In case the MA does not identify the variant to be used or in case of LOA, no release 

--- Document Chunk 7251 ---
speed shall be supervised. 

--- Document Chunk 7252 ---
3.13.9.4.5 Note: When the release speed is giv en as a fixed value from trackside, the 

--- Document Chunk 7253 ---
ERTMS/ETCS system cannot be responsible for stopping the train in rear of the 

--- Document Chunk 7254 ---
Supervised Location. In this case, it is the full responsibility of the infrastructure 

--- Document Chunk 7255 ---
manager to set the appropriate release speed with r egard to the risk of passing the 

--- Document Chunk 7256 ---
Supervised Location. 

--- Document Chunk 7257 ---
3.13.9.4.6 The start location of the release speed monitoring (i.e. where the EBI supervision limit 

--- Document Chunk 7258 ---
related to EBD is replaced with an EBI supervision limit equal to the release speed 

--- Document Chunk 7259 ---
value) shall be the location of the most restrictive SBI supervision limit among the SBI1 

--- Document Chunk 7260 ---
related to EOA, the SBI2 related to SvL  and, when the Release Speed is calculated 

--- Document Chunk 7261 ---
on-board, the SBI2 supervision limit(s) related to other target(s), if any, between the 

--- Document Chunk 7262 ---
Trip location related to the EOA and the SvL,  calculated for the Release Speed value, 

--- Document Chunk 7263 ---
taking into account the following assumptions: 

--- Document Chunk 7264 ---
a) the estimated acceleration shall be set to “zero” 

--- Document Chunk 7265 ---
b) if not inhibited by National Value, the compensation of the inaccuracy of the speed 

--- Document Chunk 7266 ---
measurement shall be set to a value calculated from the release speed, as defined 

--- Document Chunk 7267 ---
in SUBSET-041 § 5.3.1.2: V_delta0rs = f41(V_release) 

--- Document Chunk 7268 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 7490 ---
3.13.9.5.1 The purpose of the pre -indication is to inform the driver that he is approaching an area 

--- Document Chunk 7491 ---

--- Document Chunk 7492 ---
indication is used to switch from ceiling speed monitoring to target speed monitoring. 

--- Document Chunk 7493 ---

--- Document Chunk 7494 ---
follows. 

--- Document Chunk 7495 ---

--- Document Chunk 7501 ---
measurement shall be set to a value, calculated from the speed of the MRSP 

--- Document Chunk 7502 ---
element, as defined in SUBSET-041 § 5.3.1.2: V_delta0ind = f41(V_MRSP-n) 

--- Document Chunk 7503 ---

--- Document Chunk 7505 ---

3.13.9.5.11 Note 1: For ergonomic reasons, the location of a pre -indication is independent of the 

--- Document Chunk 7605 ---
estimated speed. If the pre -indication would be derived from an EBD or SBD curve 

--- Document Chunk 7606 ---
according to the estimated speed, then when the train is running at low speed the 

--- Document Chunk 7607 ---
driver would see the permitted speed already decrease while the DMI is still in ceiling 

--- Document Chunk 7608 ---
speed display. That is not consistent for the  driver and therefore the pre -indication is 

--- Document Chunk 7609 ---
independent of the estimated speed. 

--- Document Chunk 7610 ---
3.13.9.5.12 Note 2: For trackside engineering reasons, the assumptions for the calculation of the 

--- Document Chunk 7611 ---
EBI supervision limit are necessary to obtain a fully predictable pre -indication location, 

--- Document Chunk 7612 ---
i.e. independent from the measured acceleration and speed confidence interval.

--- Document Chunk 7619 ---

3.13.10.1.3 Ceiling speed monitoring is the speed supervision in the area where the train can run 

--- Document Chunk 7652 ---
with the speed as defined by the MRSP without the need to brake to a target. 

--- Document Chunk 7653 ---
3.13.10.1.4 Target speed monitoring is the speed and distance supervision in the area where the 

--- Document Chunk 7654 ---
specific information related to a target is displayed to the driver and within which the 

--- Document Chunk 7655 ---
train brakes to a target. 

--- Document Chunk 7656 ---
3.13.10.1.5 Release speed monitoring is  the speed and distance supervision in the area close to 

--- Document Chunk 7657 ---
the EOA where the train is allowed to run with release speed to approach the EOA. 

--- Document Chunk 7658 ---
3.13.10.2 General requirements

--- Document Chunk 7660 ---
speed monitoring. This shall be the estimated speed.

--- Document Chunk 7662 ---
is triggered, the on -board shall apply it until its corresponding revocation condition is 

--- Document Chunk 7663 ---
met. 

--- Document Chunk 7664 ---

be triggered instead. 

--- Document Chunk 7679 ---
3.13.10.2.4 The emergency brak e command, which is triggered instead of the service brake 

--- Document Chunk 7680 ---
command when an SBI supervision limit is exceeded, shall be revoked according to 

--- Document Chunk 7681 ---
the requirements specified for the revocation of service brake command, unless the 

--- Document Chunk 7682 ---
emergency brake command has been also triggered due to an EBI supervision limit. In 

--- Document Chunk 7683 ---
such case, the condition for revoking the emergency brake command due to EBI 

--- Document Chunk 7684 ---
supervision limit shall prevail. 

--- Document Chunk 7685 ---
3.13.10.2.5 The on -board shall revoke the Intervention status only when no brake command is 

--- Document Chunk 7686 ---
applied by the speed and distance monitoring function. 

--- Document Chunk 7687 ---
3.13.10.2.6 In level 2/3: Train trip shall be initiated if the on -board equipment detects that the 

--- Document Chunk 7688 ---
minimum safe front end has passed the EOA/LOA location. 

--- Document Chunk 7689 ---
3.13.10.2.7 In Level 1: Train Trip shall be initiated if the on -board equipment detec ts that the 

--- Document Chunk 7690 ---
minimum safe antenna position (calculated by subtracting distance between active 

--- Document Chunk 7691 ---
Eurobalise antenna and the front end of the train from the min safe front end position) 

--- Document Chunk 7692 ---
has passed the EOA/LOA location. 

--- Document Chunk 7693 ---
3.13.10.2.8 In the following sections , the term V_MRSP  (together with the derived ceiling 

--- Document Chunk 7694 ---
supervision limits) refers to the lowest MRSP element encountered between the min 

--- Document Chunk 7695 ---
safe front end and the max safe front end of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 7696 ---

Figure 56: Triggering of Train Interface commands and supervision statuses in target speed

--- Document Chunk 8482 ---
3.13.10.4.11 The braking to target Indication supervision limit is not used for estimated speeds 

--- Document Chunk 8483 ---
higher than V_MRSP. However the location of the Indication supervision limit, valid for 

--- Document Chunk 8484 ---
V_MRSP, shall be used for estimated speeds  higher than V_MRSP in order to 

--- Document Chunk 8485 ---
discriminate whether information related to the Indication status has to be displayed to 

--- Document Chunk 8486 ---
the driver. In other terms, for estimated speeds above V_MRSP, this location of the 

--- Document Chunk 8487 ---
Indication supervision limit defines a pre -indication display area starting from the pre -

--- Document Chunk 8488 ---
indication location and ending at this location. 

--- Document Chunk 8489 ---
3.13.10.4.12 Note: Figure 56 shows the parts of the ceiling speed and braking to target 

--- Document Chunk 8490 ---
supervision limits, which are used in target speed monitoring to tri gger the brake 

--- Document Chunk 8491 ---
commands and the transitions between supervision statuses. It does not show what is 

--- Document Chunk 8492 ---
displayed to the driver: in particular, the braking to target Permitted supervision limit is 

--- Document Chunk 8493 ---
displayed (even if not supervised) for values lower than the release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 8494 ---

3.13.10.4.13 In case of target EOA/SvL without any supervised release speed, the Table 9 

--- Document Chunk 8646 ---
and Table 11 shall be applied, by substituting V_release with the value 0. 

--- Document Chunk 8647 ---
3.13.10.4.13.1 In case the target is the location at the end of the maximum permitted distance to 

--- Document Chunk 8648 ---

3.14.1.2 In case only the application of  (the non-vital) service brake has been commanded and 

--- Document Chunk 8917 ---

--- Document Chunk 8918 ---

--- Document Chunk 8919 ---

--- Document Chunk 8920 ---

--- Document Chunk 8924 ---
protection or standstill supervision the brake command shall be released at standstill 

--- Document Chunk 8925 ---
and after driver acknowledgement.  

--- Document Chunk 8926 ---

--- Document Chunk 8927 ---
inconsistency or RAMS related supervision e rror, the brake command shall be 

--- Document Chunk 8928 ---

--- Document Chunk 8929 ---
3.14.1.7 If the brake command was triggered due to supervision of the safe radio connection 

--- Document Chunk 8930 ---
(T_NVCONTACT) the brake command shall be released at standstill or if a new 

--- Document Chunk 8931 ---
consistent message has been received from the RBC.  

--- Document Chunk 8932 ---
3.14.1.7.1 If the brake command was triggered due to an overpassed reversing distance related 

--- Document Chunk 8933 ---
to a reversing area or due to any further movement in the direction opposite to the train 

--- Document Chunk 8934 ---
orientation while the reversing distance is still overpassed , the brake  command shall 

--- Document Chunk 8935 ---
be released if the reversing distance becomes extended so that the reversing distance 

--- Document Chunk 8936 ---
is no longer overpassed, or at standstill after driver acknowledgement. 

--- Document Chunk 8937 ---
3.14.1.7.2 If the brake command was triggered due to change of Train Data while running (see 

--- Document Chunk 8938 ---
section 5.17 procedure "Changing Train Data from sources different from the driver”), 

--- Document Chunk 8939 ---
the brake command shall be released at standstill and after driver acknowledgement. 

--- Document Chunk 8940 ---
3.14.1.7.3 If the brake command was triggered due to the detection of a train movement while 

--- Document Chunk 8941 ---
modifying/revalidating train data or while entering SR speed/distance limits, the brake 

--- Document Chunk 8942 ---
command shall be released at standstill and after driver acknowledgement.. 

--- Document Chunk 8943 ---
3.14.1.7.4 If the brake command was triggered due to an overpassed distance allowed for moving 

--- Document Chunk 8944 ---
backwards in Post Trip mode or due to any further movement in the direction opposite 

--- Document Chunk 8945 ---
to the train orientation while the distance allowed for moving backwards in Post Trip 

--- Document Chunk 8946 ---
mode is still overpassed , the brake command shall be released at standstill and after 

--- Document Chunk 8947 ---
driver acknowledgement. 

--- Document Chunk 8948 ---
3.14.1.7.5 If the brake command was triggered due to the driver not having acknowledged a text 

--- Document Chunk 8949 ---
message, the brake command shall be released after the driver has acknowledged the 

--- Document Chunk 8950 ---
text message. 

--- Document Chunk 8951 ---
