3.14.2 Roll Away Protection 

--- Document Chunk 8965 ---
3.14.2.1 Note: This protection is only applicable if the required information can be obtained from 

--- Document Chunk 8966 ---
the direction controller. 

--- Document Chunk 8967 ---
3.14.2.2 The Roll Away Protection (RAP) shall prevent the train  from moving in a direction, 

--- Document Chunk 8968 ---
which conflicts with the current position of the direction controller in the active desk. 

--- Document Chunk 8969 ---
3.14.2.3 If the controller is in neutral position, the RAP shall prevent forward and reverse 

--- Document Chunk 8970 ---
movements of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 8971 ---
3.14.2.4 When the system recognises a movement exceeding the national value for the allowed 

--- Document Chunk 8972 ---
roll away distance the brakes shall be triggered. 

--- Document Chunk 8973 ---
3.14.2.5 Refer to section 3.14.1. 

--- Document Chunk 8974 ---
3.14.2.6 An indication shall be given to the driver showing when the RAP is commanding the 

--- Document Chunk 8975 ---
brakes. 

--- Document Chunk 8976 ---
3.14.2.7 After revocation of the brake command the RAP will be re -initialised using the current 

--- Document Chunk 8977 ---
position of the train as the new reference location. 

--- Document Chunk 8978 ---
3.14.3 Reverse Movement Protection 

--- Document Chunk 8979 ---
3.14.3.1 The Reverse Movement Protection (RMP) shall prevent the train from moving in the 

--- Document Chunk 8980 ---
opposite direction to the permitted one. The permitted movement direction of a train 

--- Document Chunk 8981 ---
shall be the one of the currently valid MA, if available on -board. See chapter 4 

--- Document Chunk 8982 ---
concerning permitted direction for special cases. 

--- Document Chunk 8983 ---
3.14.3.2 When a reverse movement is detected, the brake command shall be triggered after a 

--- Document Chunk 8984 ---
distance specified by the national value. 

--- Document Chunk 8985 ---
3.14.3.3 Refer to section 3.14.1. 

--- Document Chunk 8986 ---
3.14.3.4 An indication shall be given to the driver showing when the RMP is commanding the 

--- Document Chunk 8987 ---
brakes. 

--- Document Chunk 8988 ---
3.14.3.5 After revocation of the brake command the R MP will be reinitialised using the current 

--- Document Chunk 8989 ---
position of the train as the new reference location. 

--- Document Chunk 8990 ---
3.14.3.6 Information received from balises during reverse movement shall be ignored. 

--- Document Chunk 8991 ---
3.14.4 Standstill supervision 

--- Document Chunk 8992 ---
3.14.4.1 This function shall prevent the train from moving. 

--- Document Chunk 8993 ---
3.14.4.2 When a movement is detected, the brake command shall be triggered after a distance 

--- Document Chunk 8994 ---
specified by the national value. 

--- Document Chunk 8995 ---
3.14.4.3 Refer to section 3.14.1. 

--- Document Chunk 8996 ---

3.15 Special functions 

--- Document Chunk 9011 ---
3.15.1 RBC/RBC Handover 

--- Document Chunk 9012 ---
3.15.1.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 9013 ---
3.15.1.1.1 Trains with one or more radio(s) shall be able to pass from one RBC area to another 

--- Document Chunk 9014 ---
automatically (without driver action). 

--- Document Chunk 9015 ---
3.15.1.1.2 Since an RBC is unable to know whether the on -board is able to manage one or two 

--- Document Chunk 9016 ---
communication session(s) at once, the following principles are applicable for both 

--- Document Chunk 9017 ---
cases. Thereby, the RBCs will have the same behaviour in both cases. 

--- Document Chunk 9018 ---
3.15.1.1.3 An RBC/RBC handover performed by a train with one communication session available 

--- Document Chunk 9019 ---
may result in performance penalties since it will not be able to “prepare” (session 

--- Document Chunk 9020 ---
establishment, version determination, …) the expected supervision by the Ac cepting 

--- Document Chunk 9021 ---
RBC until the on-board disconnects from the Handing Over RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9022 ---
3.15.1.1.4 In level 3, trains following the one with one communication session available will 

--- Document Chunk 9023 ---
always suffer performance penalties since no more position reports will be issued from 

--- Document Chunk 9024 ---
the disconnection from the Handing Over RBC until the connection to the Accepting 

--- Document Chunk 9025 ---
RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9026 ---
3.15.1.2 Handing Over RBC 

--- Document Chunk 9027 ---
3.15.1.2.1 When the Handing Over RBC detects that a route is set for a train to enter another 

--- Document Chunk 9028 ---
RBC area, it shall send: 

--- Document Chunk 9029 ---
a) Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 9030 ---
b) To the Accepting RBC the following information: 

--- Document Chunk 9031 ---
 The ETCS identity of the on-board equipment; 

--- Document Chunk 9032 ---
 The border location that will be passed by the train when entering the Accepting 

--- Document Chunk 9033 ---
RBC area; 

--- Document Chunk 9034 ---
 Current mode of the on-board equipment; 

--- Document Chunk 9035 ---
 Optionally, Train Data; 

--- Document Chunk 9036 ---
 Optionally, for a non-leading engine, the ETCS identity of the leading engine. 

--- Document Chunk 9037 ---
3.15.1.2.2 The Handing Over RBC shall not send information to an on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 9038 ---
concerning the route in advance of the border without receiving the corresponding 

--- Document Chunk 9039 ---
information from the Accepting RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9040 ---

3.15.1.3 On-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 9104 ---
3.15.1.3.1 When receiving an order to switch to another RBC at a given location, the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 9105 ---
equipment shall: 

--- Document Chunk 9106 ---
a) Establish the communication session with the Accepting RBC; 

--- Document Chunk 9107 ---
b) Send a position report to the Handing Over RBC when the m aximum safe front end 

--- Document Chunk 9108 ---
of the train passes the given location; 

--- Document Chunk 9109 ---
c) Send a position report to the Handing Over RBC when the minimum safe rear end 

--- Document Chunk 9110 ---
of the train passes the given location; 

--- Document Chunk 9111 ---
3.15.1.3.2 It is up to the on -board equipment to manage the establishment of one commun ication 

--- Document Chunk 9112 ---
session and the release of the other one: 

--- Document Chunk 9113 ---
a) If it is able to handle two communication sessions at the same time, the radio 

--- Document Chunk 9114 ---
session with the Accepting RBC shall be established as soon as it receives the RBC 

--- Document Chunk 9115 ---
transition order. 

--- Document Chunk 9116 ---
b) If it is able to handle on e communication session only at a given time, it shall wait 

--- Document Chunk 9117 ---
until the session with the Handing over RBC is terminated due to crossing the 

--- Document Chunk 9118 ---
border (refer to 3.5.5.1e and 3.15.1.2.7) and then establish the session with the 

--- Document Chunk 9119 ---
Accepting RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9120 ---
3.15.1.3.3 As soon as the on -board equipment has established the session with the Accepting 

--- Document Chunk 9121 ---
RBC, it shall send its Train Data unless it is in sleeping or non leading mode. 

--- Document Chunk 9122 ---
3.15.1.3.4 When the on -board equipment is connected to both RBCs, it shall send its position 

--- Document Chunk 9123 ---
reports to both of them with the u se of the position report parameters valid for the 

--- Document Chunk 9124 ---
Handing Over RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9125 ---
3.15.1.3.4.1 If the on-board equipment is connected to both RBCs, and it executes an End of 

--- Document Chunk 9126 ---
Mission, it shall execute the End of Mission procedure with both RBCs 

--- Document Chunk 9127 ---
3.15.1.3.5 When the on -board sends a position rep ort directly to the Accepting RBC with its 

--- Document Chunk 9128 ---
maximum safe front end having passed the border, it shall use information received 

--- Document Chunk 9129 ---
from the Accepting RBC and only a disconnection order shall be accepted from the 

--- Document Chunk 9130 ---
Handing Over RBC.

3.15.2 Handling of Trains with Non Leading Engines 

--- Document Chunk 9191 ---
3.15.2.1 It shall be possible to operate a train using more than one engine, each engine being 

--- Document Chunk 9192 ---
under the control of a driver.   

--- Document Chunk 9193 ---
3.15.2.2 Only the leading engine shall be responsible for the train movement supervision 

--- Document Chunk 9194 ---
functions. 

--- Document Chunk 9195 ---
3.15.3 Splitting/joining 

--- Document Chunk 9196 ---
3.15.3.1 ERTMS/ETCS shall allow Splitting and Joining using the normal supervision functions 

--- Document Chunk 9197 ---
available (e.g. On-sight, Shunting). 

--- Document Chunk 9198 ---
3.15.3.2 Splitting only refers to the case that the two resulting trains contain at least one 

--- Document Chunk 9199 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment each. 

--- Document Chunk 9200 ---
3.15.3.2.1 Note: This must be ensured by operational procedures. 

--- Document Chunk 9201 ---
3.15.3.3 ERTMS/ETCS is not responsible for providing information that a Splitting/Joining 

--- Document Chunk 9202 ---
operation has been correctly completed (technical aspect and/or operational aspect). 

--- Document Chunk 9203 ---
3.15.3.4 Justification: ERTMS/ETCS is not able to provide this information. Splitting and Joining 

--- Document Chunk 9204 ---
shall require the fulfilment of operating rules ensuring that a Splitting/Joining operation 

--- Document Chunk 9205 ---
has been correctly completed (e.g. physical disconnection). 

--- Document Chunk 9206 ---

area, the fixed reference location being the end location of the area where reversing

of movement is permitted at the time of reception of this reversing area information. 

--- Document Chunk 9217 ---

3.15.5 Track ahead free 

--- Document Chunk 9312 ---
3.15.5.1 In a level 2/3 area, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall be able to handle a 

--- Document Chunk 9313 ---
track ahead free request given by the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 9314 ---
3.15.5.2 The track ahead free request from the RBC shall indicate to the on-board 

--- Document Chunk 9315 ---
a) at which location the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall begin to display the 

--- Document Chunk 9316 ---
request to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 9317 ---
b) at wh ich location the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall stop to display the 

--- Document Chunk 9318 ---
request to the driver (in case the driver did not acknowledge). 

--- Document Chunk 9319 ---
3.15.5.3 The driver shall have the possibility to acknowledge the track ahead free request 

--- Document Chunk 9320 ---
(meaning the driver confirms that the  track between the head of the train and the next 

--- Document Chunk 9321 ---
signal or board marking signal position is free). 

--- Document Chunk 9322 ---
3.15.5.4 When the driver acknowledges, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall stop 

--- Document Chunk 9323 ---
displaying the request, and shall inform the RBC that the track ahead is free. 

--- Document Chunk 9324 ---
3.15.5.5 There shall be no restrictive consequence by the on -board system if the driver does 

--- Document Chunk 9325 ---
not acknowledge. 

--- Document Chunk 9326 ---
3.15.5.6 A new track ahead free request shall replace the one previously received and stored. 

--- Document Chunk 9327 ---

3.15.7 Tolerance of Big Metal Mass 

--- Document Chunk 9352 ---
3.15.7.1 Big metal object in the track, exceeding the limits for big metal masses as def ined in 

--- Document Chunk 9353 ---
Subset-036, section 6.5.2 “Metal Masses in the Track” may trigger an alarm reporting 

--- Document Chunk 9354 ---
a malfunction for the onboard balise transmission function. 

--- Document Chunk 9355 ---
3.15.7.2 In Levels 0/NTC, the alarms which may be triggered by metal masses shall be ignored 

--- Document Chunk 9356 ---
for a defined dista nce (see A3.1). If the alarm persists for a longer distance the 

--- Document Chunk 9357 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall trigger a safety reaction. 

--- Document Chunk 9358 ---
3.15.7.3 Justification: Ignoring the alarm for a defined distance eliminates the need to equip all 

--- Document Chunk 9359 ---
excessive big metal masses with track c ondition “Big Metal Mass” outside ETCS fitted 

--- Document Chunk 9360 ---
areas. 

--- Document Chunk 9361 ---
3.15.8 Cold Movement Detection 

--- Document Chunk 9362 ---
3.15.8.1 After being switched off (i.e. once in No Power mode), the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 9363 ---
equipment shall be capable, if fitted with, to detect and record whether the engine has 

--- Document Chunk 9364 ---
been moved or not, during a period of at least 72 hours. 

--- Document Chunk 9365 ---
3.15.8.2 When powered on again, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall use, if 

--- Document Chunk 9366 ---
available, the memorised information about cold movement in order to update the 

--- Document Chunk 9367 ---
status of information stored by on -board equipment (see chap ter 4 section 4.11 for 

--- Document Chunk 9368 ---
details). 

--- Document Chunk 9369 ---
3.15.8.3 Note: information memorised by Cold Movement Detection function is considered as 

--- Document Chunk 9370 ---
not available if: 

--- Document Chunk 9371 ---
a) no Cold Movement Detection function is implemented in the ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 9372 ---
board equipment, OR 

--- Document Chunk 9373 ---
b) the Cold Movement Detection func tion has encountered a condition, during the No 

--- Document Chunk 9374 ---
Power period, which prevents the use of the Cold Movement information (e.g. the 

--- Document Chunk 9375 ---
battery ensuring the Cold Movement Detection function has run down during the No 

--- Document Chunk 9376 ---
Power period).

3.15.9 Virtual Balise Cover 

--- Document Chunk 9389 ---
3.15.9.1 It shall be possible to set and remove from balise a Virtual Balise Cover (VBC). A VBC 

--- Document Chunk 9390 ---
is defined by: 

--- Document Chunk 9391 ---
a) A marker corresponding to balises to be ignored by the on -board together with the 

--- Document Chunk 9392 ---
area (country or region) in which the VBC is applicable. The VBC marker and the 

--- Document Chunk 9393 ---
country/region identity form the unique VBC identity. 

--- Document Chunk 9394 ---
b) Its validity period. 

--- Document Chunk 9395 ---
3.15.9.2 During a start of mission, the driver shall have the opportunity to set a new VBC, or to 

--- Document Chunk 9396 ---
remove an existing one. 

--- Document Chunk 9397 ---
3.15.9.3 As long as a VBC is stored on-board: 

--- Document Chunk 9398 ---
a) The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall ignore any balise telegram that 

--- Document Chunk 9399 ---
includes a VBC marker  and a country/region identity that both match the VBC 

--- Document Chunk 9400 ---
identity. 

--- Document Chunk 9401 ---
b) No reaction shall be applied if errors in the reading of the rest of such balise 

--- Document Chunk 9402 ---
telegram occur. 

--- Document Chunk 9403 ---
3.15.9.4 If the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipmen t receives from balise or from driver a new 

--- Document Chunk 9404 ---
VBC with the same VBC identity as an already stored VBC, the new VBC shall replace 

--- Document Chunk 9405 ---
the previous one, including its validity period. 

--- Document Chunk 9406 ---
3.15.9.5 A VBC shall be retained on-board when the on -board equipment is switched off (i. e. 

--- Document Chunk 9407 ---
enters No Power mode)  and shall remai n applicable when powered on  again. It shall 

--- Document Chunk 9408 ---
be deleted when: 

--- Document Chunk 9409 ---
a) it is ordered by trackside, or 

--- Document Chunk 9410 ---
b) its validity period has elapsed, or 

--- Document Chunk 9411 ---
c) it is removed by the driver (during Start of Mission), or 

--- Document Chunk 9412 ---
d) a mismatch is detected between the country/region identity read from a balise group 

--- Document Chunk 9413 ---
and the country/region identity of the VBC. Not e: this means that the reception of a 

--- Document Chunk 9414 ---
consistent balise group message is a necessary condition for deleting a VBC due to 

--- Document Chunk 9415 ---
mismatching country/region identities. 

--- Document Chunk 9416 ---
3.15.10 Advance display of route related information 

--- Document Chunk 9417 ---
3.15.10.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall offer the possibility to display , only on 

--- Document Chunk 9418 ---

3.16.1 Criteria of consistency 

--- Document Chunk 9444 ---
3.16.1.1 The on-board shall not consider a message transmitted from the trackside if any of the 

--- Document Chunk 9445 ---
following criteria is not fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 9446 ---
a) Correctness of the received message: the whole message shall be complete and 

--- Document Chunk 9447 ---
respect the ETCS language; variables shall not have invalid values  

--- Document Chunk 9448 ---
b) The message shall be received in due time. 

--- Document Chunk 9449 ---
c) The message shall be received at the right expected location. 

--- Document Chunk 9450 ---
as stated below. 

--- Document Chunk 9451 ---

--- Document Chunk 9453 ---
3.16.2.1 Definitions 

--- Document Chunk 9454 ---
3.16.2.1.1 The information that is sent from a balise is called a balise telegram. 

--- Document Chunk 9455 ---
3.16.2.1.2 The whole set of information (balise telegram or telegrams) coming from a ba lise 

--- Document Chunk 9456 ---
group is called a balise group message.  

--- Document Chunk 9457 ---

--- Document Chunk 9458 ---
coincide. 

--- Document Chunk 9459 ---

--- Document Chunk 9460 ---
a) No balise is found within the maximum distance between b alises from the previous 

--- Document Chunk 9461 ---
balise in the group.  

--- Document Chunk 9462 ---
or 

--- Document Chunk 9463 ---
b) A following balise within the group has been passed.

--- Document Chunk 9489 ---

applied.

3.16.3 Radio 

--- Document Chunk 9679 ---
3.16.3.1 General issues 

--- Document Chunk 9680 ---
3.16.3.1.1 A radio message is consistent when all checks have been completed successfully: 

--- Document Chunk 9681 ---
a) Checks performed by Euroradio protocol have been passed (see Subset-037) 

--- Document Chunk 9682 ---
b) Time stamps checks have been passed (see 3.16.3.3.3) 

--- Document Chunk 9683 ---
c) Variables in the messages do not have in-valid values. 

--- Document Chunk 9684 ---
3.16.3.1.1.1 The on -board shall reject a message transmitted from the trackside if the 

--- Document Chunk 9685 ---
message is not consistent. 

--- Document Chunk 9686 ---
3.16.3.1.1.2 The on-board shall inform the trackside if a not consistent message is received. 

--- Document Chunk 9687 ---
3.16.3.1.2 Emergency messages shall be transmitted either as high priority data or as normal 

--- Document Chunk 9688 ---
priority data. 

--- Document Chunk 9689 ---
3.16.3.1.3 Other messages shall be sent as normal priority data. 

--- Document Chunk 9690 ---
3.16.3.1.3.1 Messages shall only be accepted when received with the  data priority for which 

--- Document Chunk 9691 ---
they are specified. 

--- Document Chunk 9692 ---
3.16.3.1.4 The chapters 3.16.3.2 to 3.16.3.5 define data consistency principles and 

--- Document Chunk 9693 ---
corresponding checks for data transmitted as normal priority data.  

--- Document Chunk 9694 ---
For high priority data, the checks shall not apply. 

--- Document Chunk 9695 ---

3.16.3.2.2 To time-stamp its messages, the trackside shall make a safe estimation of the on-

--- Document Chunk 9709 ---

--- Document Chunk 9710 ---
processing times. 

--- Document Chunk 9711 ---

--- Document Chunk 9712 ---
trackside shall not be in advance of the real on-board time. 

--- Document Chunk 9713 ---

--- Document Chunk 9714 ---
shall have no impact on system behaviour. 

--- Document Chunk 9715 ---
3.16.3.3 Supervision of Sequence 

--- Document Chunk 9716 ---
3.16.3.3.1 The trackside shall time -stamp a message with a value corresponding to the time of 

--- Document Chunk 9717 ---
sending. 

--- Document Chunk 9718 ---
3.16.3.3.2 There shall always be a time stamp increment between consecutive messages. 

--- Document Chunk 9719 ---
3.16.3.3.3 If the time stamp of the last received message is lower  than or equal to the former one 

--- Document Chunk 9720 ---
its content shall not be used. 

--- Document Chunk 9721 ---
3.16.3.3.3.1 Only time stamps of messages received as normal priority data shall be used. 

--- Document Chunk 9722 ---
3.16.3.3.3.2 Note: The supervision does not detect a lost message. This has to be assured by 

--- Document Chunk 9723 ---
means of the “acknowledge” function. 

--- Document Chunk 9724 ---

--- Document Chunk 9725 ---
message shall be accepted.

--- Document Chunk 9851 ---

3.17.2 Determination of the operated system version 

--- Document Chunk 9854 ---
3.17.2.1 The on -board equipment shall be able to operate with (i.e. shall support) any of the 

--- Document Chunk 9855 ---
ERTMS/ETCS system version numbers X included in the envelope of legally operated 

--- Document Chunk 9856 ---
system versions, as defined in chapter 6. 

--- Document Chunk 9857 ---
3.17.2.2 The on-board equipment shall operate with only one syst em version at a time, i.e. it 

--- Document Chunk 9858 ---
shall behave according to the whole set of requirements applicable to a system version 

--- Document Chunk 9859 ---
(refer to chapter 6 in case the operated system version is older than the last one 

--- Document Chunk 9860 ---
introduced in this release of the SRS). 

--- Document Chunk 9861 ---
3.17.2.3 The on -board equ ipment shall determine the operated system version, in relation to 

--- Document Chunk 9862 ---
non-RBC trackside constituents, as the system version number X transmitted by any 

--- Document Chunk 9863 ---
balise, loop or RIU, if this system version number X is higher than the currently 

--- Document Chunk 9864 ---
operated one. 

--- Document Chunk 9865 ---
3.17.2.4 It shall be  possible from balise group to order the on -board equipment to operate a 

--- Document Chunk 9866 ---
system version. 

--- Document Chunk 9867 ---

--- Document Chunk 9868 ---
equipment shall immediately operate the system version given in the order. After the 

--- Document Chunk 9869 ---
order is executed, the requirement 3.17.2.3 shall be again applied for any further 

--- Document Chunk 9870 ---
received balise telegram/loop message or any further contacted RIU. 

--- Document Chunk 9871 ---
3.17.2.5.1 Note: the system version order is to be used wherever it is necessary to enforce an 

--- Document Chunk 9872 ---
operated system version number X lower than the currently operated one. 

--- Document Chunk 9873 ---
3.17.2.6 If a mismatch has been detected between the country or region identifier read from a 

--- Document Chunk 9874 ---
balise/loop and the corresponding identifier(s) for which a set of national values is used 

--- Document Chunk 9875 ---
onboard, the on -board equipmen t shall consider the system version number X

3.18.4.4 ETCS Identity 

--- Document Chunk 10217 ---
3.18.4.4.1 The ETCS identity of an on -board equipment is made of a single identity number. The 

--- Document Chunk 10218 ---
ETCS identity of an RBC, balise group, loop or RIU is composed of a country/region 

--- Document Chunk 10219 ---
identity number and of an identity number within the country/region. 

--- Document Chunk 10220 ---
3.18.4.4.2 All on-board equipments in service, balise groups marked as linked, RBC’s, RIU’s, and 

--- Document Chunk 10221 ---
loops shall be assigned a unique ETCS identity within their respective group. 

--- Document Chunk 10222 ---
3.18.4.4.3 The assignment of (unique or not) ETCS identities to balise groups marked as 

--- Document Chunk 10223 ---
unlinked is the sole responsibility of the entity in charge of the assignment of values 

--- Document Chunk 10224 ---
(see SUBSET-054), depending on the specific trackside implementation. 

--- Document Chunk 10225 ---
3.18.4.5 Train Running Number 

--- Document Chunk 10226 ---
3.18.4.5.1 During the Start of Mission, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment of a leading engine 

--- Document Chunk 10227 ---
shall acquire the train running number from driver input, from the RBC or from other 

--- Document Chunk 10228 ---
ERTMS/ETCS external sources. 

--- Document Chunk 10229 ---
3.18.4.5.2 It shall be possible to enter train running number also in a non-leading engine. 

--- Document Chunk 10230 ---
3.18.4.5.3 It shall be possible to change the train running number while running, from driver input, 

--- Document Chunk 10231 ---
from the RBC or from other ERTMS/ETCS external sources. 

--- Document Chunk 10232 ---
3.18.4.5.4 Following any entry/modification of the train running number when a communication 

--- Document Chunk 10233 ---
session is already established or following the successful establishment of a 

--- Document Chunk 10234 ---
communication session  when valid train running number is already available, the 

--- Document Chunk 10235 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall send the train running number to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 10236 ---
3.18.4.5.4.1 Exception: if the train running number has been received from the RBC, it shall 

--- Document Chunk 10237 ---
not be sent back to the RBC by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 10238 ---
3.18.4.5.5 The unit, range and resolution of the train running number shall be as specified in 

--- Document Chunk 10239 ---
A.3.11.

3.18.4.6.1 The adhesion factor shall be used to adjust the emergency brake model of the train  

--- Document Chunk 10253 ---
(see 3.13).  

--- Document Chunk 10254 ---
3.18.4.6.2 The adhesion factor may be changed while the train is running. 

--- Document Chunk 10255 ---
3.18.4.6.2.1 It shall be possible to update the adhesion factor from trackside and - if permitted 

--- Document Chunk 10256 ---
by a National value - by the driver.  If, following a change of National Values, the 

--- Document Chunk 10257 ---
update of the adhesion factor is no more permitte d to the driver, the adhesion factor 

--- Document Chunk 10258 ---
previously modified by the driver to slippery rail shall immediately be reset to non 

--- Document Chunk 10259 ---
slippery rail. Any trackside adhesion profile is not affected. 

--- Document Chunk 10260 ---
3.18.4.6.2.2 The adhesion factor shall be sent as profile data from trackside when needed. 

--- Document Chunk 10261 ---
3.18.4.6.2.3 The driver shall be informed whether the value of the adhesion factor is “slippery 

--- Document Chunk 10262 ---
rail”. 

--- Document Chunk 10263 ---
3.18.4.6.3 The selection of the adhesion value from trackside or by driver entry shall be limited to 

--- Document Chunk 10264 ---
the options slippery rail/ non slippery rail. 

--- Document Chunk 10265 ---
3.18.4.6.3.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 10266 ---
3.18.4.6.4 The default value for the adhesion factor shall be the highest value (i.e. not slippery 

--- Document Chunk 10267 ---
rail). 

--- Document Chunk 10268 ---

A.3.5 Handling of Actions in Specific Situations 

--- Document Chunk 10869 ---
A.3.5.1 Regards actions executed in reference to location information received from trackside, 

--- Document Chunk 10870 ---
the on -board equipment shall ensure that the action related to a location is neither 

--- Document Chunk 10871 ---
reverted, nor executed twice. Situations to be considered shall include reverse 

--- Document Chunk 10872 ---
movement (initiated by driver or due to roll -away) and the sub -sequent forward 

--- Document Chunk 10873 ---
movement, or adjustment of train position on passing a new LRBG . This rule shall 

--- Document Chunk 10874 ---
apply to the following actions: 

--- Document Chunk 10875 ---
 Change of National Values (see 3.18.2) 

--- Document Chunk 10876 ---
 Request to acknowledge new level, level transition (see SRS chapter 5.10) 

--- Document Chunk 10877 ---
 Start and stop displaying plain or fixed text messages (see 3.12.3) 

--- Document Chunk 10878 ---
 Request to acknowledge a mode profile, mode transition due to mode profile (see 

--- Document Chunk 10879 ---
3.12.4) 

--- Document Chunk 10880 ---
 Start and stop accepting radio infill information (see 3.9.3) 

--- Document Chunk 10881 ---
 Actions related to RBC/RBC handover (see 3.15.1) 

--- Document Chunk 10882 ---
 Actions related to track condition information (see 3.12.1) with the exception of big 

--- Document Chunk 10883 ---
metal masses and non stopping areas 

--- Document Chunk 10884 ---
 Permission to initiate Reversing mode, i.e., limits of Reversing Area (see 3.15.4) 

--- Document Chunk 10885 ---
 Start and stop Track Ahead free request to driver (see 3.15.5)” 

--- Document Chunk 10886 ---
 Start and stop calculation of geographical position (see 3.6.6) 

--- Document Chunk 10887 ---
A.3.5.2 Once the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment has received a balise group message 

--- Document Chunk 10888 ---
(i.e. once it has received the last balise telegram of the balise group), the action(s) 

--- Document Chunk 10889 ---
resulting from its content shall take into account the train position measured at the time 

--- Document Chunk 10890 ---
of reception of this last telegram and shall take precedence on any other action related 

--- Document Chunk 10891 ---
to a further location that is reached before the message has been fully processed. 

--- Document Chunk 10892 ---
A.3.5.2.1 Example 1: in level 1, the crossing of the EOA/LOA location with the min safe antenna, 

--- Document Chunk 10893 ---
before a new extended MA (received when the min safe antenna was in rear of the 

--- Document Chunk 10894 ---
EOA/LOA) has been pr ocessed, will not lead to train trip. In other terms the 

--- Document Chunk 10895 ---
replacement of the EOA/LOA is considered by the on -board as happening before the 

--- Document Chunk 10896 ---
min safe antenna crosses the EOA/LOA location (i.e. preventing that clause 

--- Document Chunk 10897 ---
3.13.10.2.7 applies). 

--- Document Chunk 10898 ---
A.3.5.2.2 Example 2: when the override function is active, the crossing of the former EOA 

--- Document Chunk 10899 ---
location by the min safe antenna, before a “Stop if in SR” information (received when 

--- Document Chunk 10900 ---
the min safe antenna was in rear of the former EOA) has been processed, will not lead 

--- Document Chunk 10901 ---
to the end of t he override procedure followed by a train trip due to “Stop if in SR”. In 

--- Document Chunk 10902 ---
other terms, both the deletion of the former EOA and the end of override procedure 

--- Document Chunk 10903 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

A.3.6 Deletion of accepted and stored information when used 

--- Document Chunk 10917 ---
A3.6.1 Standard case 

--- Document Chunk 10918 ---
A3.6.1.1 When the train moves in the direction of its train orientation, storage capacity occupied 

--- Document Chunk 10919 ---
by trackside informa tion no longer used, i.e., the related on -board functionality has 

--- Document Chunk 10920 ---
been completed, shall be made available immediately. 

--- Document Chunk 10921 ---
A3.6.1.1.1 Note: The requirement is needed to allow trackside to predict the storage capacity 

--- Document Chunk 10922 ---
available on -board in order to comply with dimensioning rules regards information 

--- Document Chunk 10923 ---
stored on-board given in Subset 040. 

--- Document Chunk 10924 ---
A3.6.2 Exception 

--- Document Chunk 10925 ---
A3.6.2.1 Following information shall remain stored on -board for a distance defined by a fixed 

--- Document Chunk 10926 ---
value in rear of the min safe rear end position of the train: 

--- Document Chunk 10927 ---
 location dependent static speed restrictions , i.e., SSP, ASP, TSR, LX SR, PBD SR 

--- Document Chunk 10928 ---
(see 3.11.2.2) 

--- Document Chunk 10929 ---
 gradient information, 

--- Document Chunk 10930 ---
 reduced adhesion information received from trackside, 

--- Document Chunk 10931 ---
 Track condition “Big metal masses”. 

--- Document Chunk 10932 ---
A3.6.2.1.1 Note: The above information remains stored for the case of a reverse movement: 

--- Document Chunk 10933 ---
 With the exception of the track condition “Big metal masses”,  the stored 

--- Document Chunk 10934 ---
information allows the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment to calculate speed 

--- Document Chunk 10935 ---
supervision limits after a reverse movement (roll-away, or initiated by the driver)  

--- Document Chunk 10936 ---
 Track condition “Big metal masses” is needed also for a reverse movement itself to 

--- Document Chunk 10937 ---
avoid any false alarms due to Big metal masses in the track. 

--- Document Chunk 10938 ---
A3.6.2.1.2 Note: The distance to intervention of the roll away or reverse movement supervision is 

--- Document Chunk 10939 ---
determined by a National/Default value.  This is also true for a reverse movement in 

--- Document Chunk 10940 ---
Post trip mode. However, following an intervention, the train will not stop immediately. 

--- Document Chunk 10941 ---
In order to keep the on -board functionality simple, a fixed distance value was chosen  

--- Document Chunk 10942 ---
to define an unambiguous location in rear of the train where the above information is 

--- Document Chunk 10943 ---
no longer required and the related on-board storage capacity is made available again. 

--- Document Chunk 10944 ---

--- Document Chunk 10946 ---
λo = λ for calculation of emergency brake deceleration (A_brake_emergency(V))

λo = MIN (λ, 135) for calculation of service brake deceleration (A_brake_service(V)) 

--- Document Chunk 10959 ---
where λ is the brake percentage defined as part of Train Data. 

--- Document Chunk 10960 ---
A.3.7.2 The calculation of the basic deceleration (A_basic(V)) shall use a common algorithm 

--- Document Chunk 10961 ---
that will be used twice, once for the service brake and once for the emergency brake. 

--- Document Chunk 10962 ---
A.3.7.3 The speed limit for the first step shall be calculated as V_lim = x * λo

--- Document Chunk 10963 ---
y. 

--- Document Chunk 10964 ---
V_lim is the speed limit for the first step in km/h 

--- Document Chunk 10965 ---
x = 16.85 

--- Document Chunk 10966 ---
y = 0.428 

--- Document Chunk 10967 ---
A.3.7.4 The first step of the basic deceleration shall be calculated as AD_0 = A * λo + B 

--- Document Chunk 10968 ---
AD_0 is the basic deceleration in m/s2 for 0 ≤ speed ≤ V_lim. 

--- Document Chunk 10969 ---
A = 0.0075 

--- Document Chunk 10970 ---
B = 0.076 

--- Document Chunk 10971 ---
A.3.7.5 The following steps of the basic deceleration shall be calculated by means of a set of 

--- Document Chunk 10972 ---
polynomials of the third order with the following format: 

--- Document Chunk 10973 ---
AD_n = a3_n * λo

--- Document Chunk 10974 ---
3 + a2_n * λo

--- Document Chunk 10975 ---
2 + a1_n * λo + a0_n 

--- Document Chunk 10976 ---
and with the following values for n (all speed limits in km/h): 

--- Document Chunk 10977 ---
n = 1   valid for V_lim < speed ≤ 100  if V_lim ≤ 100 

--- Document Chunk 10978 ---
to be ignored       if V_lim > 100 

--- Document Chunk 10979 ---
n = 2   valid for V_lim < speed ≤ 120  if 100 < V_lim ≤ 120 

--- Document Chunk 10980 ---
valid for 100 < speed ≤ 120  if V_lim ≤ 100 

--- Document Chunk 10981 ---
to be ignored       if V_lim > 120 

--- Document Chunk 10982 ---
n = 3   valid for V_lim < speed ≤ 150  if 120 < V_lim ≤ 150 

--- Document Chunk 10983 ---
valid for 120 < speed ≤ 150  if V_lim ≤ 120 

--- Document Chunk 10984 ---
to be ignored       if V_lim > 150 

--- Document Chunk 10985 ---
n = 4   valid for V_lim < speed ≤ 180  if 150 < V_lim ≤ 180 

--- Document Chunk 10986 ---
valid for 150 < speed ≤ 180  if V_lim ≤ 150 

--- Document Chunk 10987 ---
to be ignored       if V_lim > 180 

--- Document Chunk 10988 ---
n = 5   valid for V_lim < speed  if V_lim > 180   

--- Document Chunk 10989 ---
valid for 180 < speed  if V_lim ≤ 180 

--- Document Chunk 10990 ---

A.3.10 Service brake feedback 

--- Document Chunk 11126 ---
A.3.10.1 The purpose of service brake feedback is to reduce the distance between the SBI and 

--- Document Chunk 11127 ---
EBI supervision limits and between the SBI and SBD curves. 

--- Document Chunk 11128 ---
A.3.10.2 The on-board shall consider the service brake feedback as available for use if: 

--- Document Chunk 11129 ---
a) The service brake feedback is implemented, AND 

--- Document Chunk 11130 ---
b) The national value does not inhibit its use. 

--- Document Chunk 11131 ---
A.3.10.3 Two different types of feedback from the service brake are specified, main brake pipe 

--- Document Chunk 11132 ---
pressure and brake cylinder p ressure. The algorithms below are made for main brake 

--- Document Chunk 11133 ---
pipe pressure. When brake cylinder pressure is used instead this shall be converted 

--- Document Chunk 11134 ---
into a fictive main brake pressure value in the following way: 

--- Document Chunk 11135 ---

--- Document Chunk 11152 ---
to take the service brake feedback into account: 

--- Document Chunk 11153 ---

--- Document Chunk 11154 ---
A.3.10.3) 

--- Document Chunk 11155 ---
p0 = reference pressure when not braking  

--- Document Chunk 11156 ---

--- Document Chunk 11157 ---
p2 = pressure limit, under which T_bs1 and T_bs2 are locked = p0 - 60  

--- Document Chunk 11158 ---
p3 = pressure at full service brake = p0 - 150  

--- Document Chunk 11159 ---

--- Document Chunk 11160 ---
reduce T_bs1 and T_bs2.

 The r eference pressure p0 shall thereafter be adapted to the current pressure 

--- Document Chunk 11246 ---
according to the following table (which applies if the calculation is performed once per 

--- Document Chunk 11247 ---
second): 

--- Document Chunk 11248 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11249 ---
 CONDITIONS: ACTION: REMARKS 

--- Document Chunk 11250 ---
a) p = p0 No change Constant pressure 

--- Document Chunk 11251 ---
b) p > p0 p0 = p0 + 1,5 Increasing pressure 

--- Document Chunk 11252 ---
c) p < p0 - 30 No change Braking 

--- Document Chunk 11253 ---
d) p0 > p > p0 - 30 p0 = p0  0,5 Decreasing pressure 

--- Document Chunk 11254 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11255 ---
Where:  

--- Document Chunk 11256 ---
- p is limited to max 550 kPa. 

--- Document Chunk 11257 ---
- Values given in kPa. 

--- Document Chunk 11258 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11259 ---
A.3.10.5 Note: If T_bs1 and T_bs2 have been locked to 0s and 2 s, the loc king will remain until 

--- Document Chunk 11260 ---
the target speed monitoring is left, even if the train speed comes below the target 

--- Document Chunk 11261 ---
speed. This avoids “jumping” indications. It also makes it possible to release the 

--- Document Chunk 11262 ---
brakes before a speed reduction, without having the curves moving back again. It 

--- Document Chunk 11263 ---
might though result in emergency brake intervention if the driver releases the brakes 

--- Document Chunk 11264 ---
too early. But since EBI is not moved, this is not a safety issue. To keep 2 s between 

--- Document Chunk 11265 ---
the SBI and EBI enables the service brake to be activated first and thus may avoid 

--- Document Chunk 11266 ---
emergency brake. 

--- Document Chunk 11267 ---
A.3.10.6 Note: If feedback has started but T_bs1 and T_bs2 are not locked, the feedback 

--- Document Chunk 11268 ---
function will remain active until the target point is reached. This avoids “jumping” 

--- Document Chunk 11269 ---
indications in some rare situations.

--- Document Chunk 11623 ---
4.3 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 11624 ---
4.3.1 Presentation of the document 

--- Document Chunk 11625 ---
4.3.1.1 This document defines the modes of the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment (see 

--- Document Chunk 11626 ---
chapter 4.4 “Definition of the modes” and chapter 4.5 “Modes and on-board functions”. 

--- Document Chunk 11627 ---
4.3.1.2 This document gives all transitions between modes (see chapter 4.6 “Tr ansitions 

--- Document Chunk 11628 ---
between modes”). 

--- Document Chunk 11629 ---
4.3.1.3 This document describes the possible exchanged information between the driver and 

--- Document Chunk 11630 ---
the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment, respect to the mode (see chapter  4.7 “ DMI 

--- Document Chunk 11631 ---
depending on modes”). 

--- Document Chunk 11632 ---
4.3.1.4 This document describes how the received informa tion is filtered, respect to several 

--- Document Chunk 11633 ---
criteria such as the level, the mode, etc.. (see chapter 4.8 “Acceptance of received 

--- Document Chunk 11634 ---
information”). 

--- Document Chunk 11635 ---
4.3.1.5 This document describes how the stored information is handled, respect to several 

--- Document Chunk 11636 ---
criteria such as the level, the mode,  etc. (see chapter 4.9 “What happens to accepted 

--- Document Chunk 11637 ---
and stored information when entering a given level”, and chapter 4.10 “What happens 

--- Document Chunk 11638 ---
to accepted and stored information when entering a given mode”). 

--- Document Chunk 11639 ---
4.3.1.6 All the tables that are included in this document shall be  considered as mandatory 

--- Document Chunk 11640 ---
requirements. 

--- Document Chunk 11641 ---
4.3.1.7 Some notes appear in this document. These notes are here to help the reader to 

--- Document Chunk 11642 ---
understand the specifications, or to explain the reason(s) of a requirement. 

--- Document Chunk 11643 ---

--- Document Chunk 11648 ---

--- Document Chunk 11649 ---

--- Document Chunk 11650 ---

--- Document Chunk 11651 ---
Passive Shunting (PS) 

--- Document Chunk 11652 ---

4.4 Definition of the modes 

--- Document Chunk 11683 ---
4.4.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 11684 ---
4.4.1.1 For each mode the following information is given: 

--- Document Chunk 11685 ---
a) The context of utilisation of the mode and the functions that characterise the mode 

--- Document Chunk 11686 ---
(chapter “Description”).  

--- Document Chunk 11687 ---
b) The E RTMS/ETCS levels in which the mode can be used (chapter “Used in 

--- Document Chunk 11688 ---
levels”). 

--- Document Chunk 11689 ---
c) The related responsibility of the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment and of the 

--- Document Chunk 11690 ---
driver, once the equipment is in this mode (chapter “Responsibilities”). 

--- Document Chunk 11691 ---
4.4.1.2 A complete list of transitions to  and from each mode is given in the section 4.6.2 

--- Document Chunk 11692 ---
“Transitions Table” ).

4.4.3 ISOLATION 

--- Document Chunk 11708 ---
4.4.3.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 11709 ---
4.4.3.1.1 In Isolation mode, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall be physically isolated 

--- Document Chunk 11710 ---
from the brakes  and can be isolated from other on -board equipments/systems 

--- Document Chunk 11711 ---
depending on the specific on-board implementation. 

--- Document Chunk 11712 ---
4.4.3.1.2 There shall be a clear indication to the driver that the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 11713 ---
equipment is isolated. 

--- Document Chunk 11714 ---
4.4.3.1.3 To leave Isolation mode, a special operating procedure is needed (no transition from 

--- Document Chunk 11715 ---
Isolation is specified). This procedure shall ensure that the on -board equipment is only 

--- Document Chunk 11716 ---
put back into service when it has been proven that this is safe for operation. 

--- Document Chunk 11717 ---
4.4.3.1.4 Note: for the list of main functions related to this mode, refer to chapter  4.5 “Modes 

--- Document Chunk 11718 ---
and on-board functions”. 

--- Document Chunk 11719 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11720 ---
4.4.3.2 Used in levels 

--- Document Chunk 11721 ---
4.4.3.2.1 Used in all levels: Level 0, level 1, level 2, level 3 and level NTC. 

--- Document Chunk 11722 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11723 ---
4.4.3.3 Responsibilities 

--- Document Chunk 11724 ---
4.4.3.3.1 Isolation of the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment is performed by the driver under his 

--- Document Chunk 11725 ---
complete responsibility. 

--- Document Chunk 11726 ---
4.4.3.3.2 Once the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment is isolated, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 11727 ---
equipment has no more responsibility. 

--- Document Chunk 11728 ---

--- Document Chunk 11739 ---

--- Document Chunk 11740 ---

--- Document Chunk 11741 ---

--- Document Chunk 11743 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment may be fed by an auxiliary power supply. 

--- Document Chunk 11744 ---
4.4.4.1.2 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall permanently command the emergency 

--- Document Chunk 11745 ---
brake. 

--- Document Chunk 11746 ---

--- Document Chunk 11747 ---
and on-board functions”.

--- Document Chunk 11754 ---

--- Document Chunk 11755 ---

--- Document Chunk 11756 ---
4.4.4.3.3 If it is required to move a loco in NP mode as a wagon, ETCS brake command must 

--- Document Chunk 11757 ---
be overridden by external means.

4.4.6 SLEEPING 

--- Document Chunk 11795 ---
4.4.6.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 11796 ---
4.4.6.1.1 The Sleeping mode is defined to manage the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment of a 

--- Document Chunk 11797 ---
slave engine that is remote controlled. 

--- Document Chunk 11798 ---
4.4.6.1.2 The desk (s) of a sleeping engine must be closed (since there is no driver, no 

--- Document Chunk 11799 ---
information shall be shown). 

--- Document Chunk 11800 ---
4.4.6.1.3 As the engine is remote controlled by the le ading engine, its ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 11801 ---
equipment shall not perform any train movement supervision. 

--- Document Chunk 11802 ---
4.4.6.1.4 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall perform the Train Position function; in 

--- Document Chunk 11803 ---
particular, the front/rear end of the engine (i.e., not the train) shall be us ed to refer to 

--- Document Chunk 11804 ---
train front/rear end. 

--- Document Chunk 11805 ---
4.4.6.1.5 Sleeping mode shall be automatically detected on-board via the train interface. 

--- Document Chunk 11806 ---
4.4.6.1.6 If possible, the train must not be stopped due to a safety critical fault in a sleeping 

--- Document Chunk 11807 ---
engine. The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall the refore try to memorise the 

--- Document Chunk 11808 ---
occurrence of such fault(s), which shall be handled when the engine leaves the 

--- Document Chunk 11809 ---
Sleeping mode. The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall also try to send an error 

--- Document Chunk 11810 ---
information to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 11811 ---
4.4.6.1.7 If a desk of the sleeping engine is opened wh ile the train is running (this is an 

--- Document Chunk 11812 ---
abnormal operation), the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall switch to Stand -By 

--- Document Chunk 11813 ---
mode. 

--- Document Chunk 11814 ---
4.4.6.1.8 If the “sleeping input signal” is lost (no more detection of the remote control), the 

--- Document Chunk 11815 ---
switch to Stand-By mode shall be made only if the train is at standstill. 

--- Document Chunk 11816 ---
4.4.6.1.9 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 11817 ---
4.4.6.1.10 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall open a communication session with the 

--- Document Chunk 11818 ---
RBC when at least one of the following events occurs: 

--- Document Chunk 11819 ---
a) in all levels, on receipt of the order to contact the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 11820 ---
b) In level 2/3, w hen entering or exiting Sleeping mode (to report the change of mode 

--- Document Chunk 11821 ---
to the RBC). 

--- Document Chunk 11822 ---
c) In level 2/3, when a safety critical fault of the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 11823 ---
occurs (to report the fault to the RBC). 

--- Document Chunk 11824 ---
4.4.6.1.11 Note: for the list of main functions related to this m ode, refer to chapter  4.5 “Modes 

--- Document Chunk 11825 ---
and on-board functions”. 

--- Document Chunk 11826 ---
4.4.6.1.12 In case of balise group message consistency error (refer to 3.16.2.4.4 and 3.16.2.5.1), 

--- Document Chunk 11827 ---
the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment shall not command the service brake. 

--- Document Chunk 11828 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

4.4.7 STAND BY 

--- Document Chunk 11863 ---
4.4.7.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 11864 ---
4.4.7.1.1 The Stand-By mode is a default mode and cannot be selected by the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 11865 ---
4.4.7.1.2 It is in the Stand-By mode that the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment awakes. 

--- Document Chunk 11866 ---
4.4.7.1.3 Data for mission shall be collected in Stand -By (see SRS-chapter 5: “Start of Mission” 

--- Document Chunk 11867 ---
procedure). 

--- Document Chunk 11868 ---
4.4.7.1.4 In Stand-By mode, the desk of the engine can be open or closed. No interaction with 

--- Document Chunk 11869 ---
the driver shall be possible as long as the desk is closed, except isolation of the 

--- Document Chunk 11870 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 11871 ---
4.4.7.1.5 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall perform the Standstill Supervision. 

--- Document Chunk 11872 ---
4.4.7.1.6 Note: for the list of main functions related to this mode, refer to chapter  4.5 “Modes 

--- Document Chunk 11873 ---
and on-board functions”.

--- Document Chunk 11876 ---
4.4.7.2.1 Used in all levels: Level 0, level 1, level 2, level 3 and level NTC.

--- Document Chunk 11878 ---
4.4.7.3 Responsibilities 

--- Document Chunk 11879 ---
4.4.7.3.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment is respon sible for maintaining the train at 

--- Document Chunk 11880 ---
standstill. 

--- Document Chunk 11881 ---
4.4.7.3.2 The driver has no responsibility for train movements. 

--- Document Chunk 11882 ---

4.4.8 SHUNTING 

--- Document Chunk 11893 ---
4.4.8.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 11894 ---
4.4.8.1.1 The purpose of the Shunting mode is to enable shunting movements. In Shunting 

--- Document Chunk 11895 ---
mode, The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment supervises the train movements 

--- Document Chunk 11896 ---
against: 

--- Document Chunk 11897 ---
a) a ceiling speed: the shunting mode speed limit  

--- Document Chunk 11898 ---
b) a list of expected balise  groups (if such list was sent by the trackside equipment). 

--- Document Chunk 11899 ---
The train shall be tripped if a balise group, not contained in the list, is passed 

--- Document Chunk 11900 ---
(When an empty list is sent, no balise group can be passed. When no list is sent, 

--- Document Chunk 11901 ---
all balise groups can be passed) 

--- Document Chunk 11902 ---
c) “stop if in shunting mode” information. The train is tripped if such information is 

--- Document Chunk 11903 ---
received from balise groups 

--- Document Chunk 11904 ---
d) Intentionally deleted 

--- Document Chunk 11905 ---
4.4.8.1.2 The Shunting mode shall not require Train Data. 

--- Document Chunk 11906 ---
4.4.8.1.3 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall perform the Train Position function 

--- Document Chunk 11907 ---
4.4.8.1.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 11908 ---
4.4.8.1.5 When in Shunting mode, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board shall not manage level 

--- Document Chunk 11909 ---
transitions. However, an immediate level transition order or a conditional level 

--- Document Chunk 11910 ---
transition order shall be stored and evaluated only when another mode than Shunting 

--- Document Chunk 11911 ---
or Passive Shunting has been entered  (i.e. when the Shunting movement is 

--- Document Chunk 11912 ---
terminated). 

--- Document Chunk 11913 ---
4.4.8.1.5.1 When receiving a communication session establishment order, the ER TMS/ETCS on-

--- Document Chunk 11914 ---
board in Shunting mode shall not establish the communication session, but shall store 

--- Document Chunk 11915 ---
the RBC ID/phone number. 

--- Document Chunk 11916 ---
4.4.8.1.5.2 When in Shunting mode, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board shall not manage RBC -RBC 

--- Document Chunk 11917 ---
hand-over, except for storing the RBC ID/phone number given at the RBC/RBC border. 

--- Document Chunk 11918 ---
4.4.8.1.6 Shunting mode can be selected by the driver, only accepted when the train is at 

--- Document Chunk 11919 ---
standstill, or ordered by the trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 11920 ---
4.4.8.1.7 In case of selection of Shunting mode by the driver: 

--- Document Chunk 11921 ---
 in level 1 operations, the switch to shunting is always acce pted by the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 11922 ---
equipment 

--- Document Chunk 11923 ---
 in level 2 and 3 areas, the on-board shall ask the trackside for an authorisation. The 

--- Document Chunk 11924 ---
switch to shunting is possible only after receiving such authorisation. The trackside 

--- Document Chunk 11925 ---
can send a list of balises, that the train is allowe d to pass while in SH, together with 

--- Document Chunk 11926 ---
the authorisation 

--- Document Chunk 11927 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 11928 ---

4.4.9 FULL SUPERVISION 

--- Document Chunk 11977 ---
4.4.9.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 11978 ---
4.4.9.1.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall be in the Full Supervision mode when all 

--- Document Chunk 11979 ---
train and track data, which is require d for a complete supervision of the train, is 

--- Document Chunk 11980 ---
available on board. 

--- Document Chunk 11981 ---
4.4.9.1.2 Full supervision cannot be selected by the driver, but shall be entered automatically 

--- Document Chunk 11982 ---
when all necessary conditions are fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 11983 ---
4.4.9.1.3 To be in Full Supervision mode, SSP and gradient are not re quired for the whole 

--- Document Chunk 11984 ---
length of the train, but shall be at least available from the FRONT END of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 11985 ---
4.4.9.1.4 Once in Full Supervision mode, if SSP and gradient are not known for the whole length 

--- Document Chunk 11986 ---
of the train, an indication “ENTRY IN FULL SUPERVISION” shall b e clearly displayed 

--- Document Chunk 11987 ---
to the driver until SSP and gradient are known for the whole length of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 11988 ---
4.4.9.1.4.1 Note: this indication may also be displayed in case the train length has been increased, 

--- Document Chunk 11989 ---
see 3.18.3.8. 

--- Document Chunk 11990 ---
4.4.9.1.5 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall supervise t rain movements against a 

--- Document Chunk 11991 ---
dynamic speed profile. 

--- Document Chunk 11992 ---
4.4.9.1.6 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall display the train speed, the permitted 

--- Document Chunk 11993 ---
speed, the target distance and the target speed to the driver (this list is not exhaustive 

--- Document Chunk 11994 ---
– refer to chapter 4.7 “DMI depending on modes”). 

--- Document Chunk 11995 ---
4.4.9.1.7 Note: for the list of main functions related to this mode, refer to chapter  4.5 “Modes 

--- Document Chunk 11996 ---
and on-board functions”. 

--- Document Chunk 11997 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 11998 ---
4.4.9.2 Used in levels 

--- Document Chunk 11999 ---
4.4.9.2.1 Used in level 1, 2 and 3. 

--- Document Chunk 12000 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 12001 ---
4.4.9.3 Responsibilities 

--- Document Chunk 12002 ---
4.4.9.3.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment is fully responsible for the train protection 

--- Document Chunk 12003 ---
(except for the 2 situations described below).

4.4.9.3.2 The driver is responsible for respecting the EOA when approaching an EOA with a

4.4.11 STAFF RESPONSIBLE 

--- Document Chunk 12057 ---
4.4.11.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 12058 ---
4.4.11.1.1 The Staff Responsible mode allows the driver to move the train under his own 

--- Document Chunk 12059 ---
responsibility in an ERTMS/ETCS equipped area. 

--- Document Chunk 12060 ---
4.4.11.1.2 This mode is used when the system does not know the route. For example: 

--- Document Chunk 12061 ---
a) After the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment starts-up (awakening of the train). 

--- Document Chunk 12062 ---
b) To pass a signal at danger / override an EOA. 

--- Document Chunk 12063 ---
c) After a trackside failure (for example: loss of radio contact). 

--- Document Chunk 12064 ---
4.4.11.1.3 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall supervise train movements against: 

--- Document Chunk 12065 ---
a) a ceiling speed: the staff responsible mode speed limit  

--- Document Chunk 12066 ---
b) a given distance (regarding its origin location see 4.4.11.1.3.1) . The ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 12067 ---
on-board equipment shall supervise braking curves with a target speed of zero to 

--- Document Chunk 12068 ---
the end of this distance. If the train overpasse s this distance (see next note) the 

--- Document Chunk 12069 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall trip the train 

--- Document Chunk 12070 ---
c) a list of expected balise  groups, if this list has been sent by the RBC. The train 

--- Document Chunk 12071 ---
shall be tripped if over -passing a balise group that is not in the list. (When an 

--- Document Chunk 12072 ---
empty list is sent, no balise group can be passed. When no list is sent, all balise 

--- Document Chunk 12073 ---
groups can be passed) 

--- Document Chunk 12074 ---
d) balise groups giving the order ‘stop if in SR’. This order shall immediately trip the 

--- Document Chunk 12075 ---
train, unless the over -passed balise group is included in a list of expected balises 

--- Document Chunk 12076 ---
as defined in item c) 

--- Document Chunk 12077 ---
e) running in the direction opposite to the train orientation (reverse movement 

--- Document Chunk 12078 ---
protection) 

--- Document Chunk 12079 ---
4.4.11.1.3.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board shall determine the start location of the SR distance 

--- Document Chunk 12080 ---
as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 12081 ---
a) If the National/Default value determin es the max permitted distance to run in SR 

--- Document Chunk 12082 ---
mode, the starting point of this distance shall refer to the estimated position of the 

--- Document Chunk 12083 ---
train front when SR mode was entered, or, already in Staff Responsible mode, 

--- Document Chunk 12084 ---
when Override was activated. 

--- Document Chunk 12085 ---
b) If the max permitted  distance to run in SR mode is determined by the value 

--- Document Chunk 12086 ---
transmitted by the RBC, or entered by the driver, the start location of the distance 

--- Document Chunk 12087 ---
shall refer to the estimated position of the train front when the distance information 

--- Document Chunk 12088 ---
is received or entered. 

--- Document Chunk 12089 ---
c) If th e max permitted distance to run in SR mode is determined by the value 

--- Document Chunk 12090 ---
transmitted by EUROLOOP, the distance information transmitted by EUROLOOP 

--- Document Chunk 12091 ---
shall be referred to one or more reference balise groups. On -board shall evaluate 

--- Document Chunk 12092 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

4.4.12 ON SIGHT 

--- Document Chunk 12183 ---
4.4.12.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 12184 ---
4.4.12.1.1 The On Sight mode enables the train to enter into a track section that could be already 

--- Document Chunk 12185 ---
occupied by another train, or obstructed by any kind of obstacle. 

--- Document Chunk 12186 ---
4.4.12.1.2 On Sight mode cannot be selected by the driver , but shall be entered automatically 

--- Document Chunk 12187 ---
when commanded by trackside and all necessary conditions are fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 12188 ---
4.4.12.1.3 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall supervise train movements against a 

--- Document Chunk 12189 ---
dynamic speed profile. 

--- Document Chunk 12190 ---
4.4.12.1.4 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall display the train speed to the driver (this 

--- Document Chunk 12191 ---
list is not exhaustive). The permitt ed speed, target distance , target speed and release 

--- Document Chunk 12192 ---
speed (if any) shall be displayed only on driver request, until the driver requests to stop 

--- Document Chunk 12193 ---
their display. 

--- Document Chunk 12194 ---
4.4.12.1.5 If receiving a "track ahead free" request from the RBC, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 12195 ---
equipment requests the driver to enter the "track ahead free" information. 

--- Document Chunk 12196 ---
4.4.12.1.6 To be in On Sight mode, SSP and gradient are not required for the whole length of the 

--- Document Chunk 12197 ---
train, but shall be at least available from the FRONT END of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 12198 ---
4.4.12.1.7 Once in On Sight mode, if SSP and gradie nt are not known for the whole length of the 

--- Document Chunk 12199 ---
train, an indication “ENTRY IN ON SIGHT” shall be clearly displayed to the driver until 

--- Document Chunk 12200 ---
SSP and gradient are known for the whole length of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 12201 ---
4.4.12.1.7.1 Note: this indication may also be displayed in case the train  length has been 

--- Document Chunk 12202 ---
increased, see 3.18.3.8. 

--- Document Chunk 12203 ---
4.4.12.1.8 Deleted 

--- Document Chunk 12204 ---
4.4.12.1.9 Note: for the list of main functions related to this mode, refer to chapter  4.5 “Modes 

--- Document Chunk 12205 ---
and on-board functions”. 

--- Document Chunk 12206 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 12207 ---

--- Document Chunk 12208 ---
4.4.12.2.1 Used in level 1, 2 and 3.

--- Document Chunk 12211 ---

4.4.14 POST TRIP 

--- Document Chunk 12262 ---
4.4.14.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 12263 ---
4.4.14.1.1 The Post Trip mode shall be entered immediately after the driver acknowledge s the 

--- Document Chunk 12264 ---
trip. 

--- Document Chunk 12265 ---
4.4.14.1.2 Once in post trip mode, the onboard equipment shall release the Command of the 

--- Document Chunk 12266 ---
emergency brake. 

--- Document Chunk 12267 ---
4.4.14.1.3 The train shall only be authorised to move backwards a given distance (national value). 

--- Document Chunk 12268 ---
The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall supervise this natio nal distance for 

--- Document Chunk 12269 ---
reverse movements, and shall command the service brakes if the distance is over -

--- Document Chunk 12270 ---
passed. The driver shall be informed about the reason for the brake application. 

--- Document Chunk 12271 ---
4.4.14.1.3.1 Note: The ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment performs the Reverse Movement 

--- Document Chunk 12272 ---
Protection (as in PT mode, the "normally allowed movement" is backwards, then the 

--- Document Chunk 12273 ---
Reverse Movement Protection avoids the train running in forward direction when in PT 

--- Document Chunk 12274 ---
mode). This implies that the given distance to run backwards in PT is considered as a 

--- Document Chunk 12275 ---
directional data, oriented backwards. 

--- Document Chunk 12276 ---
4.4.14.1.3.2 After the release of a brake command initiated due to an overpassed distance 

--- Document Chunk 12277 ---
allowed for moving backwards in Post Trip mode, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 12278 ---
equipment shall command the service brake for any further movement in the directi on 

--- Document Chunk 12279 ---
opposite to the train orientation. 

--- Document Chunk 12280 ---
4.4.14.1.4 When moving backwards in Post Trip mode, the train trip shall be inhibited. 

--- Document Chunk 12281 ---
4.4.14.1.5 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 12282 ---
4.4.14.1.6 When ERTMS/ETCS level is 1, if the driver selects “Start” the onboard equipment 

--- Document Chunk 12283 ---
proposes Staff Responsible. When ERTMS/ ETCS level is 2 or 3, the selection of Start 

--- Document Chunk 12284 ---
leads to an MA Request to the RBC. It is the RBC responsibility to give an SR 

--- Document Chunk 12285 ---
authorisation, or a Full Supervision MA or an On Sight /Shunting MA to an 

--- Document Chunk 12286 ---
ERTMS/ETCS equipment that is in Post Trip mode. 

--- Document Chunk 12287 ---
4.4.14.1.7 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 12288 ---
4.4.14.1.8 Note: for the list of main functions related to this mode, refer to chapter  4.5 “Modes 

--- Document Chunk 12289 ---
and on-board functions”. 

--- Document Chunk 12290 ---
4.4.14.1.9 In case of balise group message consistency error (refer to 3.16.2.4.4 and 3.16.2.5.1), 

--- Document Chunk 12291 ---
the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment shall not command the service brake. 

--- Document Chunk 12292 ---
4.4.14.2 Used in levels 

--- Document Chunk 12293 ---
4.4.14.2.1 Used in level 1, 2 and 3.

4.4.15 NON LEADING 

--- Document Chunk 12321 ---
4.4.15.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 12322 ---
4.4.15.1.1 The Non-Leading mode is defined to manage the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 12323 ---
of a slave engine that is NOT electrically coupled to the leading engine (and so, not 

--- Document Chunk 12324 ---
remote controlled) but has its own driver. 

--- Document Chunk 12325 ---
4.4.15.1.1.1 Note: This operating situation is called Tandem. 

--- Document Chunk 12326 ---
4.4.15.1.1.2 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall use, as a necessary condition to 

--- Document Chunk 12327 ---
enter in Non-Leading mode, a “non leading input signal" from the train interface. 

--- Document Chunk 12328 ---
4.4.15.1.1.3 If the “non leading input signal" is no longer present, the switch to Stand -By 

--- Document Chunk 12329 ---
mode shall be made only if the train is at standstill. 

--- Document Chunk 12330 ---
4.4.15.1.2 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall not perform any train movement 

--- Document Chunk 12331 ---
supervision in Non-Leading mode. 

--- Document Chunk 12332 ---
4.4.15.1.3 The ERTMS/ETCS  on-board equipment shall perform the Train Position function; in 

--- Document Chunk 12333 ---
particular, the front/rear end of the engine (i.e., not the train) shall be used to refer to 

--- Document Chunk 12334 ---
train front/rear end. 

--- Document Chunk 12335 ---
4.4.15.1.4 When level is 2 or 3, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall report its po sition to 

--- Document Chunk 12336 ---
the RBC, according to the previously received parameters. 

--- Document Chunk 12337 ---

4.4.18 REVERSING 

--- Document Chunk 12428 ---
4.4.18.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 12429 ---
4.4.18.1.1 The Reversing mode allows the driver to change the direction of movement of the train 

--- Document Chunk 12430 ---
and drive from the same cab, i.e. the train orientation remains unchanged. This shall 

--- Document Chunk 12431 ---
be possible only in areas so marked by trackside. Reversing areas shall be announced 

--- Document Chunk 12432 ---
in advance by trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 12433 ---
4.4.18.1.2 Note: This mode is used to allow the train to esca pe from a dangerous situation and to 

--- Document Chunk 12434 ---
reach as fast as possible a “safer” location. 

--- Document Chunk 12435 ---
4.4.18.1.3 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall supervise train movements against: 

--- Document Chunk 12436 ---
a) a ceiling speed: the Reversing mode speed limit given from trackside 

--- Document Chunk 12437 ---
b) a distance to run in the dire ction opposite to the train orientation , given from 

--- Document Chunk 12438 ---
trackside. The emergency brake shall be commanded if overpassing this distance 

--- Document Chunk 12439 ---
4.4.18.1.4 After the release of a brake command initiated due to an overpassed reversing 

--- Document Chunk 12440 ---
distance, and while the reversing distance is s till overpassed, the ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 12441 ---
board equipment shall command the emergency brake for any further movement in the 

--- Document Chunk 12442 ---
direction opposite to the train orientation. 

--- Document Chunk 12443 ---
4.4.18.1.5 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall display the train speed, the permitted 

--- Document Chunk 12444 ---
speed and the remaining distance to run. 

--- Document Chunk 12445 ---
4.4.18.1.6 In case the SBI supervision limit is exceeded (refer to chapter 3  table 5, triggering 

--- Document Chunk 12446 ---
condition t4), the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall command the emergency 

--- Document Chunk 12447 ---
brake instead of the service brake . For the revocation of the brake  command, refer to 

--- Document Chunk 12448 ---
3.13.10.2.4. 

--- Document Chunk 12449 ---
4.4.18.1.7 The position reports sent when in reversing mode shall refer to the location of the 

--- Document Chunk 12450 ---
driving cab (as before reversing). 

--- Document Chunk 12451 ---
4.4.18.1.8 Note: The ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment performs the Reverse Movement 

--- Document Chunk 12452 ---
Protection (as in RV mode, the "norm ally allowed movement" is backwards, then the 

--- Document Chunk 12453 ---
Reverse Movement Protection avoids the train running in forward direction when in RV 

--- Document Chunk 12454 ---
mode). This implies that the given distance to run in reversing is considered as a 

--- Document Chunk 12455 ---
directional data, oriented backwards. 

--- Document Chunk 12456 ---
4.4.18.1.9 Note: for the list of main functions related to this mode, refer to chapter  4.5 “Modes 

--- Document Chunk 12457 ---
and on-board functions”. 

--- Document Chunk 12458 ---
4.4.18.1.10 In case of balise group message consistency error (refer to 3.16.2.4.4 and 3.16.2.5.1), 

--- Document Chunk 12459 ---
the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment shall not command the service brake. 

--- Document Chunk 12460 ---
4.4.18.1.11 In case there is an alarm reporting a malfunction for the onboard balise transmission 

--- Document Chunk 12461 ---
function, the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment shall ignore this alarm. 

--- Document Chunk 12462 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

4.4.19 LIMITED SUPERVISION 

--- Document Chunk 12493 ---
4.4.19.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 12494 ---
4.4.19.1.1 The Limited Supervision mode enables the train to be op erated in areas where 

--- Document Chunk 12495 ---
trackside information can be supplied to realise background supervision of the train. 

--- Document Chunk 12496 ---
4.4.19.1.2 Limited supervision can not be selected by the driver, but shall be entered 

--- Document Chunk 12497 ---
automatically when commanded by trackside and all necessary conditions are fulfilled. 

--- Document Chunk 12498 ---
4.4.19.1.3 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall supervise train movements against a 

--- Document Chunk 12499 ---
dynamic speed profile. 

--- Document Chunk 12500 ---
4.4.19.1.4 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall display the train speed  and the release 

--- Document Chunk 12501 ---
speed, if any (this list is not exhaustive – refer to chapter 4 .7 “DMI depending on 

--- Document Chunk 12502 ---
modes”). Upon request by trackside (refer to clauses 4.4.19.1.4.2 to 4.4.19.1.4.6) if the 

--- Document Chunk 12503 ---
generic LS function marker is stored on -board or if the conditions in clause 

--- Document Chunk 12504 ---
4.4.19.1.4.7 are fulfilled, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall also display the 

--- Document Chunk 12505 ---
lowest speed amongst: 

--- Document Chunk 12506 ---
a) the lowest MRSP element between the minimum safe front end of the train and the 

--- Document Chunk 12507 ---
EOA/LOA, AND 

--- Document Chunk 12508 ---
b) the target speed at the EOA/LOA 

--- Document Chunk 12509 ---
4.4.19.1.4.1 The speed resulting from 4.4.19.1.4 a) and b) is called the Lowest Supervised 

--- Document Chunk 12510 ---
Speed within the Movement Authority (LSSMA) 

--- Document Chunk 12511 ---
4.4.19.1.4.2 Upon an order to toggle on the LSSMA display, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 12512 ---
equipment shall start a delay timer: 

--- Document Chunk 12513 ---
a) For order received from RBC/RIU: at the value of the time stamp of the message 

--- Document Chunk 12514 ---
including the order. 

--- Document Chunk 12515 ---
b) For order received from balise group: at the time of passage over the first 

--- Document Chunk 12516 ---
encountered balise of the balise group giving the order. 

--- Document Chunk 12517 ---
c) Exception to a) and b): for order that has been stored in the level transition buffer 

--- Document Chunk 12518 ---
(see section 4.8.3): at the time the level transition is performed. 

--- Document Chunk 12519 ---
4.4.19.1.4.3 When the delay timer value becomes greater than the time -out value given by 

--- Document Chunk 12520 ---
trackside, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall display the LSSMA. 

--- Document Chunk 12521 ---
4.4.19.1.4.4 On reception of an order to toggle (on or off) the LSSMA display, a toggle on 

--- Document Chunk 12522 ---
order which has not been executed yet (because the on -board delay timer has not 

--- Document Chunk 12523 ---
reached the delay time-out value) shall be deleted by the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 12524 ---
4.4.19.1.4.5 If the LSSMA display is already toggled on, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 12525 ---
equipment shall toggle off the LSSMA display in case:

4.4.20 PASSIVE SHUNTING 

--- Document Chunk 12593 ---
4.4.20.1 Description 

--- Document Chunk 12594 ---
4.4.20.1.1 The Passive Shunting mode is defined to manage the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 12595 ---
equipment of a slave engine (NOT remote controlled, but mechanically coupled to the 

--- Document Chunk 12596 ---
leading engine), being part of a shunting consist. This mode can also be used to c arry 

--- Document Chunk 12597 ---
on a shunting movement with a s ingle engine fitted with one on -board equipment and 

--- Document Chunk 12598 ---
two cabs, when the driver has to change the driving cab. 

--- Document Chunk 12599 ---
4.4.20.1.2 The desk of a Passive Shunting engine must be closed (since there is no driver, no 

--- Document Chunk 12600 ---
information shall be shown). 

--- Document Chunk 12601 ---
4.4.20.1.3 As the engine is coupled to a leading engine, its ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 12602 ---
shall not perform any train movement supervision. 

--- Document Chunk 12603 ---
4.4.20.1.4 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall perform Train Position function;  in 

--- Document Chunk 12604 ---
particular, the front/rear end of the engine (i.e ., not the train) shall be used to refer to 

--- Document Chunk 12605 ---
train front/rear end. 

--- Document Chunk 12606 ---
4.4.20.1.5 It shall only be possible to enter in Passive Shunting mode from the Shunting mode; 

--- Document Chunk 12607 ---
while in Shunting mode, the driver shall have the possibility to enable the function 

--- Document Chunk 12608 ---
“Continue Shunting on desk closure”. 

--- Document Chunk 12609 ---
4.4.20.1.6 When the active desk is closed, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall switch to 

--- Document Chunk 12610 ---
Passive Shunting mode  if the function “Continue Shunting on desk closure” is active 

--- Document Chunk 12611 ---
and the “passive shunting input signal” is received from the train interfa ce. If the 

--- Document Chunk 12612 ---
function “Continue Shunting on desk closure” is not active or the “passive shunting 

--- Document Chunk 12613 ---
input signal” is not present, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall switch to 

--- Document Chunk 12614 ---
Stand-By mode instead. 

--- Document Chunk 12615 ---
4.4.20.1.7 The special function “Continue Shunting on desk closure” s hall allow one and only one 

--- Document Chunk 12616 ---
transition from Shunting mode to Passive Shunting mode. The special function shall be 

--- Document Chunk 12617 ---
inactive once the Shunting mode is left. 

--- Document Chunk 12618 ---
4.4.20.1.8 If a desk of the Passive Shunting engine is opened  and no “Stop Shunting on desk 

--- Document Chunk 12619 ---
opening” information  previously received from balise group is stored onboard , the 

--- Document Chunk 12620 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall switch to Shunting mode. 

--- Document Chunk 12621 ---
4.4.20.1.9 If a desk of the Passive Shunting engine is opened and “Stop Shunting on desk 

--- Document Chunk 12622 ---
opening” information previously received from balise gr oup is stored onboard, the 

--- Document Chunk 12623 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall switch to Stand By mode. 

--- Document Chunk 12624 ---
4.4.20.1.10 If possible, the train must not be stopped due to a safety critical fault in a Passive 

--- Document Chunk 12625 ---
Shunting engine. The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall therefore try to 

--- Document Chunk 12626 ---
memorise the occurrence of such fault(s), which shall be handled when the engine 

--- Document Chunk 12627 ---
leaves the Passive Shunting mode. 

--- Document Chunk 12628 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 12639 ---

--- Document Chunk 12640 ---

--- Document Chunk 12647 ---
RBC hand-over, except for storing the  RBC ID/phone number information given at the 

--- Document Chunk 12648 ---
RBC/RBC border.

--- Document Chunk 12650 ---
and on-board functions”.

4.4.20.1.15 In case of balise group message consistency error (refer to 3.16.2.4.4 and 3.16.2. 5.1), 

--- Document Chunk 12652 ---
the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment shall not command the service brake. 

--- Document Chunk 12653 ---
4.4.20.2 Used in levels 

--- Document Chunk 12654 ---
4.4.20.2.1 Used in all levels: Level 0, level 1, level 2, level 3 and level NTC 

--- Document Chunk 12655 ---
4.4.20.3 Responsibilities 

--- Document Chunk 12656 ---
4.4.20.3.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment of an engine in Passive Shunting mode has 

--- Document Chunk 12657 ---
no responsibility for the train protection. 

--- Document Chunk 12658 ---
4.4.20.3.2 The notion of responsibility of the driver is not relevant for the Passive Shunting mode. 

--- Document Chunk 12659 ---
4.4.20.3.3 Note: The leading engine is responsible for the movement of the train. It is then the 

--- Document Chunk 12660 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment of the le ading engine that is fully/partially/not 

--- Document Chunk 12661 ---
responsible for the train protection, with respect to its mode.
