--- Document Chunk 12672 ---
4.5 Modes and on-board functions 

--- Document Chunk 12673 ---
4.5.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 12674 ---
4.5.1.1 The following table specifies in which modes the on -board functions are active or not. 

--- Document Chunk 12675 ---
The functions are described in the “Related SRS §” (second column of the table). 

--- Document Chunk 12676 ---
4.5.1.2 Note: Modes are not the only thing that can influence an onboard function. This is why 

--- Document Chunk 12677 ---
this Table is not enough in itself to understand all the ERTMS/ETCS onboard 

--- Document Chunk 12678 ---
behaviour. It must be understood a s a complement to all other SRS chapters 

--- Document Chunk 12679 ---
(especially §4.7, 4.8, 4.9 and 4.10). 

--- Document Chunk 12680 ---
4.5.1.3 Note: for DMI depending on modes, refer to §4.7. 

--- Document Chunk 12681 ---
4.5.2 Active Functions Table 

--- Document Chunk 12682 ---
4.5.2.1 X = functions shall be active 

--- Document Chunk 12683 ---
Empty case = function shall be inactive 

--- Document Chunk 12684 ---
O = Optional (function is not required for interoperability, but is not forbidden)

--- Document Chunk 13170 ---
4.6 Transitions between modes 

--- Document Chunk 13171 ---
4.6.1 Symbols 

--- Document Chunk 13172 ---
4.6.1.1 The indication “4>” means: The condition n°4 must be fulfilled to trigger the transition 

--- Document Chunk 13173 ---
4.6.1.2 From the mode located in the column 

--- Document Chunk 13174 ---
4.6.1.3 To the mode that is indicated by the arrow “>”. 

--- Document Chunk 13175 ---
4.6.1.4 Each transition from a given mode receives a priority order (indicated by “ -px-”, x is the 

--- Document Chunk 13176 ---
priority order) to avoid a conflict between the different transitions when they occur at 

--- Document Chunk 13177 ---
the same time (i.e. in the same clock cycle). P1 has a higher priority than P2. 

--- Document Chunk 13178 ---
4.6.1.5 Some transitions have received the same priority order. This has been decided when it 

--- Document Chunk 13179 ---
is obvious that these transitions cannot occur at the same time, and so can never lead 

--- Document Chunk 13180 ---
to a conflicting situation (for example, the RBC cannot give in the same time a MA for 

--- Document Chunk 13181 ---
FS and a MA for OS to a given engine, this is why the transition “from SR to FS” and 

--- Document Chunk 13182 ---
the transition “from SR to OS” have the same priority order). 

--- Document Chunk 13183 ---
4.6.1.6 "16, 17, 18" means "16 or 17 or 18". 

--- Document Chunk 13184 ---

--- Document Chunk 13782 ---
4.7 DMI depending on modes 

--- Document Chunk 13783 ---
4.7.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 13784 ---
4.7.1.1 The DMI is an interface  that allows the direct exchange of information between the 

--- Document Chunk 13785 ---
driver and the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment. The indirect exchange of information 

--- Document Chunk 13786 ---
done v ia the train interface (e.g. a driver’s action on the service brake used for the 

--- Document Chunk 13787 ---
service brake feedback, opening/closing the desk) is not part of the DMI. 

--- Document Chunk 13788 ---
4.7.1.2 The device(s) used to select “ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment powered/unpowered” 

--- Document Chunk 13789 ---
is (are) not part of the DMI. 

--- Document Chunk 13790 ---
4.7.1.3 The device(s) used to select /indicate “ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment isolated/not 

--- Document Chunk 13791 ---
isolated” is (are) part of the DMI. 

--- Document Chunk 13792 ---
4.7.1.4 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 13793 ---
4.7.1.5 Information (input or output) only relevant for National System and not originated by 

--- Document Chunk 13794 ---
the ERTMS/ETCS on-board is not included in the following section. 

--- Document Chunk 13795 ---
4.7.2 DMI versus Mode Table 

--- Document Chunk 13796 ---
4.7.2.1.1 X = active: For a  DMI output, this means that the output information shall be shown to 

--- Document Chunk 13797 ---
the driver when the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment is in the mode indicated in the 

--- Document Chunk 13798 ---
column. For a DMI input, this means that it shall be possible for the driver to enter this 

--- Document Chunk 13799 ---
information when the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment is in the mode indicated in the 

--- Document Chunk 13800 ---
column). 

--- Document Chunk 13801 ---
4.7.2.1.2 A = available: This means that the input/output shall become active ONLY if another 

--- Document Chunk 13802 ---
condition(s) is (are) fulfilled. This condition(s) are not described here. 

--- Document Chunk 13803 ---
4.7.2.1.3 Grey cells: availability and meaning defined by national system. 

--- Document Chunk 13804 ---
4.7.2.1.4 NA = Not Applicable: This concerns the modes SF and IS in which the DMI inputs and 

--- Document Chunk 13805 ---
outputs cannot be determined.

4.8 Acceptance of received information 

--- Document Chunk 14199 ---
4.8.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 14200 ---
4.8.1.1 The aim of this chapter is to give an overview o f which information is accepted  or 

--- Document Chunk 14201 ---
rejected depending on the state of the on -board (level, mode) and the nature of the 

--- Document Chunk 14202 ---
received information (transmission medium, type of information: infill or non-infill). 

--- Document Chunk 14203 ---
4.8.1.2 The following sections have to be interpreted by applying the filters as shown in Figure 

--- Document Chunk 14204 ---
3. The first filter is detailed in section 4.8.3 “Accepted information depending on the 

--- Document Chunk 14205 ---
level and transmission media”, the third filter in section 4.8.4 “Accepted information 

--- Document Chunk 14206 ---
depending on the modes”. 

--- Document Chunk 14207 ---
4.8.1.3 If a message contains level transition information, any ot her information in that 

--- Document Chunk 14208 ---
message shall be evaluated considering the level transition information. 

--- Document Chunk 14209 ---
4.8.1.3.1 Information received in the same message as an immediate level transition order or a 

--- Document Chunk 14210 ---
conditional level transition order that causes a level transition  shall be evaluated first 

--- Document Chunk 14211 ---
considering the on -board currently operated level, as if a level transition order for 

--- Document Chunk 14212 ---
further location had been received (i.e. conditions [1] , [2] or [6] of Figure 3, if applied, 

--- Document Chunk 14213 ---
shall be automatically fulfilled). Then, if relevant, it sha ll be immediately extracted from 

--- Document Chunk 14214 ---
the buffer and re-evaluated according to the new selected level. 

--- Document Chunk 14215 ---
4.8.1.4 Note: As shown in Figure 3, information stored following an announcement of a 

--- Document Chunk 14216 ---
change of level, is re -checked for acceptance when the level has changed. This 

--- Document Chunk 14217 ---
implies that, when the level changes, the mode is - for a short moment – still 

--- Document Chunk 14218 ---
unchanged, until the stored information has been processed. The consequence for the 

--- Document Chunk 14219 ---
Third Filter is that information needs to be accepted for this short period also in modes 

--- Document Chunk 14220 ---
in which this information is otherwise useless. 

--- Document Chunk 14221 ---
4.8.1.5 If a message contains infill information, this latter shall be evaluated considering all 

--- Document Chunk 14222 ---
other non-infill information in that message. 

--- Document Chunk 14223 ---
4.8.1.6 When evaluating trackside information received by radio or when re -evaluating a set of 

--- Document Chunk 14224 ---
information released from the transition buffer, linking information, if any, shall be 

--- Document Chunk 14225 ---
evaluated prior to any other location related information. 

--- Document Chunk 14226 ---

4.8.2 Assumptions 

--- Document Chunk 14347 ---
4.8.2.1 The following tables shall be applied assuming that: 

--- Document Chunk 14348 ---
a) the information complies with the system version checks (see section 3.17.3) and 

--- Document Chunk 14349 ---
with the data consistency checks.(see section 3.16) 

--- Document Chunk 14350 ---
b) the direction for which the information is valid matches the current train orientation, 

--- Document Chunk 14351 ---
or the balise group crossing direction (for SL , PS  and SH engines).(see section 

--- Document Chunk 14352 ---
3.6.3) 

--- Document Chunk 14353 ---
c) In levels 2/3, it is assumed that the “RBC” information which is marked “A” 

--- Document Chunk 14354 ---
(Accepted) comes from the supervi sing RBC (see RBC/RBC handover). If this 

--- Document Chunk 14355 ---
information is received from the “Accepting” RBC while the “Handing Over” RBC is 

--- Document Chunk 14356 ---
still responsible, it is stored onboard until the RBC transition is performed  

--- Document Chunk 14357 ---
exception1: the information “Acknowledgement of Train Da ta”, “ Trackside 

--- Document Chunk 14358 ---
constituent system version ”, "Initiation of Communication Session" , "Session 

--- Document Chunk 14359 ---
Management" and “Acknowledgement of Session Termination" shall be immediately 

--- Document Chunk 14360 ---
accepted. 

--- Document Chunk 14361 ---
exception2: the information “Co -operative shortening of MA” , “Revocation of  

--- Document Chunk 14362 ---
Emergency Stop” and “LSSMA display toggle on/off order” shall be rejected. 

--- Document Chunk 14363 ---
d) to check exception [4] in 4.8.3, the track description is referred to the LRBG. 

--- Document Chunk 14364 ---
e) the information from balise is received while no reverse movement is performed 

--- Document Chunk 14365 ---
(see clause 3.14.3.6) 

--- Document Chunk 14366 ---
4.8.2.2 Regarding 4.8.2.1 a): In case a balise is missed or a balise telegram cannot be 

--- Document Chunk 14367 ---
decoded, the information “Inhibition of balise group message consistency reaction”  is 

--- Document Chunk 14368 ---
only used by the on -board equipment to inhibit the service brake reaction, while the 

--- Document Chunk 14369 ---
balise group message is rejected. If all the telegrams from a balise group are correctly 

--- Document Chunk 14370 ---
read, the information “ Inhibition of balise group message consistency reaction” , if 

--- Document Chunk 14371 ---
received, shall be ignored by the on -board equipment. Therefore this information need 

--- Document Chunk 14372 ---
not to be referred to in the following tables. 

--- Document Chunk 14373 ---
4.8.2.3 In case a balise telegram contains the information VBC marker and a country/region 

--- Document Chunk 14374 ---
identity that both match a stored VBC, the whole balise telegram is ignored and any 

--- Document Chunk 14375 ---
further check in relation to this balise te legram is irrelevant (refer to 3.15.9. 3 b) ). 

--- Document Chunk 14376 ---
Otherwise the information VBC marker, if included in a consistent balise group 

--- Document Chunk 14377 ---
message, shall always be ignored by the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment and need 

--- Document Chunk 14378 ---
not to be referred to in the following tables. 

--- Document Chunk 14379 ---
4.8.2.4 Note: with the exception of the data that is forwarded to a National System through the 

--- Document Chunk 14380 ---
STM interface (see 3.15.6 and SUBSET -035), what will happen to the data to be used 

--- Document Chunk 14381 ---
by applications outside ERTMS/ETCS  (e.g. whether it is discarded, forwarded to an 

--- Document Chunk 14382 ---
external application, processed by a national function…) is outside the scope of this 

--- Document Chunk 14383 ---
specification and is assumed as not being part of the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 14384 ---
functionality. 

--- Document Chunk 14385 ---

4.8.5 Handling of transition buffer in case of level transition announcement or 

--- Document Chunk 15022 ---
RBC/RBC handover 

--- Document Chunk 15023 ---
4.8.5.1 If an order to switch to level NTC, 1, 2 or 3 at a further location has been received , the 

--- Document Chunk 15024 ---
ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment shall be able to store in a transition buffer (see 

--- Document Chunk 15025 ---
figure 3, first filter) three sets of information obtained from three filtered messages. 

--- Document Chunk 15026 ---
4.8.5.2 If a RBC transition order has been received and the Handing Over RBC is still the 

--- Document Chunk 15027 ---
supervising one, the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment shall be able to store in a 

--- Document Chunk 15028 ---
transition buffer ( see figure 3, second filter) three sets of information obtained from 

--- Document Chunk 15029 ---
three filtered messages from the Accepting RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 15030 ---
4.8.5.2.1 Note: the term “set of information” refers to the part of a message being stored in the 

--- Document Chunk 15031 ---
transition buffer  (i.e. information which is neithe r accepted nor rejected immediately) 

--- Document Chunk 15032 ---
according to the conditions stated in 4.8.3.1 [1] and [2] (for level transition) or 

--- Document Chunk 15033 ---
according to 4.8.2.1c (for RBC/RBC handover). 

--- Document Chunk 15034 ---
4.8.5.3 In case three sets of information are already stored in the transition buffer, any new set 

--- Document Chunk 15035 ---
to be stored shall replace the oldest one currently stored. 

--- Document Chunk 15036 ---
4.8.5.4 The sets of information stored in the transition buffer shall be deleted: 

--- Document Chunk 15037 ---
a) in case the level transition order is deleted or overwritten by another level transition 

--- Document Chunk 15038 ---
order for a different level, OR 

--- Document Chunk 15039 ---
b) in case the RBC transition order is deleted or overwritten by an order to switch to 

--- Document Chunk 15040 ---
another Accepting RBC, OR 

--- Document Chunk 15041 ---
c) in case the communication session with the RBC that provided the stored 

--- Document Chunk 15042 ---
information is terminated 

--- Document Chunk 15043 ---
4.8.5.5 At the same time the level transition is perfor med or at the same time the Accepting 

--- Document Chunk 15044 ---
RBC becomes the supervising one, the sets of information stored in the transition 

--- Document Chunk 15045 ---
buffer shall be released and re-evaluated in the sequence they have been received. 

--- Document Chunk 15046 ---
4.8.5.6 This sequential re -evaluation of all the released inf ormation shall be a prerequisite to 

--- Document Chunk 15047 ---
any use by the on -board equipment (e.g. it will lead neither to an intermediate change 

--- Document Chunk 15048 ---
of mode nor to a change of information displayed to the driver) and shall obey the 

--- Document Chunk 15049 ---
following principles: 

--- Document Chunk 15050 ---
a) Starting from the informatio n currently used by on -board at the moment the 

--- Document Chunk 15051 ---
level/RBC transition is effective, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 15052 ---
determine the new information for train supervision, by performing sequential 

--- Document Chunk 15053 ---
updates from the information released from the transition buffer, if accepted. 

--- Document Chunk 15054 ---
b) For each information update related to a re -evaluated set of information, the same 

--- Document Chunk 15055 ---
rules shall apply as to information update related to new information accepted 

--- Document Chunk 15056 ---
outside a level/RBC transition context. 

--- Document Chunk 15057 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

c) The information resulting from this sequential update shall then be used by the 

--- Document Chunk 15068 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 15069 ---
4.8.5.7 Accepting re -evaluated Conditional Emergency Stop information according to table 

--- Document Chunk 15070 ---
4.8.3 implies that the accepted Conditional Emergency Stop information may be 

--- Document Chunk 15071 ---
accepted or rejec ted in a further step (see clause 3.10.2.2) depending on the given 

--- Document Chunk 15072 ---
stop location. This decision , based on the comparison between the min safe front end 

--- Document Chunk 15073 ---
position of the train at the time the message was received and the given stop location,  

--- Document Chunk 15074 ---
shall be considered part of the evaluation process as it affects the further re -evaluation 

--- Document Chunk 15075 ---
of information stored in the transition buffer (see clause 3.10.2.4). 

--- Document Chunk 15076 ---
4.8.5.7.1 Note: For the case of the Unconditional Emergency Stop information accepting the 

--- Document Chunk 15077 ---
information according to table  4.8.3 will always lead to the train being tripped (see 

--- Document Chunk 15078 ---
clause 3.10.2.3) when re -evaluation of the transition buffer is completed . Information 

--- Document Chunk 15079 ---
accepted during re-evaluation of information stored in the transition buffer can then be 

--- Document Chunk 15080 ---
affected on transition to TR mode according to conditions in Table 4.10. 

--- Document Chunk 15081 ---
4.8.5.8 Note: The requirement to acknowledge an Emergency Stop information according to 

--- Document Chunk 15082 ---
clause 3.10.1.4, i.e., communicating to the RBC if the information has been accepted 

--- Document Chunk 15083 ---
(Conditional or Unconditional Emergency Stop) or rejected because the train has 

--- Document Chunk 15084 ---
passed the stop location (Conditional Emergency Stop only), applies to the time when 

--- Document Chunk 15085 ---
the information is used, immediately after the sequential update has been completed. 

--- Document Chunk 15086 ---
Regards acknowledging the reception of an emergency stop message, as for any 

--- Document Chunk 15087 ---
other information received from trackside, see clause 3.16.3.5.

4.9 What happens to accepted and stored information when 

--- Document Chunk 15099 ---
entering a given level 

--- Document Chunk 15100 ---
4.9.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 15101 ---
4.9.1.1 Every data that can be stored onboard after being accepted may be influenc ed by a 

--- Document Chunk 15102 ---
level transition. 

--- Document Chunk 15103 ---
4.9.1.2 A level transition acts on the “status” of stored information. 

--- Document Chunk 15104 ---
4.9.1.3 In case of entering level 1, MA Request Parameters, Position Report Parameters and 

--- Document Chunk 15105 ---
Track Ahead Free Request shall be deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 15106 ---
4.9.1.3.1 In case of entering level 0, NTC or 1, th e information “Inhibition of revocable TSRs 

--- Document Chunk 15107 ---
from balises in L2/3” shall be deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 15108 ---
4.9.1.4 For all other stored data, a level transition has no effect (void).

4.10 What happens to accepted and stored information when 

--- Document Chunk 15120 ---
entering a given mode 

--- Document Chunk 15121 ---
4.10.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 15122 ---
4.10.1.1 Every data that can be stored onboard after being accepted may be influenced by a 

--- Document Chunk 15123 ---
mode transition. 

--- Document Chunk 15124 ---
4.10.1.2 A mode transition acts on the “status” of stored information. 

--- Document Chunk 15125 ---
4.10.1.3 Depending on which mode is entered, the action shall be one of the following: 

--- Document Chunk 15126 ---
a) data is deleted, 

--- Document Chunk 15127 ---
b) data is to be revalidated, 

--- Document Chunk 15128 ---
c) data is reset (set to default values) 

--- Document Chunk 15129 ---
d) data status is unchanged, 

--- Document Chunk 15130 ---
e) not relevant (the action on the data cannot be determined. This concerns the entry 

--- Document Chunk 15131 ---
in SF and IS modes) 

--- Document Chunk 15132 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 15133 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 15134 ---
D = Deleted TBR = To Be Revalidated U = Unchanged NR = Not relevant R = Reset

--- Document Chunk 15713 ---
5.3 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 15714 ---
5.3.1 Scope and Purpose 

--- Document Chunk 15715 ---
5.3.1.1 This document defines the procedures that are necessary for interoperability with in the 

--- Document Chunk 15716 ---
scope of ERTMS/ETCS. 

--- Document Chunk 15717 ---
5.3.1.2 Each procedure is defined by a set of mandatory requirements and , where convenient, 

--- Document Chunk 15718 ---
is illustrated by a flowchart. 

--- Document Chunk 15719 ---
5.3.1.3 In case the condition(s) in chapter 4 triggering a mode transition is(are) fulfilled, this 

--- Document Chunk 15720 ---
transition shall be executed even if not shown in the chapter 5 procedures. 

--- Document Chunk 15721 ---
5.3.1.3.1 Note: Such a mode transition could lead to exit ing a procedure immediately (e. g. cut 

--- Document Chunk 15722 ---
off power of on-board equipment, isolation of on-board equipment). 

--- Document Chunk 15723 ---
5.3.1.4 National operation rules (outside of ERTMS/ETCS) are also excluded, but may be 

--- Document Chunk 15724 ---
applied by the railways in addition to the procedures as long as interoperability is 

--- Document Chunk 15725 ---
retained. 

--- Document Chunk 15726 ---
5.3.2 Definitions 

--- Document Chunk 15727 ---
5.3.2.1 Procedures 

--- Document Chunk 15728 ---
A procedure defines the required reaction of the ERTMS/ETCS entities (subsystems 

--- Document Chunk 15729 ---
and components) to either i nformation exchanged between ERTMS/ETCS entities or 

--- Document Chunk 15730 ---
events (triggered by external entities or internal events). The procedures focus on the 

--- Document Chunk 15731 ---
required change in status and mode of the described ERTMS/ETCS entities. 

--- Document Chunk 15732 ---
5.3.2.2 Entities 

--- Document Chunk 15733 ---
The procedures define the required  system behaviour on a context level, i. e. the 

--- Document Chunk 15734 ---
entities that are used to define the procedures are for example: the on -board 

--- Document Chunk 15735 ---
equipment, the trackside equipment (RBC/Balise), the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 15736 ---
5.3.2.3 States 

--- Document Chunk 15737 ---
States are situations of an ETCS subsystem with a specific set  of available functions 

--- Document Chunk 15738 ---
and a specific set of events that may start or terminate the state. A state remains 

--- Document Chunk 15739 ---
active as long as the conditions to trigger the transition to a succeeding state are not 

--- Document Chunk 15740 ---
completely satisfied.  

--- Document Chunk 15741 ---
Note 1: one mode of operation may include several states for the on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 15742 ---
Note 2: A new state is only created, if the behaviour of the system differs from another 

--- Document Chunk 15743 ---
one. Possession of information (e. g. location information) or not does not force 

--- Document Chunk 15744 ---
branching in states. 

--- Document Chunk 15745 ---
5.3.2.4 Transitions 

--- Document Chunk 15746 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 15753 ---

--- Document Chunk 15754 ---

--- Document Chunk 15755 ---
Page 9/87 

--- Document Chunk 15756 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 15757 ---
Transitions define the rules for passing from one state to another. A transition is 

--- Document Chunk 15758 ---
triggered by a set of conditions which has to be fulfilled in a defined order or at the 

--- Document Chunk 15759 ---
same time. When a transition refers to a driver’s selection, it means that the conditio ns 

--- Document Chunk 15760 ---
to enable the corresponding button on the DMI were fulfilled.

5.4 Procedure Start of mission 

--- Document Chunk 15773 ---
5.4.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 15774 ---
5.4.1.1 The driver may have to start a mission: 

--- Document Chunk 15775 ---
a) Once the train is awake, OR 

--- Document Chunk 15776 ---
b) Once shunting movements are finished, OR 

--- Document Chunk 15777 ---
c) Once a mission is ended, OR 

--- Document Chunk 15778 ---
d) Once a slave engine becomes a leading engine. 

--- Document Chunk 15779 ---
5.4.1.2 The common point of all these situations is that the ERTMS/ETCS on -board is in 

--- Document Chunk 15780 ---
Stand-By mode, but the Start of Mission will be different, since some data may be 

--- Document Chunk 15781 ---
already stored on-board, depending on the previous situation. 

--- Document Chunk 15782 ---
5.4.1.3 Once the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment is in Stand-By mode, the start of mission 

--- Document Chunk 15783 ---
is not the only possibility, the engine may be come remote controlled (i.e. the on-board 

--- Document Chunk 15784 ---
switches to Sleeping mode). 

--- Document Chunk 15785 ---
5.4.2 Status of data stored in the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 15786 ---
5.4.2.1 At the beginning of the Start of Mission procedure, the data required may be in one of 

--- Document Chunk 15787 ---
three states:  

--- Document Chunk 15788 ---
a) “valid” (the stored value is known to be correct) 

--- Document Chunk 15789 ---
b) “Invalid” (the stored value may be wrong) 

--- Document Chunk 15790 ---
c) “Unknown” (no stored value available) 

--- Document Chunk 15791 ---
5.4.2.2 This refers to the follo wing data: Driver ID, ERTMS/ETCS level, RBC ID/phone 

--- Document Chunk 15792 ---
number, Train Data, Train Running Number, Train Position (see 3.6.1.3). 

--- Document Chunk 15793 ---
5.4.2.3 Note 1:  The status of data in relation to the previous and the actual mode is described 

--- Document Chunk 15794 ---
in chapter 4, section "What happens to stored information when entering a mode". 

--- Document Chunk 15795 ---
5.4.2.4 Note 2: The change of status of data in course of the procedure is shown in the table 

--- Document Chunk 15796 ---
in section 5.4.3.3. 

--- Document Chunk 15797 ---

--- Document Chunk 15799 ---
a flow chart in section 5.4.4.

--- Document Chunk 15817 ---

--- Document Chunk 15818 ---
the driver to revalidate or re-enter the Driver-ID (if the Driver-ID is invalid).

--- Document Chunk 15820 ---

--- Document Chunk 15828 ---

--- Document Chunk 15832 ---
to A31 

--- Document Chunk 15833 ---

--- Document Chunk 15834 ---

--- Document Chunk 15836 ---

--- Document Chunk 15837 ---

--- Document Chunk 15838 ---

5.4.5 Degraded Situations 

--- Document Chunk 16443 ---
5.4.5.1 Nominally, accidental loss of an already open session (that can occur at any step) has 

--- Document Chunk 16444 ---
not been taken into account for the design of the SoM flowchart. However, should such 

--- Document Chunk 16445 ---
a fault occur above D11 the nominal procedure applies (refer to D11 in flowchart). On 

--- Document Chunk 16446 ---
the other hand, if it occurs in any step further than D11, the process shall go to S10. 

--- Document Chunk 16447 ---
5.4.5.2 The SoM flowchart described in section 5.4.3 only includes the main paths and does 

--- Document Chunk 16448 ---
not exhaustively cover the various operational situations, which could occur while 

--- Document Chunk 16449 ---
performing the SoM procedure (e.g. when revised instructions are given to the driver or 

--- Document Chunk 16450 ---
when the driver needs to re-enter already captured data). 

--- Document Chunk 16451 ---
5.4.5.3 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall also offer the driver the following 

--- Document Chunk 16452 ---
possibilities, in addition to the ones that are described in section 5.4.3: 

--- Document Chunk 16453 ---
a) only at S10 and S20 and if valid Train data is available, to select “Override”. If the 

--- Document Chunk 16454 ---
driver chooses to do so, then the process shall go to the procedure “Override” and, 

--- Document Chunk 16455 ---
if the position is still invalid, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board shall delete the train 

--- Document Chunk 16456 ---
position data (new status: “unknown”) 

--- Document Chunk 16457 ---
b) only at S10 and S20, to re-enter the Driver-ID 

--- Document Chunk 16458 ---
c) only at S10 and S20,to re-enter the “Train running number” 

--- Document Chunk 16459 ---
d) only at S20,  to re-enter the Train data . If the driver chooses to do so , then the 

--- Document Chunk 16460 ---
process shall go to S12. 

--- Document Chunk 16461 ---
e) only at S10 and S20, to re -enter the Level. If the dr iver chooses to do so, t hen the 

--- Document Chunk 16462 ---
process shall go to S2 

--- Document Chunk 16463 ---
f) only at S20, to select “Non Leading”. If the driver chooses to do so, then the 

--- Document Chunk 16464 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall immediately switch to Non Leading mode 

--- Document Chunk 16465 ---
and, if the position is still invalid, the ERTM S/ETCS on-board shall delete the train 

--- Document Chunk 16466 ---
position data (new status: “unknown”). 

--- Document Chunk 16467 ---
g) only at S20, to select “Shunting”. If the driver chooses to do so, then the process 

--- Document Chunk 16468 ---
shall go to the procedure “Shunting initiated by driver” and, if the position is still 

--- Document Chunk 16469 ---
invalid, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board shall delete the train position data (new status: 

--- Document Chunk 16470 ---
“unknown”). If, in level 2 or 3, the RBC rejects the request for Shunting, the process 

--- Document Chunk 16471 ---
shall go back to S20. 

--- Document Chunk 16472 ---
h) only at S10, if valid Train Data is available, to select “Start”. If th e driver chooses to 

--- Document Chunk 16473 ---
do so: 

--- Document Chunk 16474 ---
 if the level is 0, then the process shall go to S23. 

--- Document Chunk 16475 ---
 if the level is NTC, then the process shall go to S22. 

--- Document Chunk 16476 ---
 if the level is 1, then the process shall go to S24. 

--- Document Chunk 16477 ---
 if the level is 2/3 and a session is open, then the process shall go to S21. 

--- Document Chunk 16478 ---
 if the level is 2/3 and no session is open, then the process shall go to S24. 

--- Document Chunk 16479 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

5.4.6 Entry to Mode Considered as a Mission 

--- Document Chunk 16492 ---
5.4.6.1 A mission shall be considered as started as soon as the ERTMS/ETCS on-board 

--- Document Chunk 16493 ---
equipment enters FS, LS, SR, OS, NL, UN, or SN mode. 

--- Document Chunk 16494 ---
5.4.6.2 Entry in all other modes, from SB mode, shall not be considered as a mission.

5.5 Procedure End of Mission 

--- Document Chunk 16507 ---
5.5.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 16508 ---
5.5.1.1 End of mission refers to the situation where the trackside stops to authorise the 

--- Document Chunk 16509 ---
movement of a unit. End of mission is initiated by the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 16510 ---
equipment when entering specific modes (see below). 

--- Document Chunk 16511 ---
5.5.2 Entry to Mode Considered as an End of Mission: 

--- Document Chunk 16512 ---
5.5.2.1 Stand-By mode 

--- Document Chunk 16513 ---
5.5.2.1.1 From FS, LS, OS, UN, NL,  SR, PT, RV or SN mode, the entry of the ERT MS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 16514 ---
on-board equipment into the Stand-by mode is considered as an End of Mission 

--- Document Chunk 16515 ---
5.5.2.1.2 Note: While in SN mode (level  NTC), some other conditions to end the mission may 

--- Document Chunk 16516 ---
depend on the National System. 

--- Document Chunk 16517 ---
5.5.2.1.3 The entry of the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment into the S tand-by mode, from PT 

--- Document Chunk 16518 ---
mode, is only considered as an End of Mission if there was an on-going mission. 

--- Document Chunk 16519 ---
5.5.2.2 Sleeping mode 

--- Document Chunk 16520 ---
5.5.2.2.1 The entry of the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment into the Sleeping mode is 

--- Document Chunk 16521 ---
considered as an End of Mission. 

--- Document Chunk 16522 ---
5.5.2.2.1.1 Note: The transition to Sleeping mod e is always made from the Stand -By mode 

--- Document Chunk 16523 ---
(refer to chapter 4, transition between modes). If the end of mission has been already 

--- Document Chunk 16524 ---
executed in Stand-by mode no further end of mission is required. 

--- Document Chunk 16525 ---
5.5.2.3 Shunting mode 

--- Document Chunk 16526 ---
5.5.2.3.1 The entry of the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment into the Shunting mode, from FS, 

--- Document Chunk 16527 ---
LS, OS, SR, SN or UN mode, is considered as an End of Mission. 

--- Document Chunk 16528 ---
5.5.2.3.2 The entry of the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment into the Shunting mode, from PT 

--- Document Chunk 16529 ---
mode, is only considered as an End of Mission if there was an on-going mission. 

--- Document Chunk 16530 ---
5.5.2.3.3 Note: While in SN mode (level  NTC), some other conditions to end the mission may 

--- Document Chunk 16531 ---
depend on the National System. 

--- Document Chunk 16532 ---
5.5.3 End of Mission Procedure 

--- Document Chunk 16533 ---
5.5.3.1 The procedure comprises the following steps 

--- Document Chunk 16534 ---
5.5.3.1.1 Step 1 - MA, Track Description Data and Train Data may be deleted (mode 

--- Document Chunk 16535 ---
dependent, see Chapter 4, section "What happens to accepted and stored information 

--- Document Chunk 16536 ---
when Entering a Mode"). 

--- Document Chunk 16537 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 16538 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 16539 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 16540 ---
SUBSET-026-5 

--- Document Chunk 16541 ---
3.4.0 

--- Document Chunk 16542 ---
12/05/14 

--- Document Chunk 16543 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 16544 ---
Chapter 5 

--- Document Chunk 16545 ---
Procedures 

--- Document Chunk 16546 ---
Page 23/87 

--- Document Chunk 16547 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 16548 ---
End of Procedure, if there is no existing communication session.” 

--- Document Chunk 16549 ---
5.5.3.1.2 If a communication session with an RIU exists: 

--- Document Chunk 16550 ---
Step 2 - The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall terminate the communication 

--- Document Chunk 16551 ---
session 

--- Document Chunk 16552 ---
End of procedure 

--- Document Chunk 16553 ---
5.5.3.1.3 If a communication session with an RBC exists: 

--- Document Chunk 16554 ---
Step 2 - The end of mission shall be reported to the RBC by means of the message 

--- Document Chunk 16555 ---
“End of Mission”. 

--- Document Chunk 16556 ---
Step 3 -  The RBC shall request to terminate the communication session. 

--- Document Chunk 16557 ---
Step 4 - The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall terminate the communication 

--- Document Chunk 16558 ---
session 

--- Document Chunk 16559 ---
End of procedure 

--- Document Chunk 16560 ---
5.5.3.1.3.1 Note: For the termination of the communication session refer to chapter 3, 

--- Document Chunk 16561 ---
Management of Radio Communication. 

--- Document Chunk 16562 ---
5.5.3.1.3.2 Note: The “End of Mission” message contains a position report. 

--- Document Chunk 16563 ---
5.5.3.2 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 16564 ---
5.5.4 Degraded Situation 

--- Document Chunk 16565 ---
5.5.4.1.1 Level 2,3 : In case a communication session is established and no request to terminate 

--- Document Chunk 16566 ---
the communication session is received from the RBC  within a fixed waiting time (see 

--- Document Chunk 16567 ---

5.7 Entry in Shunting with Order from Trackside 

--- Document Chunk 16767 ---
5.7.1 General Requirements 

--- Document Chunk 16768 ---
5.7.1.1 This procedure is used to allow the entry of a train into a shunting area.  

--- Document Chunk 16769 ---
5.7.1.2 Note: The shunting area, pos sibly including a “safety envelope”, can be already 

--- Document Chunk 16770 ---
occupied by shunting units, not controlled by the trackside. It is therefore possible that 

--- Document Chunk 16771 ---
the train shall enter into the shunting area in OS mode. The switch to OS is performed 

--- Document Chunk 16772 ---
according to the relevant procedure.   

--- Document Chunk 16773 ---
5.7.1.3 The order to switch to SH mode shall be given by means of a mode profile, optionally 

--- Document Chunk 16774 ---
with a list of balises  groups, which the train can pass when the ERTMS/ETCS on -

--- Document Chunk 16775 ---
board equipment is in shunting mode. 

--- Document Chunk 16776 ---
5.7.1.4 The switch to shunting, if the transition to shunting was ordered by trackside, requires 

--- Document Chunk 16777 ---
a driver acknowledgement, according to the specifications below. 

--- Document Chunk 16778 ---
5.7.1.5 When the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment has switched to Shunting mode, End of 

--- Document Chunk 16779 ---
Mission, according to chapter 5.5.2.3, is performed. 

--- Document Chunk 16780 ---
5.7.2 Shunting is requested for the current location (from modes different from 

--- Document Chunk 16781 ---
Stand By and Post Trip) 

--- Document Chunk 16782 ---
5.7.2.1 In a level 1 area, or at the border from a level 0 to a level 1 area, the beginning of the 

--- Document Chunk 16783 ---
shunting area can be the location where a balise gro up is installed. In level 2/3 it is 

--- Document Chunk 16784 ---
possible to send an ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment the order to switch to shunting 

--- Document Chunk 16785 ---
at the current location. 

--- Document Chunk 16786 ---
5.7.2.2 Shunting is requested for the current location means that, according to the mode 

--- Document Chunk 16787 ---
profile received the max safe front end of the train is at or in advance of the location for 

--- Document Chunk 16788 ---
which switching to SH mode is requested. 

--- Document Chunk 16789 ---
5.7.2.3 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall switch immediately to SH mode and a 

--- Document Chunk 16790 ---
request for acknowledgement shall be displayed to the driver (refer to SRS cha pter 4, 

--- Document Chunk 16791 ---
transitions between modes). 

--- Document Chunk 16792 ---
5.7.2.4 If the driver does not acknowledge within the driver acknowledgement time (refer to 

--- Document Chunk 16793 ---
Appendix A3.1) after the change to SH mode, the service brake command shall be 

--- Document Chunk 16794 ---
triggered. The command shall be released as soon as the driver acknowledges (unless 

--- Document Chunk 16795 ---
the command was triggered also for other reasons). 

--- Document Chunk 16796 ---
5.7.3 Shunting is requested for a further location 

--- Document Chunk 16797 ---
5.7.3.1 An order to switch to SH at a further location can be sent 

--- Document Chunk 16798 ---
a) in a level 1 area by a balise group, 

--- Document Chunk 16799 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 16800 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 16801 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 16802 ---
SUBSET-026-5 

--- Document Chunk 16803 ---

Page 29/87 

--- Document Chunk 16809 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 16810 ---
b) in a level 2 or 3 area by the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 16811 ---
5.7.3.2 A request for acknowledgement shall be displayed to the driver, when the following two 

--- Document Chunk 16812 ---
conditions are fulfilled: 

--- Document Chunk 16813 ---
a) the distance between the estimated front end of the train and the beginning of 

--- Document Chunk 16814 ---
shunting area is shorter than a value, contained in the mode profile 

--- Document Chunk 16815 ---
b) the speed is lower than the Shunting mode speed limit (National Value, or value 

--- Document Chunk 16816 ---
given in the mode profile) 

--- Document Chunk 16817 ---
5.7.3.3 Once the request for acknowledgement is displayed, it shall not be taken back, even if 

--- Document Chunk 16818 ---
the above conditions are no more fulfilled (e.g., the train accelerates). 

--- Document Chunk 16819 ---
5.7.3.4 Until the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment has switched to SH mode , according to 

--- Document Chunk 16820 ---
the mode profile, the beginning of the shunting area shall be considered either as the 

--- Document Chunk 16821 ---
EOA (keeping the SvL given by the MA) or as both the EOA and SvL (instead of the 

--- Document Chunk 16822 ---
EOA and SvL given by the MA), with no release speed. 

--- Document Chunk 16823 ---
5.7.3.5 When the driver acknowledges, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 16824 ---
immediately switch to SH mode (refer to chapter 4, transitions between modes). 

--- Document Chunk 16825 ---
5.7.3.6 If the max safe front end of the train reaches th e beginning of the shunting area 

--- Document Chunk 16826 ---
according the mode profile and the driver has not yet acknowledged, the 

--- Document Chunk 16827 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall switch immediately to SH mode and a 

--- Document Chunk 16828 ---
request for acknowledgement shall be displayed to the driver (refer to SRS chap ter 4, 

--- Document Chunk 16829 ---
transitions between modes). 

--- Document Chunk 16830 ---
5.7.3.7 If, in this case, the driver does not acknowledge within the driver acknowledgement 

--- Document Chunk 16831 ---
time (refer to Appendix A3.1) after the change to SH mode, the service brake 

--- Document Chunk 16832 ---
command shall be triggered. The command shall be released as  soon as the driver 

--- Document Chunk 16833 ---
acknowledges (unless the command was triggered also for other reasons). 

--- Document Chunk 16834 ---
5.7.4 Shunting from Stand By or Post Trip mode 

--- Document Chunk 16835 ---
5.7.4.1 When performing a SoM or a Train Trip procedure and when the current level is 2 or 3, 

--- Document Chunk 16836 ---

--- Document Chunk 16837 ---
area which the train has already entered with its max safe front end. In this case, the 

--- Document Chunk 16838 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall first require an acknowledgement from the 

--- Document Chunk 16839 ---
driver. 

--- Document Chunk 16840 ---
5.7.4.2 When the driver acknowledges, the ERTMS /ETCS on-board equipment shall perfo rm 

--- Document Chunk 16841 ---
transition to Shunting mode.

--- Document Chunk 16911 ---
5.8 Procedure Override 

--- Document Chunk 16912 ---
5.8.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 16913 ---
5.8.1.1 In specific degraded situations (for example in the case of a failed signal, failed track 

--- Document Chunk 16914 ---
circuit, failed point…), railways allow a train to pass its EOA.  

--- Document Chunk 16915 ---
5.8.1.2 For ERTMS/ETCS, passing an EOA can be required in degraded situations, e.g. 

--- Document Chunk 16916 ---
 In level 2/3, if a train is stopped without MA in a location where radio is unavailable 

--- Document Chunk 16917 ---
(e.g. after having received an emergency message, or after a train trip). 

--- Document Chunk 16918 ---
 In level 2/3, if a train is stopped at the border between two adjacent RBCs (e.g. the 

--- Document Chunk 16919 ---
interface between RBCs is unavailable). 

--- Document Chunk 16920 ---
 In level 2/3 , if a train is stopped after having passed the border between two 

--- Document Chunk 16921 ---
adjacent RBCs (e.g. the connection to the Accepting RBC cannot be established). 

--- Document Chunk 16922 ---
 In level 2/3, if the RBC is unable to give a permission to run (e.g. lost connection 

--- Document Chunk 16923 ---
with the interlocking) 

--- Document Chunk 16924 ---
 In level 1, if a signal cannot show a proceed aspect (e.g., signal failure, route 

--- Document Chunk 16925 ---
cannot be set) 

--- Document Chunk 16926 ---
 In level 1, if a train is stopped without MA (e.g. after the MA has been shortened 

--- Document Chunk 16927 ---
due to a time-out). 

--- Document Chunk 16928 ---
5.8.1.3 In level 0 /NTC areas, passing a signal at danger is only a national procedure. The 

--- Document Chunk 16929 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment is not involved in this procedure, since it does not 

--- Document Chunk 16930 ---
supervise the train movements. 

--- Document Chunk 16931 ---
5.8.1.4 In ERTMS equipped areas (level 1, 2 or 3), locations where the train shall stop are 

--- Document Chunk 16932 ---
supervised by the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment. Receiving an order from the 

--- Document Chunk 16933 ---
signalman to pass the EOA, the driver must then be able to inhibit this supervision. 

--- Document Chunk 16934 ---
5.8.1.4.1 Note: The driver must not use the “Override” procedure unless authorised by trackside 

--- Document Chunk 16935 ---
personnel. This authorisation is covered by operational procedures. 

--- Document Chunk 16936 ---
5.8.1.5 If an EOA must be passed between announcement and execution of the level 

--- Document Chunk 16937 ---
transition from an unfitted area (level 0) or from an area fitted with a National System 

--- Document Chunk 16938 ---
(level NTC) to an ERTMS equipped area (level 1, 2, 3), the signalm an gives the order 

--- Document Chunk 16939 ---
to the driver to select “override”. 

--- Document Chunk 16940 ---
5.8.1.6 Note: Passing the EOA by using this procedure the driver is fully responsible for the 

--- Document Chunk 16941 ---
train driving. Therefore Staff Responsible mode is entered when the driver selects 

--- Document Chunk 16942 ---
“override”. 

--- Document Chunk 16943 ---
5.8.1.7 In addition the procedure allows to avoid a train trip when passing a balise group:  

--- Document Chunk 16944 ---
a) transmitting "stop in SR mode" 

--- Document Chunk 16945 ---
b) not contained in the list of expected balises in SR mode 

--- Document Chunk 16946 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 16947 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 16948 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 16949 ---
SUBSET-026-5 

--- Document Chunk 16950 ---
3.4.0 

--- Document Chunk 16951 ---
12/05/14 

--- Document Chunk 16952 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 16953 ---
Chapter 5 

--- Document Chunk 16954 ---
Procedures 

--- Document Chunk 16955 ---
Page 32/87 

--- Document Chunk 16956 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 16957 ---
c) transmitting "stop in SH mode" 

--- Document Chunk 16958 ---
d) not contained in the list of expected balises in SH mode" 

--- Document Chunk 16959 ---
e) Intentionally deleted 

--- Document Chunk 16960 ---
5.8.1.8 Further, the Override procedure allows a train in SR mode reaching the end of the SR 

--- Document Chunk 16961 ---
distance to proceed (see also 4.4.11.1.4) 

--- Document Chunk 16962 ---
5.8.2 Selection of “Override” 

--- Document Chunk 16963 ---
5.8.2.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall allow the driver to select “Override” (i.e. 

--- Document Chunk 16964 ---
the “Override” button becomes available) only when: 

--- Document Chunk 16965 ---
a) The train speed is under or equal to the speed limit for triggering the “override” 

--- Document Chunk 16966 ---
function (national value) AND 

--- Document Chunk 16967 ---
b) The current mode is Full Supervision, Limited Supervision, On Sight, Staff 

--- Document Chunk 16968 ---
Responsible, Shunting, Unfitt ed, Post Trip, Stand By (in level 2/3 only)  or S N 

--- Document Chunk 16969 ---
(National System) AND 

--- Document Chunk 16970 ---
c) Validated Train Data is available (except when already in Shunting mode). 

--- Document Chunk 16971 ---
5.8.2.2 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 16972 ---
5.8.2.3 The “Override” procedure shall be triggered when selected by the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 16973 ---
5.8.3 Once the “Override” procedure has been triggered 

--- Document Chunk 16974 ---
5.8.3.1 The mode shall change as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 16975 ---
a) If the current mode is Full Supervision, Limited Supervision, On Sight, Stand -By or 

--- Document Chunk 16976 ---
Post Trip, the mode shall immediately switch to the Staff Responsible (SR) mode (if 

--- Document Chunk 16977 ---
the mode is already SR it remains unchanged) 

--- Document Chunk 16978 ---
b) If the current mode is Shunting the mode shall remain unchanged 

--- Document Chunk 16979 ---
c) If the current mode is Unfitted (level 0 area) or S N (level NTC area) the mode shall 

--- Document Chunk 16980 ---
only change to Staff Responsible when the level changes to 1,2 or 3 (refer to SRS  

--- Document Chunk 16981 ---
chapter 4, transitions between modes) 

--- Document Chunk 16982 ---
5.8.3.1.1 If the mode, when activating Override, is OS , LS  or FS, the former EOA shall be 

--- Document Chunk 16983 ---
retained. If the mode is SB or PT, the current position of the train front shall be 

--- Document Chunk 16984 ---
considered as the former EOA. 

--- Document Chunk 16985 ---
5.8.3.1.2 Note: This former EOA will be used as a Trip condition if the Override function is no 

--- Document Chunk 16986 ---
longer active. Any further activation of the Override in SR mode has no effect on the 

--- Document Chunk 16987 ---
former EOA. 

--- Document Chunk 16988 ---
5.8.3.1.3 The former EOA shall be deleted if: 

--- Document Chunk 16989 ---
a) the train reads the information “stop in SR mode” from a balise group OR 

--- Document Chunk 16990 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 17014 ---

--- Document Chunk 17015 ---
Restriction (see 3.11.10) as long as the Override function is active.

--- Document Chunk 17017 ---
5.8.3.8 As long as the Override function is active, new SR distance information received from 

--- Document Chunk 17018 ---
EUROLOOP shall be rejected. 

--- Document Chunk 17019 ---
5.8.3.9 When “Override” is selected and Override is already active, the supervision of the time 

--- Document Chunk 17020 ---
and distance (see 5.8.4.1 a) and b)) for train trip suppression shall be re-started. 

--- Document Chunk 17021 ---

--- Document Chunk 17022 ---

--- Document Chunk 17023 ---

--- Document Chunk 17024 ---

--- Document Chunk 17025 ---
(national value) elapses after Override has been selected, OR 

--- Document Chunk 17026 ---

--- Document Chunk 17027 ---
function is triggered" (national value) after Override has been selected, OR 

--- Document Chunk 17028 ---

--- Document Chunk 17029 ---
by subtracting distance between active EUROBALISE antenna and the front end of 

--- Document Chunk 17030 ---
the train from the min safe front end position), OR 

--- Document Chunk 17031 ---
d) The train passes a balise group giving “stop in SR” or “stop in SH” information, OR 

--- Document Chunk 17032 ---
e) The train passes a balise group giving proceed information (i.e., MA with no 

--- Document Chunk 17033 ---
signalling related speed restriction of value zero) 

--- Document Chunk 17034 ---
f) In level 2,3, an MA is received from the RBC

5.9 Procedure On-Sight 

--- Document Chunk 17067 ---
5.9.1 General Requirements 

--- Document Chunk 17068 ---
5.9.1.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall be in On Sight mode before the train 

--- Document Chunk 17069 ---
reaches the beginning of the On Sight area or, at the latest, when the train reaches the 

--- Document Chunk 17070 ---
beginning of the On Sight area. 

--- Document Chunk 17071 ---
5.9.1.2 An acknowledgement for running in On Sight mode shall be requested from the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 17072 ---
The conditions of the acknowledgement are specified below. 

--- Document Chunk 17073 ---
5.9.2 On Sight is requested for current location (from modes different from 

--- Document Chunk 17074 ---
Stand By and Post Trip) 

--- Document Chunk 17075 ---
5.9.2.1 In a level 1 area, the beginning of the On Sight area can be the balise (group) that 

--- Document Chunk 17076 ---
gives the Mode Profile. When the train passes the balise group and receives this 

--- Document Chunk 17077 ---
information, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall immediately switch to On 

--- Document Chunk 17078 ---
Sight mode. 

--- Document Chunk 17079 ---
5.9.2.2 In a level 2 or 3 area, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment can receive a mode 

--- Document Chunk 17080 ---
profile giving an On Sight area which the train has already entered with its max safe 

--- Document Chunk 17081 ---
front end. In this case, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall immediately switch 

--- Document Chunk 17082 ---
to On Sight mode. 

--- Document Chunk 17083 ---
5.9.2.3 The driver must acknowledge the On Sight mode. A request of acknowledgement shall 

--- Document Chunk 17084 ---
be displayed to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 17085 ---
5.9.2.4 If the driver has not acknowledged after the driver acknowle dgement time (refer to 

--- Document Chunk 17086 ---
Appendix A3.1), the service brake command shall be triggered. The brake command is 

--- Document Chunk 17087 ---
released when the driver acknowledges, except if brakes are also applied for another 

--- Document Chunk 17088 ---
reason(s). 

--- Document Chunk 17089 ---
5.9.2.5 Note: Once in On Sight mode, the speed supervision is such that the train speed 

--- Document Chunk 17090 ---
cannot exceed the OS mode speed limit. If, when entering the On Sight mode, the 

--- Document Chunk 17091 ---
train speed was higher than the OS mode speed limit (because a higher speed was 

--- Document Chunk 17092 ---
allowed in Full Supervision mode, in Limited Supervision mode  or in Staff Responsible 

--- Document Chunk 17093 ---
mode) then a service/emergency brake command could be immediately triggered, 

--- Document Chunk 17094 ---
independently of the acknowledgement of the driver, but because of the On Sight 

--- Document Chunk 17095 ---
supervision (see Figure 4). 

--- Document Chunk 17096 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

5.9.3 On Sight is requested for a further location 

--- Document Chunk 17133 ---

--- Document Chunk 17134 ---
yet. This occurs when: 

--- Document Chunk 17135 ---
a) In a level 1 area, a balise group gives a Mode Profile w ith an On Sight area that is 

--- Document Chunk 17136 ---
located at a further location. 

--- Document Chunk 17137 ---
b) In a level 2 or 3 area, the RBC gives a Mode Profile with an On Sight area that is 

--- Document Chunk 17138 ---
located at a further location. 

--- Document Chunk 17139 ---
5.9.3.2 A request for acknowledgement shall be displayed to the driver when the following 

--- Document Chunk 17140 ---
conditions are fulfilled: 

--- Document Chunk 17141 ---
a)  The distance between the estimated front end of the train and the beginning of On 

--- Document Chunk 17142 ---
Sight area is shorter than a value, contained in the mode profile.   

--- Document Chunk 17143 ---
b) The speed is lower than the On Sight mode speed limit (national value, or valu e 

--- Document Chunk 17144 ---
given in the mode profile). 

--- Document Chunk 17145 ---
c) The current mode is not On Sight 

--- Document Chunk 17146 ---
5.9.3.3 Note: The first 2 conditions define the “rectangle of acknowledgement”.  

--- Document Chunk 17147 ---
5.9.3.4 Once the acknowledgement request is displayed, it is not taken back if the train leaves 

--- Document Chunk 17148 ---
the “rectangle of acknowledgement” (for example: because the train accelerates).

5.9.5 On Sight from Stand By or Post Trip mode

5.9.6 Exit of On Sight mode 

--- Document Chunk 17222 ---
5.9.6.1 General rule 

--- Document Chunk 17223 ---
5.9.6.1.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment exits the On Sight mode when the min safe 

--- Document Chunk 17224 ---
front end of the train passes the end of the On Sight area. 

--- Document Chunk 17225 ---
5.9.6.2 First case: The On Sight area ends at the EOA of the current MA 

--- Document Chunk 17226 ---
5.9.6.2.1 This occurs when the end of the On Sight area that is given by the Mode Profile has 

--- Document Chunk 17227 ---
the same location as the EOA of the related MA. 

--- Document Chunk 17228 ---
5.9.6.2.2 In this case, the train must receive a new Movement Authority to be able to exit the On 

--- Document Chunk 17229 ---
Sight area. 

--- Document Chunk 17230 ---
5.9.6.2.3 Note: In an On Sight area there is no guarantee for the RBC that the track in front of 

--- Document Chunk 17231 ---
the supervised train is free. Therefore, if the next block section is free, t he RBC has 

--- Document Chunk 17232 ---
nevertheless to ensure that there is no train/vehicle between the train and the end of 

--- Document Chunk 17233 ---
the On Sight area. This information  

--- Document Chunk 17234 ---
 can be given to the RBC by the signalman or any other trackside means  (outside 

--- Document Chunk 17235 ---
scope of  ERTMS/ETCS), or 

--- Document Chunk 17236 ---
 can be inquired by the RBC by means of the following mechanism: the RBC sends 

--- Document Chunk 17237 ---
a “track ahead free” request which the ERTMS/ ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 17238 ---
displays to the driver. If the driver confirms that the track is free up to the end of the 

--- Document Chunk 17239 ---
current section, the ERTMS/ ETCS on-board equipment will transmit this 

--- Document Chunk 17240 ---
information to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 17241 ---
5.9.6.2.4 Note: Receiving the “track ahead free” information, the RBC may be able to transmit 

--- Document Chunk 17242 ---
an MA from the current position of the train, e.g., for Full Supervision (refer to SRS 

--- Document Chunk 17243 ---
chapter 4, transitions between modes). 

--- Document Chunk 17244 ---
5.9.6.3 Second case: The On Sight area ends before the EOA of the current MA 

--- Document Chunk 17245 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

5.10 Level Transitions 

--- Document Chunk 17317 ---
5.10.1 General requirements 

--- Document Chunk 17318 ---
5.10.1.1 Every level transition border to levels 2, 3, or NTC shall be announced to the 

--- Document Chunk 17319 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment via balise group or via the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 17320 ---
5.10.1.2 A level transition announcement to the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 17321 ---
consist of an order to execute the level transition at a further location corresponding to 

--- Document Chunk 17322 ---
the border. 

--- Document Chunk 17323 ---
5.10.1.3 When the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment receives a level transition 

--- Document Chunk 17324 ---
announcement, and if this announcement will result in a change of the on -board level, 

--- Document Chunk 17325 ---
it shall immediately inform the driver about the announced level transition. 

--- Document Chunk 17326 ---
5.10.1.3.1 Note: In a mixed level area the actual level of the on -board equipment may remain 

--- Document Chunk 17327 ---
unchanged even though a level transition boundary is passed. 

--- Document Chunk 17328 ---
5.10.1.4 At the level transition border a balise group shall be placed with an immediate level 

--- Document Chunk 17329 ---
transition order or a conditional level transition order. 

--- Document Chunk 17330 ---
5.10.1.4.1 Note: Balise groups are read in all levels and level transition orders and conditional 

--- Document Chunk 17331 ---
level transition orders from balises are accepted independent of the level of operation. 

--- Document Chunk 17332 ---
Also sleeping units read balise groups. 

--- Document Chunk 17333 ---

--- Document Chunk 17346 ---

5.10.1.6 The on -board equipment shall manage only one level transition order at a time. 

--- Document Chunk 17349 ---

--- Document Chunk 17350 ---
new order to switch to a different level or to the same level but at a different location is 

--- Document Chunk 17351 ---
received, before the action from the first order has been performed, only the last order 

--- Document Chunk 17352 ---
shall be executed.

5.10.1.6.1 In Shunting and Passive Shunting modes only one set of Level Transition Information 

--- Document Chunk 17365 ---
shall be stored at a time. Therefore a set of Level Transition Information received shall 

--- Document Chunk 17366 ---
replace any Level Transition Information already stored on-board. 

--- Document Chunk 17367 ---
5.10.1.7 As soon as the announcement of the level transition has been received, some data 

--- Document Chunk 17368 ---
(mainly movement authority and track description data) from the transmission media of 

--- Document Chunk 17369 ---
the new level shall be accepted, but shall not be used until the level transition is 

--- Document Chunk 17370 ---
effective. 

--- Document Chunk 17371 ---
5.10.1.7.1 Note: for the exhaustive list of accepted/rejected information, please refer to S RS 

--- Document Chunk 17372 ---
chapter 4.8. 

--- Document Chunk 17373 ---
5.10.1.7.2 Note: if only track description has been received from the new media without any 

--- Document Chunk 17374 ---
movement authority, this track description still replaces the one previously received 

--- Document Chunk 17375 ---
from the current media when the transition is performed. 

--- Document Chunk 17376 ---
5.10.1.8 When the onboard has performed the level transition, further data (mainly movement 

--- Document Chunk 17377 ---
authority and track description data) received from the transmission media of the level 

--- Document Chunk 17378 ---
being left shall be rejected.  

--- Document Chunk 17379 ---
5.10.1.8.1 Note: for the exhaustive list of accepted/rejected information, please  refer to SRS 

--- Document Chunk 17380 ---
chapter 4.8.

5.10.2 Table of priority of trackside supported levels 

--- Document Chunk 17383 ---
5.10.2.1 Any combination of ERTMS/ETCS levels 0, NTC, 1, 2, and 3 on a given area shall be 

--- Document Chunk 17384 ---
possible. 

--- Document Chunk 17385 ---
5.10.2.2 The level transition announcement and the immediate or conditional  level transition 

--- Document Chunk 17386 ---
order at the border shall contain all the supported ERTMS/ETCS levels with a table of 

--- Document Chunk 17387 ---
priority. Even if only one level is permitted this is considered as a table of priority. 

--- Document Chunk 17388 ---
5.10.2.2.1 Note: Level 0 is considered in the same way as the other levels . This means that, for 

--- Document Chunk 17389 ---
example, when an area permits ERTMS/ETCS level 0, and is fitted with ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 17390 ---
level 1 and 2, the track-side includes levels 0, 1 and 2 in a table of priority of supported 

--- Document Chunk 17391 ---
levels in all level transition orders and conditional level transition orders applying to that 

--- Document Chunk 17392 ---
area. 

--- Document Chunk 17393 ---
5.10.2.3 The table of priority shall list all the supported levels from the highest priority level to 

--- Document Chunk 17394 ---
the lowest one. 

--- Document Chunk 17395 ---
5.10.2.3.1 Intentionally deleted. 

--- Document Chunk 17396 ---
5.10.2.4 When receiving the information about all ERTMS/ETCS levels that are supported by 

--- Document Chunk 17397 ---
trackside, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall select from the table the level 

--- Document Chunk 17398 ---
with the highest priority, which is available for use by the onboard equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 17399 ---

--- Document Chunk 17410 ---
5.10.2.4.1 The on-board equipment shall consider an ERTMS/ETCS level as “Available for use” 

--- Document Chunk 17411 ---
as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 17412 ---
a) Level 2 or 3: the level is configured on -board and at least one Mobile Terminal is 

--- Document Chunk 17413 ---
available on -board, i.e. the ETCS onboard has detected at least one Mobile 

--- Document Chunk 17414 ---
Terminal in working condition, independently whether it is registered to a network or 

--- Document Chunk 17415 ---
not. 

--- Document Chunk 17416 ---
b) Level NTC: the concerned National System  is available on -board ( if an STM is 

--- Document Chunk 17417 ---
used, refer to SUBSET-035 for further details). 

--- Document Chunk 17418 ---
c) Level 0 or 1: always. 

--- Document Chunk 17419 ---
5.10.2.4.1.1 Note regarding a) and b): how the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment checks the 

--- Document Chunk 17420 ---
availability of the Mobile Terminals or of the National System (in case no STM is used) 

--- Document Chunk 17421 ---
is an implementation issue. 

--- Document Chunk 17422 ---
5.10.2.4.2 Examples: The table of trackside supported levels gives 2, NTC X, 1, NTC Y. If level 1, 

--- Document Chunk 17423 ---
0 and NTC X are “Available for use”, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board will select NTC X 

--- Document Chunk 17424 ---
level. If level 1, 0 and NTC Y are “Available for use”, it will select level 1. If level 2 , 1 

--- Document Chunk 17425 ---
and 0 are “Available for use”, it will select level 2. 

--- Document Chunk 17426 ---
5.10.2.5 When the onboard has selected the level it will switch to, it shall carry out the level 

--- Document Chunk 17427 ---
transition as if it has received a level transition order to this level only i.e. it shall ignore 

--- Document Chunk 17428 ---
the requirements related to transitions to the other levels. 

--- Document Chunk 17429 ---
5.10.2.6 The ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment shall inform the driver about the selected level 

--- Document Chunk 17430 ---
transition only. 

--- Document Chunk 17431 ---
5.10.2.7 If none of the ordered level(s) is available for use by the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 17432 ---
equipment, it shall nevertheless make the transition, to the ordered level with the 

--- Document Chunk 17433 ---
lowest priority. 

--- Document Chunk 17434 ---
5.10.2.7.1 Justification: The On -board equipment will then indicate the trackside level to the 

--- Document Chunk 17435 ---
driver to allow him to select the correct procedures for degraded situations. 

--- Document Chunk 17436 ---
5.10.2.8 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall store the table of priority of trackside 

--- Document Chunk 17437 ---
supported ERTMS/ETCS levels.

5.10.3.14 Conditional level transition order 

--- Document Chunk 17654 ---
5.10.3.14.1 When the ERTMS /ETCS on -board equipment accepts a conditional level transition 

--- Document Chunk 17655 ---
order the onboard shall check whether the current level is contained in the priority list 

--- Document Chunk 17656 ---
of the conditional level transition order. 

--- Document Chunk 17657 ---
5.10.3.14.2 If the current level is contained in the priority list of the conditional level transition order, 

--- Document Chunk 17658 ---
the onboard shall not change the level. 

--- Document Chunk 17659 ---
5.10.3.14.3 If the current level is not contained in the priority list of the conditional level transition 

--- Document Chunk 17660 ---
order, the onboard shall evaluate the conditional level transition order in the sa me way 

--- Document Chunk 17661 ---
as an immediate level transition order (see section 5.10.2). 

--- Document Chunk 17662 ---
5.10.3.14.4 In the same way as for a level transition order, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 17663 ---
shall store the table of ERTMS/ETCS levels supported by trackside. 

--- Document Chunk 17664 ---
5.10.3.14.5 Note: The conditional level transition order allows to check, whether a train operates in 

--- Document Chunk 17665 ---
a permitted level e.g. following a start of mission after a cold movement. The level of a 

--- Document Chunk 17666 ---
train driving in a permitted level will not be changed, regardless of the priority of the 

--- Document Chunk 17667 ---
current level operated by the train.  

--- Document Chunk 17668 ---

5.11.4 Degraded Situations 

--- Document Chunk 17988 ---
5.11.4.1 ERTMS/ETCS level 2 or 3: no acknowledge for PT mode is received from the RBC 

--- Document Chunk 17989 ---
5.11.4.1.1 In case a communication session is established and no reply is received from the RBC 

--- Document Chunk 17990 ---
within a fixed waiting time (see appendix to chapter 3, List of Fixed Value Data) after 

--- Document Chunk 17991 ---
reporting the mode change,  the report shall be repeated with the fixed waiting time 

--- Document Chunk 17992 ---
after each repetition. 

--- Document Chunk 17993 ---
5.11.4.1.2 After a defined number of repetitions(see appendix to chapter 3, List of Fixed Value 

--- Document Chunk 17994 ---
Data) and if no reply is received within the fixed waiting time from the last sending of 

--- Document Chunk 17995 ---
the mode change report,  the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment shall terminate the 

--- Document Chunk 17996 ---
communication session. 

--- Document Chunk 17997 ---
5.11.4.2 Nominally, accidental loss of an already open session (that can occur at any step) has 

--- Document Chunk 17998 ---
not been taken into account for the design of the flowchart. However, should such a 

--- Document Chunk 17999 ---
fault occur in any step while ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment is in leve l 2/3 and in 

--- Document Chunk 18000 ---
PT mode, the driver shall have the possibility to select "Override" and the process shall 

--- Document Chunk 18001 ---
go to the procedure "Override " 

--- Document Chunk 18002 ---

--- Document Chunk 18013 ---
5.12 Change of Train Orientation 

--- Document Chunk 18014 ---
5.12.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 18015 ---
5.12.1.1 The scope of this procedure is the supervision of a train where the driver cont rols the 

--- Document Chunk 18016 ---
train from the cab in the front of the train with the direction controller in FORWARD 

--- Document Chunk 18017 ---
position. 

--- Document Chunk 18018 ---
5.12.1.2 This implies that when the driver has to change the orientation of the train, he has to 

--- Document Chunk 18019 ---
change the driving cab. 

--- Document Chunk 18020 ---
5.12.1.3 The scope of this procedure is NOT shun ting movements, during which the driver 

--- Document Chunk 18021 ---
changes the running direction of the train without leaving the cab, by changing the 

--- Document Chunk 18022 ---
position of the direction controller from FORWARD to REVERSE. 

--- Document Chunk 18023 ---
5.12.1.4 The scope of this procedure is NOT the backwards movement that is allo wed in Post 

--- Document Chunk 18024 ---
Trip or in Reversing mode. 

--- Document Chunk 18025 ---
5.12.2 The driver uses the same engine (a mission is on-going) 

--- Document Chunk 18026 ---
5.12.2.1 The situation is the following: The driver closes the desk A and leaves the cab A of the 

--- Document Chunk 18027 ---
leading engine of the train, to go to cab B and open desk B of this same engine. 

--- Document Chunk 18028 ---
5.12.2.2 Desk A and desk B are connected to the same ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 18029 ---
5.12.2.3 When the driver closes the desk A, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 18030 ---
immediately go to Stand-By mode, which is considered as an end of mission (see “End 

--- Document Chunk 18031 ---
of Mission” procedure) 

--- Document Chunk 18032 ---
5.12.2.4 When the driver opens the desk B, the “Start of Mission” procedure is triggered. 

--- Document Chunk 18033 ---
5.12.2.5 When the driver closes a desk and opens the other one of the same engine, the 

--- Document Chunk 18034 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall be able to calculate the new train position 

--- Document Chunk 18035 ---
data (train front position, train orientation), by use of the previous data. 

--- Document Chunk 18036 ---
5.12.3 The driver leaves the engine to go to another one 

--- Document Chunk 18037 ---
5.12.3.1 The described situation is the following : The train has two engines (engine A and 

--- Document Chunk 18038 ---
engine B). The engine A is the leading engine. The eng ine B is a slave engine. Each 

--- Document Chunk 18039 ---
engine has its own ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment.  

--- Document Chunk 18040 ---
a) If engine B is remote controlled, its ETCS on -board equipment is in Sleeping mode. 

--- Document Chunk 18041 ---
Note: The mode is entered when on -board equipment detects the presence of the 

--- Document Chunk 18042 ---
"remote control" signal. 

--- Document Chunk 18043 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 18044 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 18045 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 18046 ---
SUBSET-026-5 

--- Document Chunk 18047 ---
3.4.0 

--- Document Chunk 18048 ---
12/05/14 

--- Document Chunk 18049 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 18050 ---
Chapter 5 

--- Document Chunk 18051 ---
Procedures 

--- Document Chunk 18052 ---
Page 55/87 

--- Document Chunk 18053 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 18054 ---
b) If the slave engine is not remote controlled (Tandem operation) by the leading 

--- Document Chunk 18055 ---
engine but  there is a driver who controls the engine, then the on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 18056 ---
is in Non leading mode. 

--- Document Chunk 18057 ---
c) If the engine B is not remote controlled (Tandem Shunting o peration) by the leading 

--- Document Chunk 18058 ---
engine and there is no driver who controls the engine, then the on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 18059 ---
is in Passive Shunting mode. 

--- Document Chunk 18060 ---
5.12.3.2 Assumption: The train configuration does not change. 

--- Document Chunk 18061 ---
a) When changing the train orientation, the leading engine A will bec ome the slave 

--- Document Chunk 18062 ---
engine, and the slave engine B will become the leading engine. 

--- Document Chunk 18063 ---
b) If before the change of train orientation engine B was in SL, afterwards engine A will 

--- Document Chunk 18064 ---
be in SL mode; If before the change of train orientation engine B was in NL, 

--- Document Chunk 18065 ---
afterwards engi ne A will be in NL mode ; If before the change of train orientation 

--- Document Chunk 18066 ---
engine B was in PS, afterwards engine A will be in PS mode. 

--- Document Chunk 18067 ---
5.12.3.3 Case "Engine B was in SL mode" 

--- Document Chunk 18068 ---
5.12.3.3.1 The driver of engine A closes the desk, then the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment of 

--- Document Chunk 18069 ---
engine A switches to Stand-By mode. If the train has a mission, this is a end of mission 

--- Document Chunk 18070 ---
(see “End of Mission” procedure) 

--- Document Chunk 18071 ---
5.12.3.3.2 As soon as the remote control signal disappears, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 18072 ---
equipment of engine B switches to Stand-By mode. 

--- Document Chunk 18073 ---
5.12.3.3.3 Level 2,3: The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment of engine B shall open a 

--- Document Chunk 18074 ---
communication session (if possible) and report the mode change to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 18075 ---
5.12.3.3.4 When the driver opens a desk of engine B he triggers the "Start of Mission" procedure. 

--- Document Chunk 18076 ---
5.12.3.4 Case "Engine B was in NL mode" 

--- Document Chunk 18077 ---
5.12.3.4.1 The driver of engine A selects "Non Leading". The ERTMS/ETCS equipment switches 

--- Document Chunk 18078 ---
to Non Leading mode. 

--- Document Chunk 18079 ---
5.12.3.4.2 Once the non leading input signal is not received any more , the ERTMS/ETCS on-

--- Document Chunk 18080 ---
board equipment of engine B will switch to Stand -By mode ( refer to SRS chapter 4, 

--- Document Chunk 18081 ---
transitions between modes and chapter 5, “End of Mission” procedure). 

--- Document Chunk 18082 ---
5.12.3.4.3 Because the desk is open, when the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment enters Stand-

--- Document Chunk 18083 ---
By mode, the “Start of Mission” procedure is triggered. 

--- Document Chunk 18084 ---
5.12.3.5 Case "Engine B was in PS mode" 

--- Document Chunk 18085 ---
5.12.3.5.1 The driver of engine A selects "Conti nue Shunting on desk closure". The 

--- Document Chunk 18086 ---
ERTMS/ETCS equipment switches to Passive Shunting mode once the driver closes 

--- Document Chunk 18087 ---
the desk of engine A.

--- Document Chunk 18102 ---

--- Document Chunk 18103 ---

--- Document Chunk 18104 ---

--- Document Chunk 18105 ---

--- Document Chunk 18106 ---

--- Document Chunk 18107 ---
closure”. When the driver closes the desk A, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 18108 ---

--- Document Chunk 18109 ---

--- Document Chunk 18110 ---

--- Document Chunk 18111 ---

--- Document Chunk 18112 ---

--- Document Chunk 18113 ---
data (train front position, train orientation), by use of the previous data.

5.13 Train Reversing 

--- Document Chunk 18126 ---
5.13.1.1 This procedure is intended to allow the fast reversal of movement of a train, to run 

--- Document Chunk 18127 ---
away from a danger up to a “safe” location. 

--- Document Chunk 18128 ---
5.13.1.2 The area where initiation of reversing will be possible is announced to the 

--- Document Chunk 18129 ---
ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment by trackside (refer to 3.15.4.2 for details).  

--- Document Chunk 18130 ---
5.13.1.3 While the train is at standstill inside the reversing permitted area, the driver shall be 

--- Document Chunk 18131 ---
informed that reversing is possible 

--- Document Chunk 18132 ---
5.13.1.4 If the ERTMS/ETCS onboard detects the driver’s intention to reverse (e.g. from a 

--- Document Chunk 18133 ---
direction controller in reverse position) , the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 18134 ---
ask the driver to acknowledge transition to RV mode. 

--- Document Chunk 18135 ---
5.13.1.5 If the driver acknowledges, the on-board equipment shall switch to RV mode 

--- Document Chunk 18136 ---
5.13.1.6 Once in RV mode,  it shall be possible for the trackside to send a new permitted 

--- Document Chunk 18137 ---
distance to run and a new maximum speed. 

--- Document Chunk 18138 ---
5.13.1.7 Once in RV mode, it shall also be possible for the trackside to send, together with the 

--- Document Chunk 18139 ---
new permitted distance to run and the maximum speed, a new reference location for 

--- Document Chunk 18140 ---
the new permitted distance to run. 

--- Document Chunk 18141 ---
5.13.1.8 Note: this new reference location is the end of a new reversing area given by trackside 

--- Document Chunk 18142 ---
that the onboard will use only for the purpose of distance referencing. 

--- Document Chunk 18143 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 18144 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP
