--- Document Chunk 18155 ---
5.14 Joining / Splitting 

--- Document Chunk 18156 ---
5.14.1 Definitions 

--- Document Chunk 18157 ---
5.14.1.1 Definition for splitting: The “train to be split” is the train at standstill, waiting for being 

--- Document Chunk 18158 ---
split. The “front train after splitting” refers to the front part of the train b efore splitting, 

--- Document Chunk 18159 ---
the “new train after splitting”, refers to the other part. 

--- Document Chunk 18160 ---
5.14.1.2 Definitions for joining: The “train to be joined” is the train at standstill, waiting for being 

--- Document Chunk 18161 ---
joined. The “joining train” is the train performing the joining operation. 

--- Document Chunk 18162 ---
5.14.2 Procedure “Splitting” 

--- Document Chunk 18163 ---
5.14.2.1 Step 1 - The electrical and mechanical links between the two trains must be removed 

--- Document Chunk 18164 ---
(this is a national operational procedure, out of the scope of the SRS). 

--- Document Chunk 18165 ---
5.14.2.1.1 Note: If splitting require s moving the two train parts apart from each other for a sma ll 

--- Document Chunk 18166 ---
distance, this can be done even in SB mode 

--- Document Chunk 18167 ---
5.14.2.2 Step 2a - If the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment which was supervising the train 

--- Document Chunk 18168 ---
before splitting has not performed an end of mission for splitting, the driver must 

--- Document Chunk 18169 ---
modify the Train Data such that it fits with the  new train composition after splitting.  

--- Document Chunk 18170 ---
For level 2 or 3, the new train data is sent to the RBC (see SRS chapter 3 – Data Entry 

--- Document Chunk 18171 ---
/ Modification Process) 

--- Document Chunk 18172 ---
5.14.2.3 Step 2b - If an ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment of the "new train after splitting" was 

--- Document Chunk 18173 ---
in SL mode before,  it will switch to SB mode once the remote control signal is not 

--- Document Chunk 18174 ---
received any more (refer to SRS chapter 4, transitions between modes).  

--- Document Chunk 18175 ---
For Level 2 or 3: The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall open a communication 

--- Document Chunk 18176 ---
session (if possible) and report the mode change to the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 18177 ---
5.14.2.4 Step - 2c If an ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment of the "new train after splitting" was 

--- Document Chunk 18178 ---
in NL mode before, it will switch to SB mode once the non leading input signal is not 

--- Document Chunk 18179 ---
received any more (refer to SRS chapter 4, transitions between m odes and chapter 5, 

--- Document Chunk 18180 ---
“end of mission” procedure).  

--- Document Chunk 18181 ---
5.14.2.5 The driver can then start a new mission with this “new train after splitting” (refer to the 

--- Document Chunk 18182 ---
“Start of Mission” procedure). In all cases, to start a mission is not the only possibility. 

--- Document Chunk 18183 ---
Shunting movements, or not moving the new train at all, are also possible. 

--- Document Chunk 18184 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 18185 ---
5.14.3 Procedure “Joining” 

--- Document Chunk 18186 ---
5.14.3.1 Step 1 – The “joining train” must approach the “train to be joined”. This can be 

--- Document Chunk 18187 ---
performed in SR, OS or SH mode (depending on the information available, and on the 

--- Document Chunk 18188 ---
national procedure for joining). 

--- Document Chunk 18189 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 18190 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 18191 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 18192 ---
SUBSET-026-5 

--- Document Chunk 18193 ---
3.4.0

12/05/14

--- Document Chunk 18196 ---
Chapter 5 

--- Document Chunk 18197 ---
Procedures 

--- Document Chunk 18198 ---
Page 59/87 

--- Document Chunk 18199 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 18200 ---
5.14.3.2 Step 2 – The electrical and mechanical links between the two trains must be closed 

--- Document Chunk 18201 ---
(vehicle dependent, outside the scope of the ETCS). 

--- Document Chunk 18202 ---
5.14.3.3 Step 3a – If a former leading ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment remains leading and 

--- Document Chunk 18203 ---
there was no end of mission, the driver must modify the Train Data such that it fits with 

--- Document Chunk 18204 ---
the new train composition. For level 2 or 3, the new train data is sent to the RBC (see 

--- Document Chunk 18205 ---
SRS chapter 3 – Data Entry / Modification Process) 

--- Document Chunk 18206 ---
5.14.3.4 Step 3b – If a former leading ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment is to become slave 

--- Document Chunk 18207 ---
equipment in SL mode, when closing the desk, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 18208 ---
will switch to SB mode (see SRS chapter 4, transitions between modes) and the end of 

--- Document Chunk 18209 ---
mission procedure is executed (see “End of Mission” procedure). T ransition to SL 

--- Document Chunk 18210 ---
mode is from SB mode. 

--- Document Chunk 18211 ---
5.14.3.5 Step 3c: If a former leading ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment is to become slave 

--- Document Chunk 18212 ---
equipment in NL mode, the driver selects NL mode (see SRS chapter 4, transitions 

--- Document Chunk 18213 ---
between modes).  

--- Document Chunk 18214 ---
5.14.3.6 For further steps after joining refer to p rocedures “Start of Mission” and “Change of 

--- Document Chunk 18215 ---
Train Orientation”. 

--- Document Chunk 18216 ---

5.15 RBC/RBC Handover 

--- Document Chunk 18228 ---
5.15.1 Principles 

--- Document Chunk 18229 ---
5.15.1.1 Every RBC/RBC handover shall be announced to the ERTMS/ETCS on -board 

--- Document Chunk 18230 ---
equipment via a balise group or via the RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 18231 ---
5.15.1.2 The handover announcement (i.e. RBC transition order) to the ERTMS/ETCS on-board 

--- Document Chunk 18232 ---
equipment shall consist of an order to contact the Accepting RBC (see 3.5.3.5.3) and 

--- Document Chunk 18233 ---
to execute the handover at a further location corresponding to the border. 

--- Document Chunk 18234 ---
5.15.1.2.1 In case of RBC/RBC handover including Radio Network border cross ing, 

--- Document Chunk 18235 ---
ERTMS/ETCS trackside is responsible for the sequence of orders to register to the 

--- Document Chunk 18236 ---
new Radio Network and to contact the "Accepting" RBC, according to the Radio 

--- Document Chunk 18237 ---
Network’s configuration. 

--- Document Chunk 18238 ---
5.15.1.2.2 Note: In the following sections, "first" Mobile Terminal refers to the one used for 

--- Document Chunk 18239 ---
communication session with “Handing Over” RBC and "second" Mobile Terminal to the 

--- Document Chunk 18240 ---
one used for communication session with “Accepting” RBC. 

--- Document Chunk 18241 ---
5.15.1.2.3 Note: In the following sections, Radio Networks are supposed to be overlapped. 

--- Document Chunk 18242 ---
5.15.1.3 At the RBC/RBC border  a balise group with an order to execute the handover 

--- Document Chunk 18243 ---
immediately shall be placed. 

--- Document Chunk 18244 ---
5.15.1.3.1 Note: Balise groups are read in all levels and orders from balise groups are accepted 

--- Document Chunk 18245 ---
independent of the level of operation. Also sleeping units read balise groups. 

--- Document Chunk 18246 ---
5.15.1.4 If the m essage from the border balise group is not (yet) received, the handover shall 

--- Document Chunk 18247 ---
still be executed when the train with its max safe front end passes the border location 

--- Document Chunk 18248 ---
according to the announcement information. 

--- Document Chunk 18249 ---
5.15.1.5 The on -board equipment shall manage only one RB C/RBC transition at a time, 

--- Document Chunk 18250 ---
therefore a new transition order shall replace a previously received order. 

--- Document Chunk 18251 ---
5.15.2 Case 1: Two communication sessions can be handled simultaneously

area to another one are the following:

--- Document Chunk 18257 ---
Establishment of the radio communication session with the “Accepting” RBC; 

--- Document Chunk 18258 ---
c) Generation of movement authorities including the border;

handover.

informs the “Handing Over” RBC.

--- Document Chunk 18410 ---

--- Document Chunk 18413 ---

--- Document Chunk 18414 ---

--- Document Chunk 18415 ---

--- Document Chunk 18416 ---
to terminate the session to the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment. 

--- Document Chunk 18417 ---

of radio communication). 

--- Document Chunk 18423 ---

--- Document Chunk 18426 ---

--- Document Chunk 18427 ---

--- Document Chunk 18449 ---

--- Document Chunk 18450 ---

--- Document Chunk 18451 ---

--- Document Chunk 18452 ---

--- Document Chunk 18453 ---
by the “Handing Over” RBC. For passing the EOA the driver may select "override", or 

--- Document Chunk 18454 ---
manually change the level. 

--- Document Chunk 18455 ---

--- Document Chunk 18456 ---

--- Document Chunk 18457 ---
to terminate the session is received from the “Handing Over”  RBC within a fixed 

--- Document Chunk 18458 ---
waiting time (see appendix to chapter 3, List of Fixed Value Data) after sending the 

--- Document Chunk 18459 ---
position report (see 5.15.2.2.6) , the position report shall be repeated with the fixed 

--- Document Chunk 18460 ---
waiting time after each repetition. 

--- Document Chunk 18461 ---
5.15.4.4 After a defined number of repetitions (see appendix to chapter 3, List of Fixed Value 

--- Document Chunk 18462 ---
Data), and if no reply is received within the fixed waiting time from the last sending of 

--- Document Chunk 18463 ---
the position report,  the ERTMS/ETCS onboard equipment shall terminate the  

--- Document Chunk 18464 ---
communication session.

5.18 Indication of Track Conditions 

--- Document Chunk 18788 ---
5.18.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 18789 ---
5.18.1.1 This set of proced ures specifies the sequences of driver indications related to the 

--- Document Chunk 18790 ---
following track-conditions: 

--- Document Chunk 18791 ---
a) powerless section with pantograph to be lowered 

--- Document Chunk 18792 ---
b) powerless section with main power switch to be switched off, 

--- Document Chunk 18793 ---
c) non-stopping area, 

--- Document Chunk 18794 ---
d) radio hole, 

--- Document Chunk 18795 ---
e) air tightness area, 

--- Document Chunk 18796 ---
f) Inhibition of a defined type of brake, 

--- Document Chunk 18797 ---
g) tunnel stopping area, 

--- Document Chunk 18798 ---
h) sound horn, 

--- Document Chunk 18799 ---
i) change of traction system. 

--- Document Chunk 18800 ---
5.18.1.2 Note: For every procedure a figure supports the textual description. The textual 

--- Document Chunk 18801 ---
description of the procedures contains reference to the figures (point B, point F,…). 

--- Document Chunk 18802 ---

5.18.3 Passing a powerless section with main power switch to be switched off 

--- Document Chunk 18877 ---
5.18.3.1 This procedure is dealing with the announcement and indication to the driver of a 

--- Document Chunk 18878 ---
powerless section with main power switch to be switched off. 

--- Document Chunk 18879 ---
5.18.3.2 “Neutral section announcem ent” shall be displayed to the driver when the max safe 

--- Document Chunk 18880 ---
front end of the train reaches a location (point C) in rear of the beginning of the 

--- Document Chunk 18881 ---
powerless section. 

--- Document Chunk 18882 ---
5.18.3.2.1 This location (point C) shall be determined by the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 18883 ---
taking into acco unt the time necessary for performing the required actions and the 

--- Document Chunk 18884 ---
current train speed. 

--- Document Chunk 18885 ---
5.18.3.2.2 The displayed “Neutral section announcement” information shall also indicate if the 

--- Document Chunk 18886 ---
related functionality is executed 

--- Document Chunk 18887 ---
 automatically, or 

--- Document Chunk 18888 ---
 if the driver is requested to act. 

--- Document Chunk 18889 ---
5.18.3.2.2.1 Note: Whether the operation is automatic or manual is application dependent. 

--- Document Chunk 18890 ---
5.18.3.3 When the max safe front end of the train reaches the starting location (point D) of the 

--- Document Chunk 18891 ---
powerless section: 

--- Document Chunk 18892 ---
 “Neutral section announcement” shall no longer be displayed to the driver, 

--- Document Chunk 18893 ---
 “Neutral section” information shall be displayed to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 18894 ---
5.18.3.4 When the min safe front end o f the train reaches the “Powerless section” end location 

--- Document Chunk 18895 ---
point E): 

--- Document Chunk 18896 ---
 “Neutral section” information shall no longer be displayed to the driver 

--- Document Chunk 18897 ---
 “End of Neutral section” information shall be displayed to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 18898 ---
5.18.3.4.1 The displayed “End of Neutral section” information shall also indicate if the related 

--- Document Chunk 18899 ---
functionality is executed 

--- Document Chunk 18900 ---
 Automatically, or 

--- Document Chunk 18901 ---
 if the driver is requested to act.  

--- Document Chunk 18902 ---
5.18.3.4.1.1 Note: Whether the operation is automatic or manual is application dependent.  

--- Document Chunk 18903 ---

--- Document Chunk 18904 ---

--- Document Chunk 18905 ---
“Powerless section”.

5.18.4 Passing a non stopping area 

--- Document Chunk 18924 ---
5.18.4.1 This procedure is dealing with the announcement and indication to the driver of an 

--- Document Chunk 18925 ---
area where stopping is not permitted. 

--- Document Chunk 18926 ---
5.18.4.2 As long as there are non stopping areas stored on -board, the ERTMS/ETCS on-board 

--- Document Chunk 18927 ---
equipment shall continuously check the current speed and position of the train whether 

--- Document Chunk 18928 ---
a full service brake command would stop the train within any of the stored non 

--- Document Chunk 18929 ---
stopping areas. This shall be achieved taking into account  for each non stopping area, 

--- Document Chunk 18930 ---
two virtual SBI supervision limits (SBID and SBIG), calculated at the estimated speed 

--- Document Chunk 18931 ---
from two SBD curves of which the f eet are the start location of the non stopping area 

--- Document Chunk 18932 ---
(point D) and a location (point G) at train length distance in advance of the end location 

--- Document Chunk 18933 ---
of the non stopping area: 

--- Document Chunk 18934 ---
a) If t he max safe front end is in rear of the first SBI supervision limit  (SBID) no 

--- Document Chunk 18935 ---
information related to this non stopping area shall be displayed 

--- Document Chunk 18936 ---
b) If the max safe front end is in advance of the first SBI supervision limit  (SBID) and 

--- Document Chunk 18937 ---
the min safe front end in r ear of the second  SBI supervision limit  (SBIG), the non  

--- Document Chunk 18938 ---
stopping area related information shall be displayed to the driver  according to the 

--- Document Chunk 18939 ---
following clauses 5.18.4.3, 5.18.4.4. 

--- Document Chunk 18940 ---
c) If the min safe front end is in advance of the second SBI supervision limit  (SBIG), no 

--- Document Chunk 18941 ---
information related to this non stopping area shall be displayed. 

--- Document Chunk 18942 ---
5.18.4.3 When the max safe front end is in rear of  the start location (point D) of the non 

--- Document Chunk 18943 ---
stopping area, the “Non stopping area announcement” shall be displayed to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 18944 ---
5.18.4.4 When the max safe front end is in advance of  the start location (point D) of the non 

--- Document Chunk 18945 ---
stopping area: 

--- Document Chunk 18946 ---
 “Non stopping area announcement”, if any, shall no longer be displayed 

--- Document Chunk 18947 ---
running direction 

--- Document Chunk 18948 ---
Display: «Neutral 

--- Document Chunk 18949 ---
section» 

--- Document Chunk 18950 ---
Distance to begin of powerless section 

--- Document Chunk 18951 ---

section announcement»

5.18.8 Advising a tunnel stopping area 

--- Document Chunk 19121 ---
5.18.8.1 This procedure is dealing with the indication to the dri ver of an area under a tunnel 

--- Document Chunk 19122 ---
where stopping is permitted, and suitable escaping paths are provided. 

--- Document Chunk 19123 ---
5.18.8.1.1 Note: the tunnel stopping areas are designed in such a way that the passengers can 

--- Document Chunk 19124 ---
step out, use a walkway along the track and reach the safe area, taking into account 

--- Document Chunk 19125 ---
the longest admissible train in the tunnel stopped with its front end within the tunnel 

--- Document Chunk 19126 ---
stopping area. 

--- Document Chunk 19127 ---
5.18.8.2 On driver request, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall enable/disable the 

--- Document Chunk 19128 ---
display of the tunnel stopping area related information (initial state: disabled). 

--- Document Chunk 19129 ---
running direction 

--- Document Chunk 19130 ---
Brake inhibition length 

--- Document Chunk 19131 ---
Display: «Inhibition of 

--- Document Chunk 19132 ---
Regenerative Brake»

announcement»

5.18.8.3 As long as the display of the tunnel stopping areas is enabled (point C) and there are 

--- Document Chunk 19151 ---
tunnel stopping areas stored on -board, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 19152 ---
continuously check the current speed and position of the train  to det ermine whether 

--- Document Chunk 19153 ---
the driver can stop the train with the full service brake before reaching the end of the 

--- Document Chunk 19154 ---
closest tunnel stopping area. This shall be achieved taking into account a virtual 

--- Document Chunk 19155 ---
Permitted supervision limit (with no contribution of the GUI curve, i f any), calculated at 

--- Document Chunk 19156 ---
the estimated speed from an SBD curve of which the foot is the end location of the 

--- Document Chunk 19157 ---
tunnel stopping area: 

--- Document Chunk 19158 ---
a) If the train front end is in rear of the Permitted supervision limit, the tunnel stopping 

--- Document Chunk 19159 ---
area related information shall be displayed to the driver.  

--- Document Chunk 19160 ---
b) If the train front end is in advance of the  Permitted supervision limit, no information 

--- Document Chunk 19161 ---
related to this tunnel stopping area shall be displayed and the next tunnel stopping 

--- Document Chunk 19162 ---
area stored on-board, if any, shall be checked. 

--- Document Chunk 19163 ---
5.18.8.4 Before the tra in reaches the start location (point D) of the tunnel stopping area, the 

--- Document Chunk 19164 ---
“tunnel stopping area announcement” shall be displayed to the driver. This shall 

--- Document Chunk 19165 ---
include the indication of the remaining distance to the start location of the tunnel 

--- Document Chunk 19166 ---
stopping area. 

--- Document Chunk 19167 ---
5.18.8.5 When the train front end reaches the start location (point D) of the tunnel stopping 

--- Document Chunk 19168 ---
area: 

--- Document Chunk 19169 ---
 “Tunnel stopping area announcement” shall no longer be displayed 

--- Document Chunk 19170 ---
 “Tunnel stopping area” information shall be displayed to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 19171 ---

5.18.9 Sounding the horn 

--- Document Chunk 19205 ---
5.18.9.1 This procedure is dealing wit h the indication to the driver of a request to sound the 

--- Document Chunk 19206 ---
horn. 

--- Document Chunk 19207 ---
5.18.9.2 “Sound horn” shall be displayed to the driver when the estimated front end of the train 

--- Document Chunk 19208 ---
reaches a location (point C) in rear of the beginning of the “sound horn” area (point D). 

--- Document Chunk 19209 ---
5.18.9.2.1 This location (point C) shall be determined by the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 19210 ---
taking into account the time necessary for the driver to perform the required action 

--- Document Chunk 19211 ---
(see Appendix A3.1) and the current train speed. 

--- Document Chunk 19212 ---
5.18.9.3 When the estimated front  end of the train reaches the en d location (point E) of the 

--- Document Chunk 19213 ---
“sound horn”  area, the indication “ Sound horn ” information shall no longer be 

--- Document Chunk 19214 ---
displayed. 

--- Document Chunk 19215 ---
5.18.9.4 Note: In order not to encourage the driver to stop sounding the horn too early, the track 

--- Document Chunk 19216 ---
condition “sound horn” is defined as an area so t hat the display of the indication 

--- Document Chunk 19217 ---
“Sound horn” continues during a certain distance sent by trackside  (i.e. until point E), 

--- Document Chunk 19218 ---
after the theoretical location of the board on the line (i.e. point D). 

--- Document Chunk 19219 ---

5.19 Procedure Limited Supervision 

--- Document Chunk 19287 ---
5.19.1 General Requirements 

--- Document Chunk 19288 ---
5.19.1.1 The order to switch to Limited Supervision mode shall be given by means of a mode 

--- Document Chunk 19289 ---
profile. 

--- Document Chunk 19290 ---
5.19.1.2 An acknowledgement for running in Limited Supervision mode shall be requested from 

--- Document Chunk 19291 ---
the driver. The conditions of the acknowledgement are specified below. 

--- Document Chunk 19292 ---
5.19.2 Limited Supervision is requested for current location (from modes 

--- Document Chunk 19293 ---
different from Stand By and Post Trip) 

--- Document Chunk 19294 ---
5.19.2.1 In a level 1 area, the beginning of the Limited Supervision area can be the balise 

--- Document Chunk 19295 ---
(group) that gives the Mode Profile. When the train passes the balise group and 

--- Document Chunk 19296 ---
receives this information, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall immediately 

--- Document Chunk 19297 ---
switch to Limited Supervision mode. 

--- Document Chunk 19298 ---
5.19.2.2 In a level 2 or 3 area, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment can receive a mode 

--- Document Chunk 19299 ---
profile giving a Limited Super vision area which the train has already entered with its 

--- Document Chunk 19300 ---
max safe front end. In this case, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall 

--- Document Chunk 19301 ---
immediately switch to Limited Supervision mode. 

--- Document Chunk 19302 ---
5.19.2.3 The driver must acknowledge the Limited Supervision mode. A request of 

--- Document Chunk 19303 ---
acknowledgement shall be displayed to the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 19304 ---
5.19.2.4 If the driver has not acknowledged after the driver acknowledgement time (refer to 

--- Document Chunk 19305 ---
Appendix A3.1), the service brake command shall be triggered. The brake command is 

--- Document Chunk 19306 ---
released when the driver acknowledges, except if brakes are also applied for another 

--- Document Chunk 19307 ---
reason(s). 

--- Document Chunk 19308 ---
5.19.2.5 Note: Once in Limited Supervision mode, the speed supervision is such that the train 

--- Document Chunk 19309 ---
speed cannot exceed the LS mode speed limit. If, when entering the Limited 

--- Document Chunk 19310 ---
Supervision mode, the train speed was higher t han the LS mode speed limit (because 

--- Document Chunk 19311 ---
a higher speed was allowed in Full Supervision mode, On Sight mode or in Staff 

--- Document Chunk 19312 ---
Responsible mode) then an emergency brake  command could be immediately 

--- Document Chunk 19313 ---
triggered, independently of the acknowledgement of the driver, but be cause of the LS 

--- Document Chunk 19314 ---
supervision (see Figure 22). 

--- Document Chunk 19315 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 19346 ---
by giving with the previous MA an E OA (or a L OA = LS mode speed limit) at the 

--- Document Chunk 19347 ---
location of transition to Limited Supervision mode. 

--- Document Chunk 19348 ---
5.19.2.7 If the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment is already in LS mode when receiving the LS 

--- Document Chunk 19349 ---
mode profile, no further acknowledgement shall be requested from the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 19350 ---
5.19.3 Limited Supervision is requested for a further location 

--- Document Chunk 19351 ---
5.19.3.1 The beginning of the Limited Supervision area can be a location that the train has not 

--- Document Chunk 19352 ---
reached yet. This occurs when: 

--- Document Chunk 19353 ---
a) In a level 1 area, a balise group gives a Mode  Profile with an Limited Supervision 

--- Document Chunk 19354 ---
area that is located at a further location. 

--- Document Chunk 19355 ---
b) In a level 2 or 3 area, the RBC gives a Mode Profile with an Limited Supervision 

--- Document Chunk 19356 ---
area that is located at a further location. 

--- Document Chunk 19357 ---
5.19.3.2 A request for acknowledgement shall be displayed t o the driver when the following 

--- Document Chunk 19358 ---
conditions are fulfilled: 

--- Document Chunk 19359 ---
a)  The distance between the estimated front end of the train and the beginning of 

--- Document Chunk 19360 ---
Limited Supervision area is shorter than a value, contained in the mode profile.   

--- Document Chunk 19361 ---
b) The speed is lower than the Limited  Supervision mode speed limit (national value, 

--- Document Chunk 19362 ---
or value given in the mode profile). 

--- Document Chunk 19363 ---
c) The current mode is not Limited Supervision 

--- Document Chunk 19364 ---
5.19.3.3 Note: The first 2 conditions define the “rectangle of acknowledgement”. 

--- Document Chunk 19365 ---
5.19.3.4 Once the acknowledgement request is displayed, it is not  taken back if the train leaves 

--- Document Chunk 19366 ---
the “rectangle of acknowledgement” (for example: because the train accelerates). 

--- Document Chunk 19367 ---

--- Document Chunk 19411 ---

5.19.4 Limited Supervision from Unfitted or SN mode 

--- Document Chunk 19413 ---
5.19.4.1 The mode profile with regards to an LS area is only evaluated in levels 1,2,3, although 

--- Document Chunk 19414 ---
the mode profile may have been receive d in level 0 (Unfitted mode) or NTC (SN 

--- Document Chunk 19415 ---
mode). A transition to Limited Supervision mode can therefore earliest occur at a 

--- Document Chunk 19416 ---
transition of level: from level 0 or NTC to level 1 or 2 or 3.

5.19.5 Limited Supervision from Stand By or Post Trip mode 

--- Document Chunk 19431 ---
5.19.5.1 When performing a SoM or a Train Trip procedure and when the current level is 2 or 3, 

--- Document Chunk 19432 ---
the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment can receive a mode profile giving an Limited 

--- Document Chunk 19433 ---
Supervision area which the train has already entered with its max safe front end. In this 

--- Document Chunk 19434 ---
case, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall first require an acknowledgement 

--- Document Chunk 19435 ---
from the driver. 

--- Document Chunk 19436 ---
5.19.5.2 When the driver acknowledges, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment shall perform 

--- Document Chunk 19437 ---
the transition to Limited Supervision mode. 

--- Document Chunk 19438 ---
5.19.6 Exit of Limited Supervision mode 

--- Document Chunk 19439 ---
5.19.6.1 General rule 

--- Document Chunk 19440 ---
5.19.6.1.1 The ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment exits the Limited Supervision mode when the 

--- Document Chunk 19441 ---
min safe front end of the train passes the end of the Limited supervision area. 

--- Document Chunk 19442 ---
5.19.6.2 First case: The Limited supervision area ends at the EOA of the current MA 

--- Document Chunk 19443 ---
5.19.6.2.1 This occurs when the end of the Limited Supervision area that is given by the Mode 

--- Document Chunk 19444 ---
Profile has the same location as the EOA of the related MA. 

--- Document Chunk 19445 ---
5.19.6.2.2 In this case, the train must receive a new Movement Authori ty to be able to exit the 

--- Document Chunk 19446 ---
Limited Supervision area. 

--- Document Chunk 19447 ---
5.19.6.3 Second case: The Limited Supervision area ends before the EOA of the current 

--- Document Chunk 19448 ---
MA 

--- Document Chunk 19449 ---
5.19.6.3.1 In this case, the current Movement Authority already allows the train to exit the Limited 

--- Document Chunk 19450 ---
Supervision area. 

--- Document Chunk 19451 ---
5.19.6.3.2 When exiting the  Limited Supervision area, the ERTMS/ETCS on -board equipment 

--- Document Chunk 19452 ---
switches either to Full Supervision, On Sight or to Shunting mode (refer to SRS 

--- Document Chunk 19453 ---
chapter 4, transitions between modes). 

--- Document Chunk 19454 ---

--- Document Chunk 19625 ---
6.3 Scope 

--- Document Chunk 19626 ---
6.3.1.1 The chapter defines the composition of envelope of legally operated system versions, 

--- Document Chunk 19627 ---
i.e. all the ERTMS/ETCS system versions that trackside shall be allowed to operate 

--- Document Chunk 19628 ---
and that on-board equipment shall support. 

--- Document Chunk 19629 ---
6.3.1.2 By default, all the clauses listed in the other SRS chapters shall be applicable 

--- Document Chunk 19630 ---
regardless of the system version operated; this chapter includes the exceptions to 

--- Document Chunk 19631 ---
these clauses and the additional clauses, which shall apply when the system version of 

--- Document Chunk 19632 ---
some trackside constituents and/or the system version operated relates to a version 

--- Document Chunk 19633 ---
number older than the last one introduced. 

--- Document Chunk 19634 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

6.4 Envelope of legally operated system versions 

--- Document Chunk 19645 ---
6.4.1 Incompatible versions 

--- Document Chunk 19646 ---
6.4.1.1 The system version number X, which a trackside infrastructure is allowed to operate 

--- Document Chunk 19647 ---
with, shall be one of the following: 1 or 2 

--- Document Chunk 19648 ---
6.4.2 Compatible versions 

--- Document Chunk 19649 ---
6.4.2.1 Within system version number X = 1, the system version number Y that a trackside 

--- Document Chunk 19650 ---
infrastructure is allowed to use shall be any of the following: 0 or 1 

--- Document Chunk 19651 ---
6.4.2.2 Within system version number X = 2, the system version number Y that a trackside 

--- Document Chunk 19652 ---
infrastructure is allowed to use shall be 0 

--- Document Chunk 19653 ---

6.5 Trackside requirements in relation to older system versions 

--- Document Chunk 19664 ---
6.5.1 Trackside areas operated with system version number X = 1 

--- Document Chunk 19665 ---
6.5.1.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 19666 ---
6.5.1.1.1 The section is applicable for trackside infrastructures that will be tendered and still 

--- Document Chunk 19667 ---
operated with the system version number X = 1, after the entry into force of this 

--- Document Chunk 19668 ---
release of the SRS. 

--- Document Chunk 19669 ---
6.5.1.1.2 Within a trackside infrastructure operated with the system version number X = 1, it 

--- Document Chunk 19670 ---
shall be allowed to use the following values of M_VERSION: 1.0, and 1.1 

--- Document Chunk 19671 ---
6.5.1.1.3 Within a trackside area operated with an RBC certified to the system version number X 

--- Document Chunk 19672 ---
= 1, it shall also be allowed to use the value M_VERSION = 2.0 for balises. 

--- Document Chunk 19673 ---
6.5.1.1.3.1 Note: this configuration is meaningful in case the trains operating on this RBC area 

--- Document Chunk 19674 ---
support the system version number X = 2 and the on-board requirements related to the 

--- Document Chunk 19675 ---
trackside information marked with 2.0 are applicable regardless of the operated 

--- Document Chunk 19676 ---
version (i.e. they are applied by the on-board equipment even if this latter operates 

--- Document Chunk 19677 ---
with the system version number X = 1 ordered by RBC). 

--- Document Chunk 19678 ---
6.5.1.2 Exceptions to chapter 3 

--- Document Chunk 19679 ---
6.5.1.2.1 Clause 3.5.3.11 shall be replaced with:”In case the RBC is the initiator, the first 

--- Document Chunk 19680 ---
message from RBC to on-board shall include a request for acknowledgement and shall 

--- Document Chunk 19681 ---
have the time-stamp and the LRBG identity set to "unknown".” 

--- Document Chunk 19682 ---
6.5.1.2.1.1 Section 3.6.2.4 shall not apply. 

--- Document Chunk 19683 ---
6.5.1.2.2 Clause 3.7.1.1 b) shall be replaced with: “When needed, limitations related to the 

--- Document Chunk 19684 ---
movement authority, i.e. Mode profile for On Sight or Shunting and signalling related 

--- Document Chunk 19685 ---
speed restriction (see sections 3.12.4 and 3.11.6). Mode profile and Signalling related 

--- Document Chunk 19686 ---
Speed restriction shall always be sent together with the MA to which the information 

--- Document Chunk 19687 ---
belongs” 

--- Document Chunk 19688 ---
6.5.1.2.3 In clause 3.7.1.1 c), the bullet “Optionally Speed restriction to ensure a given permitted 

--- Document Chunk 19689 ---
braking distance (see section 3.11. 11)” shall not apply. 

--- Document Chunk 19690 ---
6.5.1.2.4 In clause 3.7.2.4, the bullet “LX speed restrictions” shall not apply. 

--- Document Chunk 19691 ---
6.5.1.2.5 In clause 3.7.2.4, the bullet “Inhibition of revocable TSRs from balises in L2/3 (from 

--- Document Chunk 19692 ---
RBC only)” shall not apply. 

--- Document Chunk 19693 ---
6.5.1.2.6 Clause 3.9.3.2 shall be replaced with: “The orders shall be sent via balise groups.” 

--- Document Chunk 19694 ---
6.5.1.2.7 Clause 3.9.3.8.1 shall not apply. 

--- Document Chunk 19695 ---
6.5.1.2.8 Clause 3.11.3.2.2 c) shall not apply.

7.3 Components of ERTMS/ETCS Language 

--- Document Chunk 21689 ---
7.3.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 21690 ---
7.3.1.1 The ERTMS/ETCS language is used in transmitting information over the radio, balise 

--- Document Chunk 21691 ---
and loop airgaps. 

--- Document Chunk 21692 ---
7.3.1.2 The ERTMS/ETCS language is based on variables, packets, messages and telegrams 

--- Document Chunk 21693 ---
(variables and packets are des cribed in this section, while telegrams and messages 

--- Document Chunk 21694 ---
are described in chapter 8). 

--- Document Chunk 21695 ---
7.3.1.3 Note: A number of variables contain values which have to be assigned. Some of these 

--- Document Chunk 21696 ---
values have to be unique to ensure that the system functions properly. A centralised 

--- Document Chunk 21697 ---
handling of this assignment is therefore required (nationally or internationally, 

--- Document Chunk 21698 ---
depending on the variable). The variables concerned have been marked. The values 

--- Document Chunk 21699 ---
included in this document for these variables are therefore not to be used without prior 

--- Document Chunk 21700 ---
verification of their validity. See SUBSET-054 for further details. 

--- Document Chunk 21701 ---
7.3.2 Definition of Variables 

--- Document Chunk 21702 ---
7.3.2.1 Variables shall be used to encode single data values. Variables cannot be split in 

--- Document Chunk 21703 ---
minor units. The whole variable has one type (meaning). 

--- Document Chunk 21704 ---
7.3.2.2 Variables may have special values which are related to the basic meaning of the 

--- Document Chunk 21705 ---
variable. 

--- Document Chunk 21706 ---
7.3.2.3 Special values have always the highest values in a variable (eg. 11...111 = “unknown”). 

--- Document Chunk 21707 ---
7.3.2.4 Spare values shall be located between the normal and special values in the variable 

--- Document Chunk 21708 ---
range 

--- Document Chunk 21709 ---
7.3.2.5 Names of variables are  unique. A variable is used in context with the meaning as 

--- Document Chunk 21710 ---
described in the variable definition. Variables with different meanings have different 

--- Document Chunk 21711 ---
names. 

--- Document Chunk 21712 ---
7.3.2.6 All variable definitions shall be independent of the transport media over which they are 

--- Document Chunk 21713 ---
used, if used in more than one media. 

--- Document Chunk 21714 ---
7.3.2.7 Signed values shall be encoded as 2’s complement. 

--- Document Chunk 21715 ---
7.3.2.8 One bit variables (Boolean) shall always use 0 for false and 1 for true. 

--- Document Chunk 21716 ---
7.3.2.9 Offsets for numerical values shall be avoided (0 shall be used for 0, 1 for 1, etc.) 

--- Document Chunk 21717 ---
except where justified. 

--- Document Chunk 21718 ---
7.3.2.10 When transmitting over the different transmission media, the most significant bit shall 

--- Document Chunk 21719 ---
be transmitted first. 

--- Document Chunk 21720 ---
7.3.2.11 All Variables have one of the following prefixes: 

--- Document Chunk 21721 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 21722 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 21723 ---

7.3.3 Definition of Packets 

--- Document Chunk 21744 ---
7.3.3.1 Packets are multiple variables grouped into a single unit, with a defined internal 

--- Document Chunk 21745 ---
structure. 

--- Document Chunk 21746 ---
7.3.3.2 This structure consists of a packet header with: 

--- Document Chunk 21747 ---
 Track to Train: a  unique packet number, the length of the packet in bits, the 

--- Document Chunk 21748 ---
orientation information, optionally the distance scale and an information section 

--- Document Chunk 21749 ---
containing a defined set of variables. The packet structure is as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 21750 ---
Number NID_PACKET Packet identifier 

--- Document Chunk 21751 ---
Direction Q_DIR Specifies the validity  direction 

--- Document Chunk 21752 ---
of transmitted data 

--- Document Chunk 21753 ---
Length L_PACKET  Number of bits in the packet 

--- Document Chunk 21754 ---
Scale Q_SCALE Specifies which distance scale 

--- Document Chunk 21755 ---
is used for all distance 

--- Document Chunk 21756 ---
information within the packet. 

--- Document Chunk 21757 ---
There is no Q_SCALE variable 

--- Document Chunk 21758 ---
in packets which do not contain 

--- Document Chunk 21759 ---
distance information. 

--- Document Chunk 21760 ---
Information ...... Well defined set(s) of variables. 

--- Document Chunk 21761 ---
 Train to Track: a unique packet number, the length of the packet in bits, optionally 

--- Document Chunk 21762 ---
the distance scale and an information section containing a defined set o f variables. 

--- Document Chunk 21763 ---
The packet structure is as follows: 

--- Document Chunk 21764 ---
Number NID_PACKET Packet identifier 

--- Document Chunk 21765 ---
Length L_PACKET  Number of bits in the packet 

--- Document Chunk 21766 ---
Scale Q_SCALE Specifies which distance scale 

--- Document Chunk 21767 ---
is used for all distance 

--- Document Chunk 21768 ---
information within the packet. 

--- Document Chunk 21769 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 21770 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 21771 ---
SUBSET-026-7 

--- Document Chunk 21772 ---
3.4.0 

--- Document Chunk 21773 ---
12/05/14 

--- Document Chunk 21774 ---
System Requirements Specification 

--- Document Chunk 21775 ---
Chapter 7 

--- Document Chunk 21776 ---
ERTMS/ETCS language 

--- Document Chunk 21777 ---
Page 8/86 

--- Document Chunk 21778 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 21779 ---
There is no Q_SCALE va riable 

--- Document Chunk 21780 ---
in packets which do not contain 

--- Document Chunk 21781 ---
distance information. 

--- Document Chunk 21782 ---
Information ...... Well defined set(s) of variables. 

--- Document Chunk 21783 ---
7.3.3.3 The packet definition does not change when transmitted over different transmission 

--- Document Chunk 21784 ---
media. 

--- Document Chunk 21785 ---
7.3.3.4 All currently not defined packet identifiers are r eserved for future use  and shall be 

--- Document Chunk 21786 ---
considered as invalid values (i.e. like spare values). Exception: reception of information 

--- Document Chunk 21787 ---
only differing by Y with regards to the highest system version number X supported by 

--- Document Chunk 21788 ---
on-board (refer to section 3.17.3.11). All future packet definitions shall follow the above 

--- Document Chunk 21789 ---
defined structure. 

--- Document Chunk 21790 ---
7.3.3.5 Exception: Packet 0 “Virtual Balise Cover marker” and Packet 255: “End of Telegram” 

--- Document Chunk 21791 ---
do not follow the above defined structure. 

--- Document Chunk 21792 ---
7.3.3.6 N_ITER specifies the number of iterations of a variable or gro up of variables which 

--- Document Chunk 21793 ---
follow. 

--- Document Chunk 21794 ---
7.3.3.7 If N_ITER is 0 then no variables follow. 

--- Document Chunk 21795 ---
7.3.3.8 Two nested levels of iterations can exist. 

--- Document Chunk 21796 ---
7.3.3.9 If, depending on the value of a previous qualifier variable in the packet, a variable is 

--- Document Chunk 21797 ---
optional, it is written indented in the packet definition 

--- Document Chunk 21798 ---
7.3.3.10 Note: Row “Transmitted by” in the description of a packet specifies which 

--- Document Chunk 21799 ---
ERTMS/ETCS trackside device (b alise, loop, RIU, RBC) can  transmit this packet.  

--- Document Chunk 21800 ---
“Any” means that the packet can be transmitted by a balise, a loop, an RBC and a RIU. 

--- Document Chunk 21801 ---
7.3.3.10.1 Note: Row “T ransmitted to” in the description of a packet specifies to which 

--- Document Chunk 21802 ---
ERTMS/ETCS trackside device the packet can be transmitted. 

--- Document Chunk 21803 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 23300 ---
7.5.0.1 A_NVMAXREDADH1 

--- Document Chunk 23301 ---
Name Maximum deceleration under reduced adhesion conditions (1) 

--- Document Chunk 23302 ---
Description Maximum deceleration under reduced adhesion conditions applicable for trains: 

--- Document Chunk 23303 ---
 With brake position “Passenger train in P”, and 

--- Document Chunk 23304 ---
 with special/additional brakes independent from wheel/rail adhesion. 

--- Document Chunk 23305 ---
This variable is part of the National Values 

--- Document Chunk 23306 ---
Length of variable Minimum Value Maximum Value Resolution/formula 

--- Document Chunk 23307 ---
6 bits 0 m/s2 3.15 m/s2 0.05 m/s2 

--- Document Chunk 23308 ---

--- Document Chunk 25801 ---
8.3 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 25802 ---
8.3.1 Scope and Purpose 

--- Document Chunk 25803 ---
8.3.1.1 This chapter defines the format and content of messages necessary for ERTMS/ETCS 

--- Document Chunk 25804 ---
functions. 

--- Document Chunk 25805 ---
8.3.1.2 Concerning the transmission media, this chapter does not cover considerations such 

--- Document Chunk 25806 ---
as medium-specific use constraints (e .g. distance between track -circuit and balise…), 

--- Document Chunk 25807 ---
as well as functions (e .g. detection of balise reference, tim e and location stamp, 

--- Document Chunk 25808 ---
identifying type of receiving balise, Key Management, Releasing/maintaining a radio 

--- Document Chunk 25809 ---
connection…) and performance of the transmission media. 

--- Document Chunk 25810 ---
8.3.2 Definitions 

--- Document Chunk 25811 ---
8.3.2.1 Transmission media considered hereafter are standard ERTMS/ETCS transmission 

--- Document Chunk 25812 ---
media used for ETCS (Eurobalise, Euroradio and Euroloop). 

--- Document Chunk 25813 ---
8.3.2.2 A message includes user data (application level) and protocol data (depending on the 

--- Document Chunk 25814 ---
transmission medium). 

--- Document Chunk 25815 ---
8.3.2.3 A Eurobalise message is the information sent by a balise group (i.e. the message is 

--- Document Chunk 25816 ---
composed of one or several telegrams, sorted by balise number in the group (telegram 

--- Document Chunk 25817 ---
from balise number 1 first), ea ch telegram is transmitted by a Eurobalise). A 

--- Document Chunk 25818 ---
Eurobalise telegram contains one header and an identified and coherent set of 

--- Document Chunk 25819 ---
Packets. 

--- Document Chunk 25820 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 25821 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 25822 ---

--- Document Chunk 25865 ---
8.4 Rules 

--- Document Chunk 25866 ---
8.4.1 Common Rules 

--- Document Chunk 25867 ---
8.4.1.1 A message (Euroradio/Euroloop) or telegram (Eurobalise) shall be composed of 

--- Document Chunk 25868 ---
1. One Header, 

--- Document Chunk 25869 ---
2. When needed, a predefined set of variables (only for Radio), 

--- Document Chunk 25870 ---
3. When needed, a predefined set of Packets (only for Radio), 

--- Document Chunk 25871 ---
4. Optional Packets as needed by application. 

--- Document Chunk 25872 ---
8.4.1.2 The transmission order shall respect the order of data elements listed in the message 

--- Document Chunk 25873 ---
format (from top to bottom). 

--- Document Chunk 25874 ---
8.4.1.3 The behaviour of the receiver shall not depend on the sequence of the Packets given 

--- Document Chunk 25875 ---
by the message. 

--- Document Chunk 25876 ---
8.4.1.3.1 Exception for Infill information: The locations given in the packets following packet 136 

--- Document Chunk 25877 ---
(Infill Location Reference) shall be referred to the balise group indicated in such 

--- Document Chunk 25878 ---
packet. 

--- Document Chunk 25879 ---
8.4.1.3.2 Note: orientations are in any case always referred to the directionality of  balise group 

--- Document Chunk 25880 ---
(balise transmission), directionality of loop (Euroloop transmission) or directionality of 

--- Document Chunk 25881 ---
LRBG (radio transmission). 

--- Document Chunk 25882 ---
8.4.1.4 It shall be forbidden to send more instances of the same packet type for the same 

--- Document Chunk 25883 ---
direction in the same message. 

--- Document Chunk 25884 ---
8.4.1.4.1 Exception 1: A message can contain several packets 44 (Data used by applications 

--- Document Chunk 25885 ---
outside the ERTMS/ETCS system). 

--- Document Chunk 25886 ---
8.4.1.4.2 Exception 2: A message can contain several packets 65 (Temporary Speed 

--- Document Chunk 25887 ---
Restriction). In case of  revocable TSRs, the identities of the corresponding tempor ary 

--- Document Chunk 25888 ---
speed restrictions (variable NID_TSR) transmitted in the same message shall be 

--- Document Chunk 25889 ---
different. 

--- Document Chunk 25890 ---
8.4.1.4.3 Exception 3: A message can contain several packets 66 (TSR Revocation). The 

--- Document Chunk 25891 ---
identities of the corresponding temporary speed restrictions (variable NID_TSR) 

--- Document Chunk 25892 ---
transmitted in the same message shall be different. 

--- Document Chunk 25893 ---
8.4.1.4.4 Exception 4: A message transmitted by a balise group can contain one packet 136 per 

--- Document Chunk 25894 ---
balise telegram per direction. Each packet 136 indicates which part of that telegram is 

--- Document Chunk 25895 ---
to be considered as part of the infill  information. Multiple packets 136 in balises of a 

--- Document Chunk 25896 ---
balise group shall have identical content per direction. 

--- Document Chunk 25897 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP 

--- Document Chunk 25898 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 25899 ---
SUBSET-026-8 

--- Document Chunk 25900 ---
3.4.0 

--- Document Chunk 25901 ---
12/05/14

Chapter 8 

--- Document Chunk 25904 ---
Messages 

--- Document Chunk 25905 ---
Page 10/33 

--- Document Chunk 25906 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 25907 ---
8.4.1.4.5 Exception 5: A message can contain several packets 88 (Level Crossing information). 

--- Document Chunk 25908 ---
The identities of the corresponding Level Crossings (variable NI D_LX) transmitted in 

--- Document Chunk 25909 ---
the same message shall be different. 

--- Document Chunk 25910 ---
8.4.1.4.6 Exception 6: A message transmitted by a balise group can contain several packets 254 

--- Document Chunk 25911 ---
(default balise, loop or RIU information). 

--- Document Chunk 25912 ---
8.4.1.4.7 Exception 7: A message transmitted by a balise group can contain several packets 145 

--- Document Chunk 25913 ---
(Inhibition of balise group message consistency reaction). 

--- Document Chunk 25914 ---
8.4.1.4.8 Exception 8: A message transmitted by a balise group can contain several packets 0 

--- Document Chunk 25915 ---
(Virtual Balise Cover marker). 

--- Document Chunk 25916 ---
8.4.1.4.9 Exception 9: A message transmitted by a balise group can contain sev eral packets 6 

--- Document Chunk 25917 ---
(Virtual Balise Cover order). The identities (pairs of variables NID_VBCMK and NID_C) 

--- Document Chunk 25918 ---
of the corresponding VBC transmitted in the same message shall be different. 

--- Document Chunk 25919 ---
 

--- Document Chunk 25920 ---
ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

--- Document Chunk 25937 ---
Up-link telegram (track to train) (1) 

--- Document Chunk 25938 ---

--- Document Chunk 25939 ---

--- Document Chunk 25940 ---

--- Document Chunk 25941 ---
balise group. 

--- Document Chunk 25942 ---

--- Document Chunk 25943 ---

--- Document Chunk 25944 ---
duplicate of the balise before or after this one.  

--- Document Chunk 25945 ---

--- Document Chunk 25948 ---
balise group.

--- Document Chunk 25950 ---

(optional)

8.4.4 Rules for Euroradio messages 

--- Document Chunk 26008 ---
8.4.4.1 The message identifier is unique (variable NID_MESSAGE). 

--- Document Chunk 26009 ---
8.4.4.1.1 All currently not defined message identifiers are reserved for future use and shall be 

--- Document Chunk 26010 ---
considered as invalid values (i.e. like spare values). Exception: reception of information 

--- Document Chunk 26011 ---
only differing by Y with regards to the highest system version number X supported by 

--- Document Chunk 26012 ---
on-board (refer to section 3.17.3.11 b)). 

--- Document Chunk 26013 ---
8.4.4.2 Each message shall indicate its own  length through the use of the  variable 

--- Document Chunk 26014 ---
L_MESSAGE. 

--- Document Chunk 26015 ---
8.4.4.2.1 If the computed length of the message is not equal to the length given by 

--- Document Chunk 26016 ---
L_MESSAGE, the entire message shall be rejected. 

--- Document Chunk 26017 ---
8.4.4.3 The messages shall be composed of predefined variables and packets. 

--- Document Chunk 26018 ---

message.

8.5 List of radio Messages 

--- Document Chunk 26164 ---
8.5.1 Introduction 

--- Document Chunk 26165 ---
8.5.1.1 This section identifies the radio messages with corresponding Message Identifier 

--- Document Chunk 26166 ---
(“Mes. Id.”) and Message Name. It also gives a list of the version-invariant messages. 

--- Document Chunk 26167 ---

--- Document Chunk 26168 ---
priority data (E), as defined in Euroradio specifications.
